DOC.HEAD: Christian Prison Inmates Build House for Needy Family
DOC.TEXT: At a time when many residents are rallying against housing prisoners in their neighborhoods, a Houston church congregation opened its homes to four federal prisoners armed with hammers and nails. ``I was scared to death,'' said Matthew Criswell, construction manager for Houston Habitat for Humanity, which helps provide homes for poor people. ``When I got the word they were sending us four prisoners, I automatically started asking questions: `Are we going to have to keep an armed guard here? Are they going to do what I say? Am I going to have to keep them away from telephones?' ``Now I just wish they were back, doing more work,'' he said. Last week, three convicted drug dealers and an income tax evader - all members of a Christian prison program - helped build a four-bedroom house for a needy family in an impoverished Houston neighborhood. The prisoners didn't get special privilges or time off their sentences for the work, but it didn't matter to inmate Calvin Edwards, 33, who said he was working for the Lord. ``It's been a blessing for me to be out helping people,'' he said. The effort was co-sponsored by Houston Habitat Humanity and Prison Fellowship-Houston. The latter is a part of Prison Fellowship USA, founded in 1976 by Charles Colson, a Nixon administration aide sentenced to prison for his role in the Watergate scandal. Under the program, volunteers approved by their prison's warden and chaplain are allowed to take hammers and saws into the community to help others. This is the third year the program has operated in Houston. ``They do construction or renovation for needy families that couldn't be met through conventional financing,'' said Don Beard of Crossroads Baptist Church, which found homes for the inmates during their week of construction work in Houston. Other churches provided lunches. ``They stayed with these families ... showed up every night for Bible study and then they went to the job site between 8:30 a.m. and nightfall,'' said Beard, himself a former inmate convicted of embezzlement. ``They were just an inspiration to me,'' Criswell said. ``Just the fact that they have decided to turn their lives around and do what's right and help other people.'' ``That's why we're doing this,'' said Bruce Daniel, 49, a federal prisoner serving time in Texarkana. ``We're helping others while serving the Lord.''

DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE BUDGET ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Kuwaiti Refugee: Iraqi Executions Have Silenced Resistance
DOC.TEXT: A newly arrived Kuwaiti refugee says resistance to Iraqi forces virtually ended in his homeland after the occupiers began executing suspected resistance members, sometimes in front of their families. The former Health Ministry employee, Issa el-Nasrallah, said the Iraqis are forcing out Kuwaitis to ``isolate the resistance.'' His charges came as several hundred more Kuwaiti refugees arrived Sunday at the Khafji border crossing in neighboring Saudi Arabia. Iraq had again relaxed restrictions on departing Kuwaitis. Exiled Kuwaiti officials say Iraq is trying to chase away Kuwaitis and repopulate the oil-rich land with Palestinians and Iraqis. Nasrallah, who fled with his wife and four children, said many people in occupied Kuwait believe Iraq is preparing for combat there soon - presumably expecting to do battle with the U.S.-led multinational force massed against it in Saudi Arabia. ``They also want to isolate the resistance to have everyone but them leave. They're trying to force people out,'' said Nasrallah. He said acts of resistance had stopped in Kuwait City since the Iraqis began killing anyone suspected of belonging to the resistance, many in front of their families. ``Everybody's scared there. They don't know when the Iraqis will come in the house and kill them,'' said Yusuf al-Ali, 25, a Kuwaiti Airways pilot who also arrived during the weekend. Several hundred Westerners are still believed to be hiding in Kuwait, fearful of being taken to Iraq for use as human shields at military and other strategic installations. Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2 in a dispute over land and oil, annexed the emirate and declared it an Iraqi province. Later in August, Kuwaiti refugees reported that resistance fighters were staging desperate and daring attacks, including suicide bombings. At that time, they said Iraq had been unable to wipe them out. Exiled Kuwaitis have directed the resistance from a forward command post in Khafji, three miles south of the border. They had been smuggling in ammunition and communications equipment to help fighters inside Kuwait. In early September, a senior guerrilla leader said the resistance had recruited thousands of volunteers from among Kuwaiti refugees in Saudi Arabia. At that time, a senior Saudi official said the resistance was growing in strength and stepping up attacks on the Iraqi occupiers. The latest opening of the border came Friday after Iraqi authorities intensified night searches in Kuwait City, refugees said. The searches prompted many of them to leave out of fear. Iraqi troops were confiscating all identification papers in Kuwait, the refugees reported. They said Iraqi authorities had announced that everyone must hold identification cards issued in Baghdad, effectively making them all into Iraqi citizens. Those arriving said Iraqi troops at the border were seizing some men under age 40 and taking bribes to allow others to cross. Refugees claim young men are being sent back for Iraqi military service. The new opening of the border raised Saudi fears the Iraqis are planning attempts to infiltrate agents into the kingdom. The new refugee influx is the largest since mid-September, when 7,000 Kuwaitis poured through over three days. In the new crush, more than 1,000 refugees have arrived since Friday. An estimated 300,000 Kuwaiti refugees are in Saudi Arabia and neighboring Persian Gulf states. Before the invasion, Kuwait had a native population of about 600,000.

DOC.HEAD: Juvenile Crime Needs Stricter Punishments, Police Chiefs Say
DOC.TEXT: Oklahoma City police Chief Dave McBride says coddling juvenile offenders just leads to more adult criminals. McBride, speaking at the 97th International Association of Chiefs of Police Convention, criticized some parents and said the courts' handling of juveniles is ``the biggest failure of the justice system.'' ``There's almost no such thing as a first-time (adult) offender,'' McBride said. ``Most of the adults in prison were handled a half-dozen times as juveniles.'' McBride and more than 7,000 other police chiefs from around the world have gathered in Tulsa for the convention. Chiefs from Japan, the Philippines and Germany also are scheduled to attend the six-day meeting, which began Sunday. McBride said he doesn't have all the solutions to juvenile crime, but believes a starting point is at home. ``There are more parental delinquents than there are juvenile delinquents,'' he said. ``Too many parents send their kids to school to learn morality. They don't have any guidance at home.'' Kansas City, Kan., police Chief Tom Dailey said more and more juveniles are getting into trouble in his city, especially young car thieves and youth gang members. He said vehicle thefts jumped by 1,000 this year in his city, compared to 1989. ``We've got the same thing here,'' said Perry Anderson, chief of police in Miami, Fla. ``They're active in auto thefts and burglary. We arrest them, then they're right back on the streets again. ``We just don't have the space to house them.'' Juvenile thieves are the least of Chicago's worries, with more serious offenders occupying officers' time, said police Detective Lt. Howard Allen of Chicago's youth section. ``They probably wouldn't even get into a secure facility,'' he said. ``Maybe if they had eight to 10 charges against them and the facility wasn't full, but usually not.'' Most of the youths who go to jail or prison are charged with violent crimes like robbery, arson and rape, Allen said. Chuck Gruber, president of the police chiefs group, said the conference is the best chance for police from around the world to compare notes and share techniques. ``It's a learning process for police chiefs, sharing information and hopefully coming away better prepared to do our jobs,'' said Gruber, who is chief in Elgin, Ill. Delegates will discuss crime issues common to almost every part of the world, ranging from traffic tickets to hate crimes and international money laundering, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Deputies Involved in 56 Questionable Shootings Since 1985
With PM-Police Chiefs
DOC.TEXT: More than 50 people shot by Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies since 1985 may have been unarmed, and most of the victims were members of minority groups, a newspaper reported. Sheriff's deputies have been involved in 56 questionable shootings in the last five years in which 26 people were killed. None of the victims fired a weapon, the Los Angeles Daily News reported Sunday. Just four of the shootings involved undisputed evidence that the victim had some type of weapon in hand when deputies fired - the weapons were a knife, a push broom brush head, a sauce pan and a metal pipe, according to the report. In the other cases, there was conflicting evidence over whether the victims possessed any weapon, the newspaper said. The newspaper study, which examined the department's 202 shootings since 1985, relied on the sheriff's own investigation reports, called ``shooting books.'' Eighty-percent of the 56 disputed cases involved members of minority groups, department records showed. Sheriff Sherman Block defended his department's record, saying deputies are faced with rising crime in minority neighborhoods where the ``perception'' of danger often leads them into situations where shooting is justified. ``There is bound to be a higher level of violent confrontation between law enforcement and those people,'' Block said. The department has refused to disclose how many deputies were disciplined in the shootings or identify them, the newspaper said. Last month, a civil rights lawsuit was filed against the sheriff's department on behalf of 75 people who allegedly were victims of brutality or racial harassment by deputies at a sheriff's station in the city of Lynwood. Block said the department is conducting an internal investigation into brutality questions.

DOC.HEAD: Britain's `Desert Rats' Under U.S. Marine Command
DOC.TEXT: The soldiers of Britain's 7th armored brigade - the ``Desert Rats'' of North Africa fame - have been assigned to U.S. Marine control in an unusual pairing in the Persian Gulf multinational forces. Officials say that in the event of war, the 7,000 British troops would fight as an integral unit of the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade, relying on Marine air support and using NATO-type communications gear. Both sides appear to welcome the teaming despite their contrasting skills. The 33,000 Marines, trained primarily as an amphibious assault force using helicopters and landing craft, have been in the Saudi sand for six weeks. The 7th Brigade, despite its desert legacy, has spent much of the last 40 years in the green fields of western Europe. The British brigade's two regiments recently spent some time training in hot, dry terrain in Canada, but conditions there hardly compare with what the British will find in the Saudi desert, with its extreme heat and equipment-ravaging sand. Advance parties of the brigade are already in Saudi Arabia and Royal Engineers are building a tent city, located close to the Marine base, to be ready when the main force begins to arrive by air on Oct. 16. The unit's equipment, including 120 advanced-design Challenger tanks, will be sent aboard 31 chartered ships, British officials say. The Challengers, fitted with 120mm main guns and what British experts call the world's best armor, are ``superior to anything the Iraqis have,'' British Armed Forces Minister Archibald Hamilton said during a vist on Saturday. Hamilton, the second-ranking official in Britain's Defense Ministry, told reporters that the idea of putting the 7th Brigade under Marine operational control originated with the Americans as a way of ``enhancing the capability of the Marines.'' ``We welcome it,'' agreed a Marine officer who asked not to be named. ``Everybody will keep their national identity, but tactically the Brits will be just another maneuver element in our force.'' U.S. officers say the Marines will furnish the air cover for the 7th Brigade as well as their own troops. The British will be responsible for their own logistics, resupply and transportation.

DOC.HEAD: Denver Police Minority Hiring Program Displeases Whites and Blacks
With PM-Police Chiefs
DOC.TEXT: City efforts to improve race relations by increasing the number of black police officers instead have generated ill-feelings among whites and blacks alike. Whites are angry that black candidates for police training didn't have to score as high as white applicants on the entrance exam. Also vexed were members of the Denver Black Police Officers Association. ``Blacks as much as any others want to make sure that standards are not lowered,'' said Kirk L. Dunham, president of the black officers association. ``Our lives are on the line because we do the same jobs as white and Hispanic officers. We want competent, qualified black officers.'' The complaints arose after all 96 black applicants who passed an entrance test in July were accepted for further testing, while only 89 of 636 whites were accepted and 15 of 160 Hispanics advanced. Although all those accepted scored passing grades, some of the blacks accepted scored lower than some of the rejected whites. The 200 people who passed the first hurdle are competing for only 40 slots in the police academy class that begins Nov. 1. The city's Civil Service Commission is operating under a court decree that requires 45 percent of three upcoming police academy classes to be black. The quota resulted from an agreement between the city and the police union. Blacks make up only 6 percent of the 1,331-member police force. Seventy-seven percent of the officers are white, the rest are Hispanic or other minorities. Blacks account for 12 percent of the city's population. City officials also were concerned by the high failure rate of blacks on the written, physical and psychological portions of the July test. Of the 194 blacks who took the test, 49.5 percent passed, while 79.5 percent of the whites passed and 58.8 percent of the Hispanics passed. The city hired Dr. David Morris, president of the Morris and McDaniel consulting firm of Washington, D.C., to review the tests for any cultural biases. Morris said he found none, but he did cite problems with the city's minority recruiting program. In one instance, recruiters pursued randm candidates at a shopping mall, he said. In another instance, they recruited blacks who couldn't read and tried to teach them to read. ``That's like sending a baseball coach or a football coach to a mall to recruit athletes, just because they're black,'' Morris said. ``It was a waste of their time and the taxpayers' money.'' He said the city needs to begin recruiting minorities in high school, find the ones with an aptitude for police work and support them through school and the academy, financially and academically. ``If the city would do that, it wouldn't need an affirmative action program,'' he said. ``In three or four years, the problem would take care of itself.'' White candidates also were angered because the city set up a tutoring program to help blacks pass the test. Morris said whites also received tutoring, but not as much as blacks. Jim Belknap, clerical services supervisor for the Civil Service Commission, stressed that the city did not lower its standards for black applicants and that all who were accepted made a passing grade. ``You're still talking about B-minus or C-plus students,'' he said. John Wyckoff, a spokesman for the police department, said he received just five complaints from citizens concerned the city was hiring less than qualified police officers. ``We're not compromising our position,'' he said. ``They still have to pass the test. An individual who is not qualified is not hired.''

DOC.HEAD: Kansas City Police Image Damaged by Brutality Cases
With PM-Police Chiefs
DOC.TEXT: Singled out for praise from the White House as the year began, the city police department will close 1990 struggling to restore its image after a rash of brutality and racism allegations. Police brass are developing a ``behavior modification'' program for offending officers after rising use of force complaints and the killing of more suspected criminals in 1990 than in the three previous years combined. ``I think everybody is certainly not at the top of their game. We've had an awful lot of incidents just in the last five months,'' Police Chief Steven Bishop said. ``I think it has hurt the relations greatly between this police department and the community.'' Only a few of his 1,200 officers violate citizen's rights, but the bad apples are threatening to impair neighborhood confidence in police, Bishop said. The trouble comes after President Bush visited in January to praise cooperation between police and local anti-crime groups, calling the city a model for the war on drugs. The simmering image crisis reached a fever pitch in late September, when local television station KMBC-TV broadcast videotape of officers beating a white man. News footage showed officers yanking the man through the open window of his van and onto the ground, where one officer kicked him several times and another officer hit him with a small club. ``Most officers are just as ashamed and disgusted by what these officers did as I am and I think the community at large is,'' said Bishop, a 20-year veteran of the force who became chief in June. The man had led officers on an hour-long chase through three counties. He was charged with trying to run a police officer off the road. The two officers resigned after the incident and Bishop banned the weighted leather clubs called ``slappers'' that one of the officers used. Clay County Prosecuting Attorney Mike Reardon said a grand jury would look into the case. Last spring, several white officers surrounded and bloodied a black priest with nightsticks after stopping his car because they said a passenger matched the description of an armed robber. Neither the priest nor his companion were charged. In another incident, a white officer hit a black minister in the head with a shotgun. Officers mistakenly thought the man, a native of Nigeria, was drunk because of his thick accent. He also was not charged. Both clergymen claimed the attacks were racially motivated. Officers have shot and killed six suspects so far in 1990, compared to five over the previous three years. Four of the people killed were black, and two were white. In one case, four officers fired 19 times at a black man brandishing a barbecue fork. Black community leaders said the death was racially motivated, but a grand jury and Bishop cleared the four officers, two white and two black, of wrongdoing. Bishop suspended the officers who beat the ministers, and he suspended three undercover officers involved in the shooting of a black man who remains crippled. The chief appointed a task force to develop ways to identify officers with rough tendencies. The department plans a ``behavior modification'' program to teach problem officers how to better deal with citizens. Alvin Brooks, the city's human relations director, is a founder of the Ad Hoc Group Against Crime, a liaison between the department and the black community. He said the recent cases reinforced a perception in black neighborhoods that officers want to harass and brutalize blacks. ``It becomes a self-fulfilling prophesy,'' said Brooks, a former police officer and prominent black leader. Despite the prevailing negative perceptions, Brooks said most officers enforce the law fairly. ``Overall, I don't think you can say it's racism,'' he said. ``I think it's unfortunate that a few folks, like in any other profession, lose sight of their mission.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Dispute Closes Parks, Museums: `It Stinks,' Tourists Say
DOC.TEXT: Camp David is open as usual for President Bush and his guests, but the closed sign is hung at the visitors' center in the surrounding Catoctin National Park. It was a scene repeated at national parks from New York to Hawaii after the federal government ran out of money at midnight Friday. The shutdown ruined some vacations and inconvenienced countless Americans over the weekend. But its full impact will not be felt until Tuesday, when federal offices are scheduled to reopen after the three-day Columbus Day weekend. Most of the 2.4 million federal workers were being told to report to work on Tuesday, but without a budget agreement most would likely be sent home soon afterward. Richard Darman, the White House budget director, said only workers performing services needed to ``protect life and property'' would stay on the job. That includes Weather Service meteorologists, air traffic controllers, prison guards, meat and poultry inspectors and the military. Mail delivery would continue since the Postal Office is not dependent on government appropriations. And the National Hurricane Center in Miami was continuing to track tropical storm Klaus. Congress and Bush administration officials continued wrangling over a budget into the night Sunday. Bush, meanwhile, spent most of the weekend at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md. The president opted to travel by motorcade rather than take a helicopter; it was cheaper that way, a White House aide said. Camp David is located in the Catoctin Mountain Park and the adjacent Cunningham Falls State Park. However, the retreat is a Navy installation, staffed permanently by Navy personnel and Marine guards. Its recreational facilities were not subject to the shutdown. In the nation's capital, the Washington Monument, the White House and the Smithsonian museums were closed. The grounds of the National Zoo were open, but the animal buildings were not. Sightseers could walk around the Lincoln Memorial or the Vietnam Veterans Memorial but there were no Park Service officials to answer questions and no cleanup crews to pick up trash. Leaders of the National Committee for American War Veterans, a volunteer group that maintains a vigil near the Vietnam memorial, said they would begin picking up trash on the Mall. ``This one's closed, too, Dad,'' was a refrain repeated time after time around the capital. A Roanoke Rapids, N.C., Boy Scout troop had this reaction to the locked doors at the National Air and Space Museum: ``It stinks.'' Troop leader Bill Johnson said, ``The boys won't forget this and I expect they'll go home and tell their parents about what happened to them.'' Ironically, the Capitol was one of the few tourist sites open in Washington. ``Unfortunately we are the only game in town so our tour guides are really busy,'' said Tom Keating, executive assistant to the House sergeant at arms. Still, the action in the Capitol was limited at best. When the House came into session at 4 p.m. - only to recess again moments later - loud booing erupted from the galleries packed with tourists. ``They should have settled the budget instead of going on vacation,'' said 20-year-old Kara DiMugno of Southington, Conn., referring to the long recess members of Congress took in August. While the national parks were not closed, services were virtually nil. For the most part, restrooms were closed, first aid assistance was not available and guided tours were canceled. At the Saratoga National Park in New York, park rangers turned away a man who annually re-enacts Gen. Horatio Gates' defeat of British soldiers. Sunday was the 213th anniversary of the Revolutionary War battle. The annual historic fair was canceled at Georgia's Andersonville National Historic Site, the Confederate prison camp where 123,000 Union soldiers died during the Civil War. ``An awful lot of people were angry that we were closing the gates, but when Congress said close it down, we closed it down,'' said park ranger Mark Ragan. John Diehl of Chicago was vacationing in Hawaii and had hoped to see the Arizona Memorial before heading to the island of Kauai. Instead he and his friends were greeted by a closed sign. ``It's time to elect some new representatives and senators, since they can't get the budget passed,'' he said, joining other tourists peering through locked glass doors of the visitor center, staring out over Pearl Harbor at the memorial. At Yosemite National Park in California, visitors were forced to leave the campgrounds after non-essential rangers were sent home, but some hikers parked vehicles outside gates and went back in on foot. ``We ought to lay off the people at the top,'' said Richard Chaboya of San Jose. ``Why attack the pleasures of the average people.'' Judy Laymon, a clerk at the private Lake Amistad Resort and Marina in south Texas on the Rio Grande River, said, ``What I want to know is are they going to shut down the borders? I'd hate to go over to Mexico to eat and not be able to get back.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Once again, the government finds itself on the financial precipice because of the inability of a Republican White House and a Democratic Congress to agree to a solution to the worsening deficit problem. Here are answers to some frequently asked questions about the impact of budget stalemate on Americans:

Q: Why is the federal government forced to shut down? A: Because the budget dispute prevented enactment of any of the 13 regular appropriations bills for fiscal 1991, the federal budget year that began Oct. 1. The Constitution states that ``No money shall be drawn from the Treasury but in consequence of appropriations made by law.'' While some appropriations are in permanent law, most day-to-day government operations are renewed annually in one of the 13 spending bills. What that means is that government agencies are not allowed to spend money, including for salaries or purchases, unless there is a law authorizing them to do so. Since there wasn't even a stopgap law in place Saturday, the agencies were legally required to send people home and close down.

Q: Has this ever happened before? A: Yes. Similar squabbles have forced the government to shut down temporarily three times in the past decade. It happened briefly in November 1981 when an estimated 400,000 employees were dismissed at midday after President Reagan vetoed an emergency money bill. On Oct. 4, 1984, about 500,000 government workers were sent home by Congress' failure to approve an appropriations bill. And on Oct. 16, 1986, the government sent 500,000 ``non-essential'' employees home, but Congress later in the day passed an appropriations bill acceptable to Reagan and workers were ordered to report on their next shift. Congress, as it had done in 1981 and 1984, passed a resolution ordering that employees furloughed get their regular salaries anyway.

Q: What is this ``Gramm-Rudman Act'' I keep hearing so much about and why was it passed? A: Congress enacted the law, named for Sens. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, and Warren Rudman, R-N.H., in 1985 and revised it in 1987. In passing the law, Congress in effect admitted that it could not make the tough choices needed to halt deficit spending without some outside pressure to force them into it. The law requires Congress and the president to reduce the deficit to predetermined annual targets, leading eventually to a balanced budget. If the targets are missed, the law requires across-the-board spending cuts to do the job Congress could not. The target for fiscal 1991 is $64 billion, but the president's estimates are so far above that number that Bush and Congress agree it is impossible to reach. They will change it to a much higher number - if they agree on an overall budget package. The result will be to delay the goal of a balanced budget probably until 1996 or beyond.

Q: What events prompted the current shutdown? A: On Sept. 30, the last day of fiscal 1990, Bush and the bipartisan congressional leadership announced agreement on a five-year, $500 billion deficit-reduction package that included approximately $134 billion in new taxes. Congress passed and Bush signed a one-week temporary appropriations bill to keep the government operating while Congress passed the plan. Bush went on national television Tuesday night to appeal for congressional support of the package, but it was decisively voted down Thursday night. Members of the House and Senate approved another stopgap spending measure, known as a ``continuing resolution,'' on Friday. That would have kept the government running until Friday, Oct. 12, and would have given lawmakers another week's time to arrive at a budget consensus. But Bush vetoed that bill Saturday.

Q: How will the shutdown affect me? Can I still catch my flight, for example? A: The government began closing so-called ``non-essential'' facilities Saturday, including parks and tourist attractions, but air traffic controllers are among those considered essential. However, if the deadlock persisted, there would be a reduction in the number of controllers allowed to work.

Q: What is meant by ``essential'' and ``non-essential?'' A: Each agency decides what is an essential service. But, generally, staying on the job will be workers dealing with national security, health, emergency and similar things. The military, air traffic controllers, border guards, medical institution personnel and prison guards will be unaffected. Federal meat and poultry inspection will continue during a general shutdown.

DOC.HEAD: Exotic Animals Blessed in New York to Honor of St. Francis
DOC.TEXT: An elephant, a camel, a llama and other creatures great and small marched through the bronze doors of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and down the church's center aisle in honor of the Feast of St. Francis. ``St. Francis Day belongs to the city and all its creatures and the animals bless us as much as we bless them,'' the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, dean of the cathedral, said Sunday. ``So, in the presence of these beautiful beasts, we will pray this year for ourselves: that we may have the wisdom and courage to be more faithful custodians of God's creation,'' he said. The procession of borrowed animals also included a horse, goat, pig, eagle and chimpanzee. Morton also blessed parishioners' pets and even a petrie dish containing algae and one-celled organisms. A smaller animal-blessing celebration was held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Brooklyn. Two horses from the Police Department's Mounted Unit and a police German shepherd, Jake, joined other dogs, cats, snakes, a ferret, gerbils, a mouse and goldfish in the lineup blessed by the Rev. Peter Cullen. ``I thought on the whole they behaved very well,'' Cullen said. ``They're often better behaved than the people.'' Afterward, the blessed critters munched on dog biscuits and carrots - with cookies and soda for the humans. The Feast of St. Francis is Oct. 4. The animal-blessing ceremonies are typically held on the nearest Sunday. St. Francis of Assisi, who died in the 13th Century, is associated with a simple love of nature and is often depicted preaching to birds.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Welfare Programs Still Face Cuts, but Less Than Before
DOC.TEXT: The state's welfare providers are going to have to bite the bullet this year, but not as hard as once feared, thanks to a last-minute infusion of $93.2 million in new-found revenue. ``This is going to ease the pain ... a lot,'' said Baldwin Bunkley, budget chairman for a coalition of nearly 100 advocacy organizations for Florida's economically disadvantaged, including the poor, homeless and disabled. Florida, like other states, is still strapped for cash for social service programs, but an 11th-hour surge in lottery ticket sales, coupled with an early loan repayment and money found in various trust-fund accounts, has helped ease the financial burden this year. As a result, Gov. Bob Martinez and the state Cabinet are to vote Tuesday on a proposed $54.1 million cut in state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services programs. The figure, recommended by state budget officials Friday, is down from an earlier proposed cutback of $147.3 million. Officials say the $54.1 million shortfall will still add up to substantial reductions in programs, however. Private day care centers in south and central Florida may have to stop serving hundreds of poor children whose single mothers are trying to find work and break the cycle of welfare dependency, said Jack Levine, executive director of the Florida Center for Youth & Children. Several new programs designed to keep juvenile delinquents out of detention centers and adult prisons also will be slashed, Levine said. ``These juvenile slots are, pure and simple, prison prevention,'' he said. Also, anyone seriously hurt in an accident could be affected if the state reduces its support of emergency room equipment and personnel at hospitals, Bunkley said. The need for budget cuts became evident last month when state economists discovered tax collections would fall $540 million short of projections. Under the state constitution, Florida must adopt a balanced budget, but in the past few weeks, the state found $215.2 million to offset the reduced revenues. About $80 million came from a loan to the Department of Transportation from the general revenue fund that wasn't due to be paid back until 1996. The rest came from trust funds where money is kept for specific state programs and a windfall of lottery revenues when sales soared for last month's $106.5 million Lotto jackpot. Chris Schuh, executive director of the state Association for Retarded Citizens, said she was thankful the extra money was found. But she noted the proposed cuts also come in a year when lawmakers are not appropriating cost-of-living increases to private groups that contract with the state to provide welfare services. ``It's a ridiculous situation to be in, that you are thankful that your programs are not going to be cut,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: 80-Year-Old Woodworker Doesn't Let Blindness Stand in His Way
LaserPhoto KAN1
DOC.TEXT: The spinning drill bit bites into soft pine an inch from Ed Beherns' left index finger, finding its mark safely over and over. His skill in creating wooden toys would be remarkable for anyone, but Beherns accomplishes his work without seeing what he's doing. The 80-year-old craftsman is blind. There is no hint that he can't see his work in the finished wooden tractor-trailer trucks, the small railroad steam engines, the pickup trucks, wheelbarrows and wooden animals he builds in his basement shop. ``I know just about where everything is - unless somebody moves it,'' said Beherns, who moves gracefully through the narrow and twisted passages in his workshop where the musty smell of cedar and the spicy aroma of freshly worked pine fill the air. He says he finds joy building toys, children's rocking chairs, tables and doll cradles. He sells his work, but only for enough to cover his expenses. And he looks ahead to new challenges. In his mind lives the blueprint for a working steam threshing machine - a scale model of the one his brother, Harry, used to own. It will be 18 inches long and an alcohol burner will make the steam. The thresher will be metal and Beherns will use the metal-working skills he developed during a 31-year career at a Kankakee factory. He started working with wood 10 years ago, shortly after he began losing his sight to glaucoma. A blind craftsman from Champaign visited him and suggested he try building bird houses. Now Beherns has a long waiting list of people who want his custom-built bird houses to give as holiday gifts. His interest in toys originated a bit earlier, when he was growing up on a farm in Illinois. ``When I was a kid - you know there wasn't too much money in those days - I used to make my own toys,'' he said. ``I made trucks - a whole construction outfit. Even a crane. And I made a Caterpillar tractor and put an alarm clock (mechanism) in it to drive the thing.'' His blindness makes him an even better toymaker, because now he feels the contours and tests the smoothness of finished surfaces with hands made extra sensitive by his lack of sight. ``Before,'' he says, ``I'd only look at the pieces.''

DOC.HEAD: 13-Foot-Long, 85-Pound Boa Constrictor Loose in Syracuse
DOC.TEXT: Rabbits beware: There's a hungry 13-foot-long snake in the grass. Snake owner Thomas M. Thorton, 26, reported Sunday night that his pet boa constrictor had slithered away. He told police that the snake could become ``easily agitated'' because it had not been fed its usual daily meal of a full-grown rabbit. Thorton said the snake measures 1 foot around, 13 feet long and weighs about 85 pounds. He said he put the snake in the grass for a moment, and when he looked down his pet had escaped, according to a police report. The Onondaga County Sheriff's Department said a helicopter was sent to light up the area, near the Burnet Park Zoo, but the snake was not found. Police said they do not believe the snake poses a danger to people.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Awarded Distinguished Flying Cross After 46-Year Wait
DOC.TEXT: It took 46 years, but the U.S. Air Force finally honored a World War II hero with its most prestigious medal for airborne bravery. As family and friends gathered Saturday around his bed at the Hallmark Nursing Center, a U.S. Air Force colonel pinned the long-awaited Distinguished Flying Cross on the chest of Jack Ward. As co-pilot of a B-24 bomber, an injured Ward continued to fly his plane over Austria and Hungary after it had been hit, allowing crew members to parachute to the ground. The pilot had died instantly. ``There are five of us living today because of him.'' said Gilbert Fisher, the plane's nose gunner from Bethesda, Md. A military oversight kept Ward from receiving his medal. His wife, Beverly, wrote to politicians and military officials. Her efforts were futile until a newspaper article caught the attention of Rep. Dana Rohrabacher. Rohrabacher's staff gathered accounts of the mission from those who flew with Ward and eventually the Air Force relented. Ward, 67, a former Los Angeles teacher who suffered a stroke eight years ago, stared at the ceiling with brimming eyes as he was praised during Saturday's ceremony. Ward was only able to respond with a stick clenched in his teeth. Pointing to a board with letters on it, he spelled out: ``Thanks for coming.'' ``I thought, frankly, he was going to be dead before this happened,'' Mrs. Ward said. ``This is like being able to hear your own eulogy.''

DOC.HEAD: Not on This Sidewalk, Surfer
DOC.TEXT: The big wheels here don't want to be bothered by little wheels. British Columbia government officials have banned skateboarding and roller skating on the grounds of the provincial Legislature, a longtime gathering spot for speedy young daredevils. Under a recently approved order, offenders who don't leave the grounds when asked can be tossed off bodily by security guards.The ban also applies to Confederation Park, just across the street. Persistent skateboarding scofflaws can face fines reaching $500.

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong Takes Its Glamor Show On the Road
DOC.TEXT: Promoters of Hong Kong's unlimited future as a capitalist empire brought a glittering road show to Los Angeles this weekend, with an emphasis on the colony's most glamorous product - fashion. Eager to woo Western investors, the Hong Kong Trade Development Council played down the impending return of the British crown colony to China in 1997 and staged a five-day cultural celebration called ``Festival of the Lantern.'' Its aim is to show off Hong Kong's best - and opening night was a Hollywood-style extravaganza with a dazzling fashion show, colorful lion dances and fireworks lighting up the sky over the Century City Shopping Center and Marketplace. The full moon shone brightly on this replica ff the traditional Hong Kong moon festival. ``We want the public to be aware of Hong Kong,'' said Christopher Cheng, a garment manufacturer and member of the HTDC board who helped stage the event. The Los Angeles promotion is one of 10 being held in cities around the world. Cheng's California-based Pacific Coast Highway sportswear firm is part of his $250 million a year fashion business which manufacturers 20 percent of its products in Hong Kong. Cheng, a native of Hong Kong educated in the United States, has vowed to keep doing business in Hong Kong long after the 1997 transfer of power. The fashion show is a key element in promoting Hong Kong's image, he said. The territory long has been a fashion manufacturing hub for American and European firms, but has failed to export many creations by its own designers. ``To raise the status of Hong Kong we have to encourage young designers,'' Cheng said, as the work of a dozen new fashion names was displayed on an outdoor runway to the applause of appreciative shoppers and local dignitaries. From the bright harlequin knit sweater jackets and coats of Hidy Ng to extravagantly beaded gold gowns by Susana To, the show was a knockout. There was oriental influence in the work of Mayeelok whose ``Indian Night'' collection drew gasps of admiration. Mayeelok's Thai silk jackets in brilliant shades of green, orange and gold trimmed in black and embellished in gold were elegantly teamed with flowing black chiffon skirts and pantaloons. Glitter wasn't the only option in this overview of Hong Kong designs. Wool crepe suits with flowing capes were the forte of Dominic Mok of M.D.P. Fashion Studio whose hooded, rust-colored coat drew loud applause. Earth tones, pleated sleeves and wide swinging skirts were features of innovative knit ensembles by Savy Wong and Patrina Tam. Long skirts and trumpet sleeves also showed up in the silk jacquard designs of Sandy Liu for Retkie International. The formals, however, stole the show. The black velvet and chiffon gowns of Ben Yeung of Benny's Fashion and Design Center and the ruffled, pleated and beaded chiffon numbers by Patrick Li of Archee were anybody's dream dresses. The ultimate in glamour came from Susana To whose gold-upon-gold creations were show stoppers. With fringed gold gloves and shoulder-length gold earrings as accessories, these dresses were world class. A floor-length black velvet sheath with long sleeves, slit up the front and trimmed in gold and white beading was fit for a movie queen.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Alcoholism, Drug Abuse Much Higher Among Homosexuals
DOC.TEXT: The rate of alcoholism and drug abuse among homosexuals may be three times as high as for people in society's mainstream, it was reported today. Three out of every 10 homosexuals have a drinking or drug abuse problem, according to figures from the National Lesbian and Gay Health Foundation. About one out of 10 people in mainstream society have the same types of problems, according to The Boston Globe, which cited the gay health group's figures. Fraelean Curtis, a Boston clinical social worker and president of the National Association of Lesbian and Gay Alcoholism Professionals, said lesbians are at even greater risk of substance abuse than gay men because they also must deal with sexism in a society that tends to devalue women. Many homosexuals may turn to alcohol or drugs because they suffer from ``diminished self-esteem and impaired sense of self-worth,'' said Don Wert, executive director of the Pride Institute in Minnesota, an in-patient substance abuse center specifically for homosexuals. ``That's not unlike other marginalized social groups,'' Wert said. ``Among native Americans and in black and Hispanic communities, you tend to see the same overrepresentation of addiction.'' In the case of homosexuals, finding a cure for substance abuse can be more difficult, Wert said. ``Ordinarily, clients (who) are recovering from alcohol and drugs tend to feel better about themselves,'' he said. ``But for lesbian and gay clients, you're taking away their anesthesia, and they are feeling ... more strongly than ever their sense of not being OK, of being alien in their own communities, schools, churches and homes. ``The difference in treatment for lesbians and gay people is that part of their recovery means examining, understanding, affirming and ultimately celebrating their sexuality also,'' Wert said.

DOC.HEAD: KGB Boards Greenpeace Ship off Soviet Arctic Nuclear Test Site
DOC.TEXT: Armed KGB border guards boarded a Greenpeace vessel in the arctic early today after it defied a Soviet ban and sent four activists ashore to a Soviet nuclear test site, environmentalists aboard the ship said. The Dutch-registered ship MV Greenpeace stopped in the Barents Sea off Novaya Zemlya island after the Soviet icebreaker threatened to open fire, and allowed the 15 Soviets aboard. Radio contact with the Greenpeace was lost about 20 minutes later, Shannon Fagan of Greenpeace in Norway said. In a radio report from the ship, activist Steve Shallhorn said the Soviets who boarded told the Greenpeace crew that their ship had violated Soviet territory. A few hours earlier, the protesters sent four activists ashore in rubber raft, Shallhorn said. ``We don't know if they are aware that our party went ashore. We are going to try to stay in the area until we get our landing party back, which could take a couple days,'' he said. He said the ship was four miles from the island. In Moscow, KGB spokesman Viktor Pressman said the agency had no information on the Greenpeace ship. The KGB supervises border guards who would be involvced in such an action. The MV Greenpeace, with about 35 Western activists and five Soviets aboard, had permission to tour the Soviet arctic but has been told by the Soviets to steer clear of Novaya Zemlya, where the anti-nuclear organization had planned a protest. The island was a primary Soviet nuclear test site until the early 1960s. Greenpeace claims it was used as recently as 1988. The group claims new tests are planned there, stirring opposition in Nordic government circles and among other environmental groups. Shallhorn said the icebreaker, armed with deck guns, had pursued the MV Greenpeace since Wednesday and had threatened to fire ``so we decided to stop.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctor: Baby Diagnosed With Usually Fatal Heart Defect Heals Self
DOC.TEXT: An infant diagnosed with a usually fatal heart defect healed by himself, amazing doctors who thought a transplant was the only way to save his life. The parents of 9-week-old Weston Wells Kilpatrick will be able to bring him home this week, officials at Loma Linda University Medical Center said. Dr. Steven Gundry, a pioneer in infant heart transplant surgery, said it is unlikely the child will ever need a transplant. ``It's the first time we've seen it,'' Gundry said Saturday, adding that he believed the healed birth defect was unprecedented in medical history. Weston, who was born July 27, was brought to Loma Linda University Medical Center when he was 4 days old, after doctors concluded he had hypoplastic left heart syndrome. The boy's damaged heart grew stronger as he waited for a heart transplant donor, Gundry said. ``Theoretically, we knew the left ventricle might be able to grow, because we know the right ventricle can grow if you keep the blood flowing, but to our knowledge it has never been reported for the left ventricle,'' the doctor said. Parents Layne and Janet Kilpatrick, both 31, had moved from Lompoc to Redlands to be near the medical center known for advances in child heart transplants. Doctors determined Weston's heart had three abnormalities that would normally have killed a baby within two weeks if left untreated, Gundry said. He had an abnormal mitral valve, which regulates the flow of blood through the heart; an abnormally small left ventricle, the pumping chamber of the left side of the heart; and a constricted aorta, the main artery that carries blood through the body. As the family waited for a heart donor, doctors treated Weston with a drug that kept open a heart blood vessel that normally shuts down after birth. A few weeks ago, doctors noticed that the baby's left ventricle had grown considerably and was gradually becoming functional. A surgical team successfully performed an operation Friday to enlarge Weston's narrowed artery and to close the artery that was no longer needed. Gundry said Weston may need minor surgery in the future, but will probably not need a heart transplant.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Release of British Hostages Expected Soon
DOC.TEXT: A Beirut newspaper today quoted diplomats as saying final arrangements were being made for the release of British hostages believed held by Shiite Moslem extremists i Lebanon. It was the latest in a series of reports predicting some would be freed this week. In related development, a British newspaper quoted a Shiite leader in Lebanon as saying the future of Western hostages should no longer be linked to that of Arab prisoners. The paper, the Independent, said the statement could herald a breakthrough in efforts to secure the release of the 13 Westerners missing and believed held hostage in Lebanon by pro-Iranian Shiite fundamentalists. A series of news reports have predicted the release of foreign hostages following the restoration of British and Iranian diplomatic ties in late September after an interruption of 19 months. The ties were broken during the dispute over Iranian death threats against British novelist Salman Rushdie. President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran apparently has been seeking to free the hostages to help improve relations with the West following the June 1989 death of his country's fundamentalist patriarch, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Rafsanjani has been opposed by radicals in his own government. The leftist Beirut newspaper, As-Safir, today quoted unidentified diplomats as saying the release of the British captives ``awaits the proper time.'' But it said arrangements for freeing them have been put ``on a hot burner.'' It was impossible to verify the report. The paper is known to maintain close links with leftist and fundamentalist Shiite factions. The Beirut paper said the fate of the foreign hostages also depends on the Lebanese government extending its authority to ``greater Beirut,'' which includes the southern slums. Those slums, where most of the Westerners are believed held, are a stronghold for the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, the umbrella group for the captors. The Syrian-backed government of President Elias Hrawi has pledged to spread its authority over all of Beirut as a step toward ending the 15-year civil war. In another report, the conservative newspaper Ad-Diyar said Sunday that an unidentified Iranian envoy had arrived in Beirut to complete preparations for freeing Anglican church envoy Terry Waite ``in the next few days.'' Arab sources in Syria said Sunday that Syrian officials were making strenuous efforts to free some Westerners missing in Lebanon. One source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa was trying hard ``to resolve the issue but was encountering unexpected obstacles.'' He did not elaborate, but he noted that Sharaa was expected to meet soon with Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati to discuss the issue. Ad-Diyar said Waite's release was expected to be ``the preface to releasing all British hostages in Lebanon.'' Waite, 51, the envoy of the archbishop of Canterbury, disappeared in west Beirut on Jan. 20, 1987. He had left his hotel for a meeting with Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, the group that claims to hold American captives Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held foreign captive. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The other missing Britons are journalist John McCarthy, retired pilot Jack Mann and writer Alec Collett. The Revolutionary Organization of Socialist Moslems claimed in 1986 that it hanged Collett in retaliation for Britain's support of U.S. air raids on Libya. No body was produced, but British officials believe Collett is dead. In its report today, the Independent quoted Sheikh Mohamed Hussein Fadlallah as saying the hostage issue ``can be settled in such a way that no party feels he has been blackmailed.'' The sheikh as described as the most important spiritual adviser to Hezbollah. In the past, kidnappers have said the Western hostages won't all be freed until the release of Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails and of Shiite extremists held in Kuwait. Fadlallah said he believed, as earlier reports have indicated, that the 15 Moslems imprisoned in Kuwait for bombing the French and U.S. embassies there in 1983 had escaped after the Iraqi Aug. 2 invasion. He said he believes they are no longer in Kuwait. ``We call on every side that could do something about this humanitarian issue to dissociate these two problems from each other,'' the sheikh said. The sheikh was also quoted as saying he had been interviewed by Anderson two days before the American reporter was abducted. ``I tried very hard to help him on several occasions, and I was unable to do so. But the change in the political atmosphere in the region and in the world could bring about a happy result,'' the sheikh was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans Teachers Vote to End Strike
DOC.TEXT: Some 3,000 teachers voted to end their 3-week-old strike immediately and accept a contract offering 7 percent pay raises over the next three years. ``We obviously didn't get all that we wanted, but it's enough to recommend a settlement,'' Nat LaCour, head of United Teachers of New Orleans, said shortly before Sunday night's voice vote to approve the pact. Teachers were to return to their classrooms today. According to New Orleans School Board President Carl Robinson, the new contract includes a 3 percent pay raise for the current school year, no raise next year and a 4 percent raise during the 1992-93 school year. The school board will have to cut $7 million in programs and personnel to finance the new contract, Robinson said. The board also agreed not to punish strikers in exchange for the teachers agreeing to drop a recall movement against board members, LaCour said. Some teachers expressed anger over the recall-reprisal agreement, but LaCour said union members agreed to both it and the new contract in separate votes. ``They blackmailed the union that we cannot recall them,'' complained teacher Betty Sapp. ``We're political hostages for the next three years.'' ``I went on strike because the board wasn't being fair with us,'' said teacher Virginia Pluta. ``Now I don't think the union is being fair with us. I'm very, extremely upset with the union right now.'' About 3,000 of the 4,500 teachers in Louisiana's largest school district went on strike beginning Sept. 17. School officials used substitutes to help keep classes in session for the district's 68,000 students.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Rockies; Rain Across Nation's Mid-Section
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell across much of the nation's mid-section early today, and snow blanketed the eastern Rockies and western slopes of the Plains. The West Coast, much of the Eastern seaboard and Gulf states had clear skies early today. Rain and showers fell in a wide swath from the central Plains, across the Midwest and into the upper Appalachians. The rain was following a cold front that stretched from the Texas panhandle, along the Ohio River and across Pennslyvania into New England. A flash flood watch was in effect today for all of Arkansas, a day after heavy rains pelted the state. During a three-hour eeriod Sunday more than 5 inches fell at Smithville, Okla., and 4{ inches fell during the same time at Dequeen, Ark. More than 4 inches of rain fell at Deer, Ark., in a six-hour period. Snow fell today in the four-state area of Colorado, Wyoming, South Dakota and Nebraska. Today's forecast called for up to 5 inches of snow in northeastern Colorado, and up to 9 inches in the mountains, the National Weather Service said. The high for the nation on Sunday was 99 degrees at Laredo, Texas.
