DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower, Pound Soars
DOC.TEXT: The dollar nose-dived against the Japanese yen and the soaring British pound today in early European trading, but it rose against most other foreign currencies. Gold prices fell. The pound rocketed as it trading for the first time since being linked to Europe's other currencies after its weekend entry into the Exchange Rate Mechanism. Shares prices in London also soared at the opening before falling back but still well up from Friday. In London, the pound was quoted at $1.9795, nearly 3.5 cents higher than $1.9455 late Friday. The pound was quoted at $1.9115 at Thursday's close, so the currency has jumped more than 7 cents since the Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major's surprise announcement late Friday afternoon. The Exchange Rate Mechanism of the European Currency System links European currencies to one another to avoid huge swings in exchange rates. With British membership, 10 of the currencies of the 12-nation European community are linked in the system. Under the rules of ERM membership, the British government is obliged to halt any rise in the pound outside its upper band of 3.13 German marks to the pound. Sterling is allowed to range within 6 percent of its central rate of 2.96, so its lowest exchange rate is 2.77 marks. If the currency goes too high, Britain must lower its exchange rate either by selling sterling or reducing interest rates. Some traders said they expected central bank intervention before the end of the week. ``Sterling is not a totally free lunch,'' said Geoffrey Dennis, international economist at James Capel & Co. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 3.67 yen to a 1{-year low against the Japanese yen, closing at 130.05 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 130.80 yen. Dealers said they expected the dollar to remain sidelined today, with the Columbus Day national holiday in the United States and because of the continuing budget negotiations. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: -1.5370 German marks, up from 1.5372 -1.2865 Swiss francs, up from 1.2847 -5.1477 French francs, up from 5.1473 -1.7365 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7340 -1,151.50 Italian lire, up from 1,150.50 -1.1510 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1500 Gold prices were recovering after being pushed sharply lower in Asian trading, dealers said. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $391.25 per ounce at midmorning, down from $394.35 bid per ounce late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $391.00, down from $394.40 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped $3.26 per ounce to close at $388.69. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.66 a troy ounce, from Friday's $4.69.

DOC.HEAD: Most Americans Know Little About Hepatitis B, Survey Shows
DOC.TEXT: Hepatitis B, an inflammation of the liver, kills about 14 Americans every day, but a Gallup survey to be released today indicates most people know almost nothing about the disease. ``The survey shows that 69 percent of all U.S. adults, from 18-55, do not know that a vaccine exists to prevent people from becoming infected with hepatitis B,'' said Dr. David L. Hoff, medical director of the Akron, Ohio, City Health System. Eighty-three percent of those surveyed also acknowledged they knew little or nothing about the disease, Hoff said. The results were to be discussed by Hoff during the annual meeting of the American Academy of Family Physicians today. Some 1,000 people were surveyed nationwide by telephone Sept. 10-17 as part of a patient and physician education program for SmithKline Beecham. Hoff said of the adults questioned, nearly two-thirds were married, 40 percent were high school graduates or had taken technical courses and 40 percent had taken college courses or had college degrees. ``The real cause of concern of the data from this survey is the lack of awareness of the seriousness of the disease and the availability of a preventive vaccine,'' Hoff said. ``This is particularly worrisome when you think of those in our society who are presumably less in touch with such issues and could be at high risk for contracting the disease. Officials say that about 300,000 persons are afflicted annually by the disease in the United States and about 5,000 people, including 300 health care workers, die of the disease or its complications. The virus, spread by blood or other body fluids, is many times more contagious than Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV), the cause of AIDS, officials say. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control says that persons with multiple sexual partners and people who use injectable illicit drugs are at risk of contracting the virus and should get the vaccine.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Citation, Summary for Nobel Prize in Medicine
With PM-Nobel-Medicine
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of today's citation by the Nobel Assembly for the Nobel Prize in medicine and the summary of the winners' achievements as released in an English language statement:
DOC.HEAD: CITATION
DOC.TEXT: The Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institute has today decided to award the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 1990 jointly to Joseph E. Murray and E. Donnall Thomas for their discoveries concerning ``Organ and Cell Transplantation in the Treatment of Human Disease.''
DOC.HEAD: SUMMARY
DOC.TEXT: This year's Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is given for discoveries that have enabled the development of organ and cell transplantation into a method for the treatment of human disease. Joseph E. Murray discovered how rejection following organ transplantation in man could be mastered, E. Donnall Thomas managed to diminish the severe reaction that the graft can cause in the recipient, i.e. the so-called ``graft-versus-host'' reaction (GVH). In addition, Thomas could show that intravenously infused bone marrow cells were able to repopulate the bone marrow and produce new blood cells. Murray successfully transplanted a kidney between homozygous twins for the first time. He pioneered transplantation of kidneys obtained from deceased persons and could show that patients with terminal renal insufficiency could be cured. The field was then open for transplantation of other organs such as liver, pancreas and heart. Thomas was successful in transplanting bone marrow cells from one individual to another. Bone marrow transplantation can cure severe inherited disorders such as thalassemia and disorders of the immune system as well as leukemia and aplastic anemia. Murray's and Thomas' discoveries are crucial for those tens of thousands of severely ill patients who either can be cured or given a decent life when other treatment methods are without success.

DOC.HEAD: Klaus Weakens to Depression, Moves Over Open Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: A tropical depression was all that remained this morning of Klaus, the 11th named storm and the sixth hurricane of the Atlantic hurricane season, forecasters said. But Klaus, which briefly reached hurricane status Friday, left at least six dead and 1,500 homeless in the northeastern Caribbean before being downgraded Saturday to a tropical storm. The system late Sunday dropped again, this time to tropical depression strength, with top winds this morning reaching only 35 mph. At 6 a.m. EDT, the depression was centered near 20.6 north and 68.8 west, or about 145 miles northeast of Puerto Plata in the Dominican Republic, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. The depression was moving west-northwest at near 15 mph and was expected to maintain that heading and forward speed for the next 24 hours, said officials at the hurricane center. Little change in strength was expected today.

DOC.HEAD: Some Hard Hitting, But No Knockouts in Wilson-Feinstein Debate
DOC.TEXT: Dianne Feinstein and Pete Wilson traded sharp jabs and barbed one-liners over abortion, campaign fund-raising and leadership qualities in the first of two scheduled debates in the California governor's race. Feinstein attacked Wilson's absenteeism from the U.S. Senate, and he criticized her record on taxes. Sunday's televised debate produced no knockouts but drew political blood from both candidates. Although both are seasoned politicians, each postured as the political outsider while criticizing the other as the establishment candidate. Feinstein, the Democratic former mayor of San Francisco, has 20 years in public office; Wilson, California's Republican U.S. senator, has held various elective offices for 24 years. Feinstein repeatedly keyed on Wilson's political ties to the policies of retiring Republican Gov. George Deukmejian, describing Wilson as ``the candidate for the status quo.'' Wilson endorsed Proposition 140, which limits the number of terms in political office and is bitterly opposed by most state legislators. He also stressed Feinstein's political alliance with Assembly Speaker Willie Brown and Senate President pro tem David Roberti. ``I am not beholden,'' said Wilson. ``I do not owe Willie. I do not owe David.'' Feinstein sharply responded: ``Well, senator, if you really feel you can't handle Willie Brown or David Roberti, then stay in Washington. I'll handle them.'' Each candidate tried to out-do the other in appealing to voters who are pro-choice on abortion. ``I've been pro-choice longer than Dianne Feinstein,'' Wilson said. Feinstein fired back with a recitation of alleged contradictions between Wilson's pro-choice statements and Senate votes against abortion funds. ``Pete Wilson isn't pro-choice,'' she said. ``I think he's multiple choice.'' Wilson also mocked the ``tough and caring'' slogan of Feinstein's television commercials, saying that as mayor she supported a utility tax that fell hardest on the elderly and poor. ``I don't think that was very caring. Tough, but not caring,'' Wilson said. He also criticized Feinstein for taking large campaign donations in the wake of a judge's overturning of Proposition 73, which had limited individual donations to $1,000. Feinstein accused Wilson of having ``the worst attendance record in the Congress,'' missing votes on the death penalty, Supreme Court confirmation, Middle East resolutions and the budget. Some observers gave Feinstein a slight edge in delivery and Wilson a slight edge in content, but nearly all agreed that both candidates probably did a better job of pleasing voters already committed to them than winning new supporters. A second debate is scheduled next week in San Francisco. Recent polls have found the race to be a toss-up.

DOC.HEAD: Musk Ox at Tacoma Zoo Could Get Artificial Leg
DOC.TEXT: Pengun the musk ox has already learned to maneuver a ceiling sling at Point Defiance Zoo since her left foreleg was amputated in September. A veterinarian now hopes infections heal enough to allow her to become perhaps the first musk ox in the world to receive an artificial leg. But fitting a 300-pound animal with a prosthesis can be tricky. ``This is a unique, special animal at a unique, special zoo,'' said veterinarian Rick Williams. ``This probably won't happen again for 100 years.'' The 10-year-old musk ox fell one night in August and hurt her left leg, zoo authorities said. After the leg became infected, veterinarians were forced to amputate. Williams is waiting for the infection to heal before he tries fitting Pengun with an artificial leg. Pengun, which means ``little hill'' in Aleut, was brought to the Tacoma zoo with five other musk oxen from Nunivak Island, Alaska, in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Whale Pod Numbers in Prince William Sound Drop
DOC.TEXT: A pod of killer whales in Prince William Sound is declining in number, according to researchers studying whether the whales were affected by the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill. The study, sponsored by the National Marine Fisheries Service, is finding that the number of whales in the AB pod, a family group that lives much of the year in the western part of the sound, has dropped from 35 animals to as few as 22 during the past two summers. ``Nothing like this has been documented before,'' said Craig Matkin, a marine zoologist conducting the Prince William Sound study. ``They're all missing out of one pod,'' he said. ``It's a pod that's been very stable. ... The mortality rate for mature females, especially, (has been) just almost nil.'' Yet researchers in the sound last summer could not find seven whales, including several females, and another five or six whales appeared to be missing when scientists returned to the sound this summer, Matkin said. Killer whales in ``resident'' pods, like the AB pod, travel in female-dominated packs, Matkin said. Several of the AB pod mothers and offspring are apparently missing, and some young whales have been seen accompanying older females other than their mothers. ``The whole social structure seems to be breaking down as we lose more females,'' Matkin said. ``We're worried about the future of the pod,'' he said. As many as a dozen other killer whale pods along the Gulf of Alaska also are being studied, but apparently have not experienced unusual population drops, he said. Speculation about the causes of the population changes in the AB pod are being kept confidential, as are most publicly funded scientific data from spill-related studies. Lawyers for the federal and state governments have said releasing information now could hurt them years from now in court when they try to recover money from Exxon for the damage caused by the spill.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Responds Cautiously to Reports of Soviet Concession
DOC.TEXT: Japanese officials responded cautiously today to reports that the Soviet Union may be willing to return some of the disputed islands that have been the main barrier to better ties between the two nations. Japanese newspapers said on Sunday that Soviet officials offered the compromise over the southern Kuril islands to a group of Japanese lawmakers who visited Moscow late last month. ``The proposal shows a desire to improve Japan-Soviet relations,'' Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama said in a statement. But he added that Japan has demanded the return of all the islands, which were seized by the Soviets at the end of World War II. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, talking to reporters on his trip to Saudi Arabia, said he would carefully consider the proposal if it were delivered through formal channels. However, the Soviet news agency Tass said the Soviet Foreign Ministry had not made any new proposals to Japan concerning the islands. Tass quoted a senior Soviet diplomat as saying reports that the Soviet Union had expressed readiness to transfer a portion of the island chain to Japan did not reflect the facts. He said the Soviet Foreign Ministry was preparing a refutation of the reports. Both sides recently have seemed eager to resolve the 45-year-old dispute. For the Soviet Union, improved ties could mean a much-needed infusion of capital from Japan's financial reserves. For Japan, an agreement could open the way to joint development of the Soviet Union's plentiful natural resources, particularly Siberian oil. The disputed territory consists of three islands and a cluster of islets off northern Japan totaling only 2,000 square miles. The Soviets claim them as historically Russian territory, while Tokyo insists they were ceded to Japan in 19th-century agreements. Japan's Kyodo News Service quoted governing party officials as saying that Soviet officials had proposed a new bilateral agreement that would confirm a 1956 Japan-Soviet Joint Declaration. In that declaration, Moscow agreed to return one island and a group of smaller islands. But when Japan signed a mutual security treaty with the United States in 1960, the Soviet Union declared it would return the islands only after all foreign troops were withdrawn from Japan. Kyodo said the Soviet compromise proposal also called for a peace treaty within three to five years after the two countries sign the agreement. Because of the dispute, the nations have never officially ended their war hostilities.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Hopeful Captive Dolphins Will Adapt to Wild
DOC.TEXT: After two years in captivity, Echo and Misha spent a second day in freedom today - with scientists looking over their shoulders to see how captive dolphins adapt in the wild. The two dolphins will be under scrutiny of the Mote Marine Laboratory for the next year. The scientists watched anxiously Saturday when the duo's flight to freedom got off to a somewhat rocky start. Seconds after being lowered into the water, Echo and Misha sped away - and promptly beached themselves on a sandbar. Researchers swam to the animals and gave them a second shove to liberty. ``It will take them a while to get their bearings,'' said conservation biologist Randy Wells. ``When they start swimming along the coast and socializing with other dolphins - then we'll call it a success.'' Within an hour, the two were spotted swimming with a pod of about three dolphins. Wells, affiliated with the Chicago Zoological Society, took the dolphins from the same harbor off Ruskin in the summer of 1988 for a project at the University of California-Santa Cruz to study the sophisticated system of sounds dolphins use to gather information about their watery environment. Last month, the two 300-pound dolphins were transported to Mote on Central Florida's Gulf Coast to prepare for their return home. While other captive dolphins have been released in the wild, Wells said this is the first project involving electronic monitoring and tracking to find out how captive dolphins readjust and socialize. Successful reintroduction into Tampa Bay could open up new vistas. It could mean that in the future, dolphins might only need to be taken from the wild long enough to breed with captive dolphins to replenish the gene pool. Already, a Perth, Australia, oceanarium that closed down has inquired about the project amid plans to free its nine dolphins. ``Controversy about dolphins in captivity seems to grow every day,'' Ms. Dieffenwierth said. ``If we find they can be reassimilated, putting them back in the wild may be a solution.''

DOC.HEAD: Garry Trudeau: I Told Jane to Walk
DOC.TEXT: Doonesbury creator Garry Trudeau says he urged wife Jane Pauley to ``walk away from NBC altogether'' when she was edged off the ``Today'' show in favor of Deborah Norville. Trudeau wanted to satirize the morning program in his irreverent comic strip because ``it had a formal, Kabuki-like quality ... that would have been a natural for me,'' he said in a rare interview in the Oct. 15 issue of Newsweek magazine. But Pauley's broadcast career appears, in retrospect, to have benefited from her move. And Trudeau says writing about his own family in his comic strip would be ``a violation (as well as) infinitely banal.'' Pauley has wrestled with the same conflict between public and private lives. She told People magazine last week that she'd love to interview her husband, ``but a) he would never do it, and b) I would not ultimately do it. But I know it's a neat story.'' Trudeau said he decided to talk with Newsweek to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the strip's syndication. He wisely chose a magazine - Pauley had told People she'd ``be really irritated'' if he did an interview with a rival television network.

DOC.HEAD: First Israelis Receive Gas Masks Courtesy of Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to CORRECT `Plane' to `Plain' and `Judgement' to `Judgment.' Pickup 3rd pvs, `Officials tried...'
DOC.TEXT: In this town overlooking the Plain of Armageddon, Israeli civilians have begun picking up the gas masks their government is distributing to counter a feared Iraqi chemical attack. Government officials launched the program Sunday in Yoqneam, where the Bible says the battle of Judgment Day will be waged, and in two other small towns. They say they will provide the free masks to all 4.7 million Israelis, which is expected to take several weeks. Officials tried to promote calm as residents trickled into instruction centers in school classrooms, where soldiers showed how to use gas masks and poison antidotes. The classrooms were festooned with the handiwork of pupils, and children received colored gas masks to help ease their fears. ``It's colorful and pretty so the child should not get afraid,'' said a female instructor, holding up a red-and-yellow gas mask for infants. ``It's troubling,'' said Aliza Artzi, after putting her 2-year-old daughter through a plastic anti-gas tent for infants. Her daughter, Tali, seemed unphased. Ms. Artzi said she hoped the kit would never be needed, but believed otherwise. Asked whether she believes war is likely, she said, ``I think so.'' Officials said that within days, they will have handed out masks to the 30,000 people of Ofakim, Kfar Yona and Yoqneam. Israelis have already paid for their gas masks through their obligatory national insurance premiums. The army says most Palestinians in the occupied territories will not be given the protection kits since they do not pay national insurance. However, they will however be able to purchase the kits bought by the army in Europe at cut-rate prices of about $20 each. The government announced the program a week ago during an escalation of tensions in the 2-month-old Persian Gulf crisis. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has threatened to draw Israel into a war if his country is attacked, and he has threatened to use chemical weapons. Yoqneam, a hilltop town of 7,000 about 40 miles north of Tel Aviv, has problems that extend far beyond fears of chemical attack. Indeed, it is a microcosm of Israel's setbacks, as well as its successes. An immigrant town, it was a showcase of the Jewish melting pot, a thriving community of Moroccans, Russians, Kurds, Romanians, Iraqis, Bulgarians and native-born Sabras. But this summer, its biggest employer, the Soltam munitions plant, went under and the work force has fallen from 4,500 to 150. Sacked workers who occupied the building were ousted by guards with attack dogs, leaving Yoqneam deeply embittered. Now, with unemployment at 15 percent, Russian immigrants are pouring in - 400 so far this year. Some of them were shopping in the supermarket on Sunday before heading up the hill to the Oranim school to pick up gas masks. ``They don't really understand what it's all about,'' said Eva Maman, a saleswoman. ``They have other problems.'' At the school sat a cross-section of Israel: an elderly man in a skullcup, a young woman in a designer T-shirt and sunglasses, a middle-age couple perspiring from the exhausting uphill hike to the school, and the Artzi family, their little girl sucking furiously at her pacifier as the instructor described symptoms of gas poisoning - trembling, bodily secretions, inflamed eyes. ``This is the injection. Orange up, green down,'' barked the tough-looking instructor in olive-green uniform. ``How do you remember? Easy. Orange - the sun - up; green - the grass - down.'' The army instructors also handed out leaflets in Hebrew, Arabic, Russian and English. Hebrew and Russian placards decorated the walls. There was no hint of panic. The schools were empty for the Jewish festival of Sukkot so no classes were disrupted. Yoqneam snoozed away the hot afternoon hours. Men played backgammon in a coffee shop. A car driven by Hassidic Jews passed by with music blaring from loudspeakers, towing a mobile sukkah, the traditional hut in which the observant spend the eight-day holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Gainesville Slayings Suspect Faces Assault Count
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began today in the assault trial of a man who is also a suspect in last month's slayings of five college students in Gainesville. Edward Lewis Humphrey, who has been under intense scrutiny by investigators and the media since his arrest by Brevard County authorities, is accused of beating his 79-year-old grandmother - a charge both he and the grandmother deny. Retired Judge Theron A. Yawn, visiting from Alachua County to preside over the misdemeanor case, summoned 20 prospective jurors for initial questioning. The trial needs six jurors. Attorneys for Humphrey say they expect it will take a long time to select a jury because of the publicity surrounding the unrelated slayings. The 18-year-old University of Florida freshman was arrested on the assault charge Aug. 29. Shortly afterward, investigators publicly named him as a suspect in the deaths of the five students, whose bodies were discovered the three preceding days. Humphrey has remained jailed on $1 million bond. If convicted, he could be sentenced to up to 5{ years in prison. Humphrey is charged in connection with an incident the night of Aug. 29, when he left Gainesville and returned to his Indiatlantic home. Police were called, and his grandmother, Elna Hlavaty told them Humphrey had hit her. She has since refused to press charges, and has denied that her grandson hit her.

DOC.HEAD: Seattle Bone-Marrow Researcher Says Nobel Prize Unexpected
With PM-Nobel-Medicine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The prize ...' to CORRECT Nobel died in 1896, sted 1901.
DOC.TEXT: Dr. E. Donnall Thomas, who blazed a new path for the treatment of leukemia when he performed the first human bone marrow transplant in 1956, said today he always considered the Nobel Prize ``a long shot at best.'' Thomas, 70, of Bellevue, Wash., and Joseph E. Murray, 71, were awarded the Nobel Prize in medicine today, officials in Stockhom, Sweden announced. Murray, affiliated with Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, was recognized for his discovery of a method to prevent tissue rejection when organs are transplanted in people. Thomas, with the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, said he learned of the good news when awakened by a reporter's telephone call early this morning. ``I really thought this work was too clinical to ever win the prize,'' Thomas said. ``There are many scientist-researchers out there who are eligible for this prize. ``It's a long shot at best, and it would be a mistake to waste time thinking about winning it.'' The prize shared by Murray and Thomas, worth $695,000, is endowed by the will of dynamite inventor Alfred Nobel, who died in 1896. Thomas said he hasn't had time yet to think of what he will do with the money. Thomas, who took after his father and fulfilled his childhood desire to become a doctor, performed the first human bone marrow transplant in Cooperstown, N.Y., in 1956. The surgical procedure has become standard treatment for many sufferers of leukemia and lymphoma, which are types of cancer. Thomas joined the University of Washington faculty in 1963 and went to the Hutchinson center when it opened in 1975. The center is now one of the world'sleading cancer treatment and research institutions. ``I think it's a recognition of a lot of work by a lot of people who have worked on the problems over the years. I have a medical team here of some 50 physicians and Ph.D.s who now work with me on this. It's been very gratifying to see the procedure become accepted as the primary form of treatment for leukemia,'' Thomas said. In a bone marrow transplant, the patient's diseased marrow is destroyed by chemotherapy and radiation. Disease-free marrow is removed by needle from the hip bone of a donor, often a relative, and dripped intravenously into the patient. In time, the transplanted cells begin to grow in the patient's marrow and produce new white and red blood cells and platelets.

DOC.HEAD: Nobel Prize Winner Led Pioneering Kidney Transplant Team
With PM-Nobel-Medicine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with reax, picking up 4th graf, `Richard lived ...; SUBS last 2 grafs with 2 grafs to include background, DELETE reference to Thomas, now redundant.
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Joseph E. Murray, who won the Nobel Prize in medicine today, was chief surgeon of a team whose pioneering transplant operation 35 years ago began the now-routine business of shifting organs from person to person. That operation, the first success after 15 failures, at last showed that transplants were possible. But several more years passed before doctors found ways to reliably outsmart the body's natural defenses against alien organs. The Nobel Assembly of the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm gave the prestigious medical prize jointly to Murray, 71, and Dr. E. Donnall Thomas, 70, whose work helped diminish the severe reaction that bone marrow grafts can cause in recipients. Although the two physicians did not collaborate on their prize-winning work, Murray recalled today that they began their careers together at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston, where Murray still practices. ``He was a resident in medicine and I was a resident in surgery,'' Murray recalled. ``This was after World War II. We both started working in transplants together, but from different angles. It's marvelous to share it with him.'' Murray spoke by telephone from his daughter's house in the San Francisco suburb of Lafayette. He was in the Bay area for an American College of Surgeons conference. ``I was sound asleep and my daughter came in and woke me up and said, `Daddy, I have good news for you,''' Murray said. ``I couldn't believe it, obviously.'' He gave credit to his chief of surgery, Dr. Francis D. Moore, and said he had been thinking about all of his colleagues, although he had not spoken to them yet. ``I just talked to my family. That of course is most important,'' he said. ``We have six children and they called from all over the country.'' Murray's groundbreaking operation was performed Dec. 23, 1954 at Brigham Hospital. Doctors removed a healthy kidney from 23-year-old Ronald Herrick and gave it to his identical brother, Richard. Richard lived for seven more years. He died of heart disease that was a complication of his underlying kidney disorder. The Herrick brothers were genetically identical. Their operation did not answer the problem of shifting organs between people whose tissues are not exactly the same. The Brigham team showed that such operations might be possible in 1959, when they transplanted kidneys between brothers who were fraternal, not identical, twins. The doctors gave the recipient cortisone and low weekly doses of radiation in an effort to suppress his immune defenses. But they did not believe the treatment was powerful enough to stop rejection and were unsure why the operation succeeded. In 1962, Murray performed the first successful kidney transplant from an unrelated donor. The key to this operation was the drug azathioprine, which suppresses the body's immune system and keeps it from fighting off the new organ. Dr. George Hitchings, a co-developer of the drug, won the Nobel Prize in medicine two years ago. Americans have now won or shared the prize in medicine 32 times in the past 21 years, compared with 19 winners from all other countries combined. The prize shared by Murray and Thomas, worth $695,000, is endowed by the will of dynamite inventor Alfred Nobel, who died in 1896.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting to CORRECT writethru sequence.
Magazine Report: Dinkins Gets $11,500 Headboard
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with new Dinkins remarks; pick up 5th graf, `The headboard ...
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins said today that whatever his new bed's headboard cost - and it reportedly cost $11,500 - the city will not pay a penny of it. The mayor said he has instructed city officials to find out by Tuesday whether it really took $11,500 for a city carpenter to duplicate a headboard that would have cost $1,600 in a store. ``Whatever the explanation, the city will not pay a single penny of the cost,'' Dinkins said in a statement issued by his press secretary, Albert Scardino. ``It will all be covered by private donations from friends of the city, many of whom have contacted me this morning to offer their contributions.'' Dinkins was stung by a Newsweek magazine story about the headboard, which came days after the city's money woes prompted the mayor to freeze hiring, propose new taxes and raise the possibility of laying off 15,000 city employees. Dinkins said the headboard was delivered to Gracie Mansion, the mayor's official residence, on Friday. It was built to match other pieces of a bedroom set that Dinkins said he paid for himself. ``I wish somebody would ask me why don't I seek reimbursement for the $8,000 or $9,000 I spent on the bedroom suite. No questions have come to me in that regard. I contributed that,'' he said Sunday at the Pulaski Day parae. Dinkins' statement said the city had received contributions of $1,400 toward the cost of the bed. Earlier, Scardino said materials for the headboard cost $1,400 and that it was paid for by the Gracie Mansion Conservancy, a private, nonprofit organization. Labor cost should have added up to an additional ``few hundred dollars at most,'' Scardino said. The headboard was built by Anthony Russo, a carpenter on the staff of the city's Human Resources Administration, Newsweek said. He has submitted bills for 266 hours of labor at a cost to date of $6,484.12, according to a work order obtained by Newsweek. Two HRA sources told Newsweek the complete job is expected to total 500 hours - at a cost of $23 an hour, or $11,500. The Dinkinses chose a cherrywood set and bought nightstands and bureaus from a private company with their own money for $8,000, officials said. The matching headboard had been discontinued by the company so the conservancy agreed to buy the materials to build one. Scardino speculated the bill that Newsweek obtained might actually have been for a series of jobs. ``It's possible this bill represents many jobs, that's the only way to explain it, because there's no possible way the labor cost of the headboard could be more than the rest of the furniture bought for the room,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Commerce Department Issued Questionable Export Licenses
DOC.TEXT: For the past several years, the U.S. Commerce Department approved export licenses for American companies to ship technology to Iraq that could be used against U.S. troops, a newspaper reported. The Commerce Department was largely unhindered in its drive to promote trade with South Africa, Libya, Iraq and Iran, The (Cleveland) Plain Dealer reported in articles Sunday and today. Pentagon and other government officials with expertise about weapons and national security interests were routinely kept in the dark about many U.S.-made exports they say now threaten American troops, the newspaper reported. ``If the exports are in the gray area of dual use, chances are we don't even know about it,'' said William N. Rudman, the Pentagon's deputy undersecretary for trade security policy. If the Pentagon has suspicions about a deal, it has no legal authority to stop the shipment; it would be up to the State Department to do so, he said. ``They (Commerce Department) wanted to push as much stuff out the door as they could,'' said Stephen Bryen, a former Pentagon trade security official. The newspaper said that from 1984 until just months before Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait, the Commerce Department approved at least 15 licenses to export tens of millions of dollars in equipment and technology that intelligence specialists believe could be used to help pack Iraq's arsenals. Among the licenses were ones allowing U.S. businesses to sell Iraq mainframe computers useful in designing and plotting the course of missiles, and to sell furnaces that could melt and cast nuclear materials. The newspaper said that in 1987, the Commerce Department agreed to allow a New Jersey company, Electronics Associates Inc., to sell a half-million-dollar analog computer system to Iraq. It was similar to one at the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico. The company's brochure had a photo of a missile on the cover. The Pentagon's office of national trade security protested the sale, but the computer was shipped anyway, the newspaper said. At least twice, executives at another New Jersey company, Consarc Corp., themselves raised the possibility that Iraq intended to buy the company's furnaces and computers for nuclear purposes instead of for their stated purposes of making knee joints and artificial hips. In July, just as the furnace was about to be loaded onto a ship in Philadelphia, President Bush blocked the shipment. Paul Freedenberg, former head of export controls for the Commerce Department, defended the department's decisions, saying that too-zealous blocking of exports would erode the United States' competitive edge and that Iran, South Africa or others would get the product from another country such as Germany. ``I don't have any regrets,'' said Freedenberg. ``I don't remember any particular export I have second thoughts about.'' Still, he conceded that ``if it turns out Iraq's an enemy, obviously (the Pentagon will) have been proven right'' in its objections. But at the time, there was no legal justification to deny the export licenses, Freedenberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Central Committee Holds First Meeting Since July Party Congress
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party Central Committee today opened its first meeting since July's party congress, with the nation's worsening economy a major topic, Tass reported. The committee's meeting comes as the party is losing its authority and membership. Earlier this year, the party surrendered its constitutional monopoly on power. Prominent members such as Russian Federation Boris N. Yeltsin and the mayors of Moscow and Leningrad have quit, the republics are exercising more independence from the Kremlin, and the Soviet president and party leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, is transferring much of his power to the government. Tass said that participants in today's meeting included the more than 400 members of the Central Committee; the party's Central Control Commission; party leaders from the 15 Soviet republics; territorial, regional and district party officials; academics and national legislators. In July, the 28th party congress expanded the Central Committee from 249 to 412 members, most of them centrists like Gorbachev. Today's session was likely to provide clues as to what role the Central Committee will play in the changing Soviet Union. Tass also said the move to a market economy was expected to dominate today's meeting. The Communist Party newspaper Pravda carried an article by Ruben Safarov, a participant in July's congress, who suggested that the party may have to leave the political arena if it keeps its old methods of operation. The party also has been openly criticized by radical groups seeking their share of power. On Sunday, in the western Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, hundreds of people gathered and shouted anti-Communist slogans, such as ``God, rid us of the Communist Party!'' according to local activist Anatoly Popov. The Supreme Soviet legislature has set up a committee to combine several programs on rescuing the Soviet economy and report back by Oct. 15. The most radical reform proposal, written by economist Stanislav Shatalin, calls for junking the central planning system and moving to a market economy within 500 days by selling factories to private owners and breaking up collective farms. The most conservative proposal, backed by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, would leave the government in control of most of the economy while moving gradually to allow free enterprise. Gorbachev has backed a compromise that contains many elements of the 500-day plan but would not move as fast. He also wants a national referendum to decide whether to return land to private farmers. On Sunday, Grbachev met with leading economists to discuss the economic plans under consideration, Tass reported. Gorbachev opened today's plenum with a speech, and his deputy, Vladimir Ivashko, also gave a report, Tass said. It did not provide details. The Communist Party has lost more than 765,000 members this year, leaving it with about 18 million members, party personnel chief Boris Pugo has reported. Some 375,000 members have followed Yeltsin and other reformers in quitting the party, another 125,000 members were expelled, 120,000 died and 150,000 stopped paying their membership dues or participating in party activities.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed When Plane Hits Highway
DOC.TEXT: A single-engine airplane came down on a highway, skidded into a ditch and burst into flames, killing four people, officials said. The Beechcraft Bonanza struck the ground Sunday night on the south side of U.S. 224, about four miles east of Ottawa in northwest Ohio, said Putnam County Sheriff Ron Diemer. The plane skidded across the highway, narrowly missing two trucks, and came to a stop in the ditch and caught fire, officials said. Diemer said the drivers of the two trucks contacted police. ``They were about 100 feet from the where the plane crashed,'' he said. Authorities speculated the craft may have been making an approach to the Putnam County airport. They said rainy, foggy weather may have played a role in the crash. The plane was registered in the name of Nelson Manufacturing Co. of Ottawa, said company spokesman, George Rellinger. The cause of the crash wasn't determined immediately. Investigators for the National Transportation Safety Board were called to the scene.

DOC.HEAD: Austrian Vote: Socialists Hold Own, But Nationalists Gain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Cabinet to dissolve according to tradition, Vranitzky meets Waldheim. Pickup 12th pvs, `The Socialists...'
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Franz Vranitzky remained in a position today to rebuild his broad coalition government, but a charismatic populist campaigning on a nationalist platform scored big gains in national elections. Vranitzky defied predictions of large losses for his Socialist Party in Sunday's vote. But his conservative partner, the People's Party, suffered the worst electoral setback of its 45-year history. Joerg Haider's populist Freedom Party nearly doubled its parliamentary representation on the strength of his appeals to nationalist sentiments, warnings of rising crime, and complaints over Austria's relatively liberal immigration policies for Eastern Europeans. The Socialists consider Haider's party too far to the right to be considered a governing partner, and the 53-year-old Vranitzky offered to join with the People's Party in another governing coalition. Voters seemed to prefer personalities to parties, reflecting widespread dissatisfaction with bureaucracy, corruption and party privileges. ``It was a vote for the chancellor,'' said the Socialist Party chief secretary, Josef Cap, in assessing the result. Vranitzky led a campaign largely focused on his continuing role as head of government. His popularity appeared responsible for his success, despite a series of scandals involving Socialist officials tampering with public funds. According to final results, the Socialists won 43 percent of the popular vote and 81 seats in the 183-seat parliament, one more than in the last elections in 1986. The People's Party, led by Vice Chancellor Josef Riegler, suffered losses in each of the country's nine provinces, dropping to 60 seats from 77. Haider's Freedom Party nearly doubled its seats from 18 to 33, winning almost 17 percent of the popular vote. The environmental Green Alternative Party won an additional seat for a total of nine. Vranitzky's government was to submit its resignation Tuesday after the regular Cabinet session. According to longstanding tradition, President Kurt Waldheim will ask Vranitzky, as leader of the strongest party, to form a new government. The chancellor met with Waldheim today, as did Peoples' Party leader Josef Riegler to discuss the outcome of the elections. The Socialists' showing amounted to a victory for their party after ollsters predicted heavy losses for both governing parties. But the relatively low turnout of 83 percent of the 5,628,912 registered voters suggested that many Austrians are unhappy with the status quo. Turnout in 1986 was 90 percent. Haider, 40, appealed to voters seeking change after 45 years of governing by either the Socialists or the People's Party. He lashed into government bureaucracy, special advantages for party members, corruption, and sometimes other political leaders. Green leader Johannes Voggenhuber attributed some of the Socialists' success to Vranitzky's clear ``no'' to governing with Haider and to his conservative partner's failure to clearly rule out that possibility. He said the Peoples' Party had thus ``committed political suicide on an open stage.'' Haider said his party intended to remain in the political opposition, saying it would be ``good for Austria'' to have a medium-sized party opposing the government. He attributed his party's strong gains in this country of 7.6 million people to its role as a ``successful opposition'' in the past legislative period. Helmut Kukacka, the People's Party general secretary, called it a ``heavy, depressing defeat.'' He acknowledged, ``We are certainly the big losers.'' The conservatives still bear the burden of their support four years ago for Waldheim, who is accused of concealing his World War II past. Waldheim was not considered a major issue in this campaign, however.

DOC.HEAD: Art Forgery Disclosed in Artist's Will
DOC.TEXT: An Italian artist has claimed in his will that he was the author of a painting previously attributed to Leonardo da Vinci and estimated to be worth millions of dollars. The claim was made by Cesare Tubino, who died in this northern city last week at the age of 91, the Turin daily Stampa Sera reported Monday. ``If the painting is ever sold, it must carry my name,'' Tubino's will read, according to Stampa Sera. A relative of Tubino, Elio Pretolani, confirmed the newspaper story. The ``Madonna with Cat'' first surfaced in the 1930s and was shown at a prestigious Milan exhibition in 1939 after several experts attributed it to the 15th century master. But it disappeared soon after, and was believed to have been stolen or lost. It was found in Tubino's apartment after his death. Stampa Sera wrote that Tubino used the style and the original colors of Leonardo and succeeded in creating the conditions of aging to trick the experts.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Shoot Guard, Steal More Than 90 Sacks of Mail
DOC.TEXT: Robbers handcuffed and chained a security guard, shot him in the neck and stole more than 90 sacks of mail from a post office, police said Monday. A co-worker found the guard Sunday and took him to a hospital, where doctors removed the bullet and said his life was not in danger. Police said at least three robbers participated in the break-in, which occurred Saturday night but was not discovered until 12 hours later. The guard, Vladimir Korade, 44, was found with his feet in chains and his wrists bound by his own handcuffs. No details were disclosed about the contents or value of the stolen sacks. The incident came a week after a robbery at a postal center in the Mediterranean port city of Toulon, about 110 miles east of Nimes. In July, robbers stopped a train near Nimes and made off with large quantities of mail from two freight cars. No arrests have been made in either case.

DOC.HEAD: 67 Tamil Refugees Drown While Fleeing Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: A boat carrying Sri Lankan refugees capsized off India's south coast Monday and 67 people were feared drowned, news reports said. Indian authorities confirmed the disaster but said they were awaiting a report on casualties. United News of India reported that 11 survivors swam to shore in the Pudukottai district and reported that their boat carrying 78 people had sunk. A search was on for the missing passengers, it said. On Sunday, another refugee boat capsized, killing 11 people, refugee authorities said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Since July, 119,000 Tamils have fled Sri Lanka, where Tamil rebels are fighting government forces. The rebels are seeking an independent homeland for the minority Tamils, claiming ethnic discrimanation by the Sinhalese-dominated government.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Destruction Threatens Plants, Animals in Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Wanton destruction of forests in Vietnam has put 226 species of flora and fauna in danger of extinction, the official Vietnam News Agency reported. Statistics from the Ministry of Forestry, although incomplete, show that the threatened species include 104 bird and animal species, 100 plant species, and 22 species of amphibians and reptiles, the report said. Most of the species are very rare, including cedar trees and a species of kingwood tree, as well as the rhinoceros, kouprey, leopard, pheasant, and a species of crane, said the report dated Sunday and seen in Bangkok Monday. It said 17.2 million acres of forest have been destroyed in recent decades, and only 28 percent of the country's former natural greenery remains.

DOC.HEAD: Crocodile Attacks Woman Protecting Her Husband
DOC.TEXT: A 13-foot crocodile attacked a family sleeping in a tent, mauling a woman until her son stuck his fingers into its eyes, the son said Monday. ``It was something my father had told me to do if we were ever attacked,'' Peter Pangquee said. Lena Pangquee, 55, was in serious but stable condition in Royal Darwin Hospital. She was attacked by the crocodile as she tried to protect her partly incapacitated husband. Mrs. Pangquee, her 55-year-old husband and their 35-year-old son had accompanied other family members on a camping and fishing trip to an isolated creek about 120 miles south of Darwin in far northern Australia. The younger Pangquee, who had accompanied his father on previous crocodile-hunting expeditions, said the crocodile attacked Saturday night as he, his mother and father and three teen-age family members were asleep in a 13-foot-square mosquito shelter. ``I was sleeping at my mother and father's feet when I heard my mother yell out,'' Pangquee said. ``I jumped up and saw the crocodile rip straight through the mesh. ``It came in from my parents' side, and my mother could see it was going for dad. He's been left weak down one side after having a stroke, and she just threw herself between him and the croc. ``She was was pulling him out of the way when the croc grabbed her around the body. ``It all happened so quick, but I just went for the croc's head. I must have stuck my fingers about an inch into its eyes, and it stopped as if it didn't know what to do. It dropped my mother and went up onto its hind legs before spinning around.'' Mrs. Pangquee suffered deep puncture wounds, broken ribs and other internal injuries. She was driven 30 miles through scrub and over rough roads before a hospital rescue squad could be contacted. A Royal Darwin Hospital spokeswoman said Monday that Mrs. Pangquee remained in intensive care, but appeared to be recovering satisfactrily. Northern Territory Conservation Commission Chief Wildlife ranger Ross Belcher said it was the first report he had of a crocodile entering a tent. Belcher said the area was considered too isolated for the rogue croc to be hunted down.

DOC.HEAD: Behind Japan's Economic Success Still Lies Depressed, Angry Class
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: When a slum in the nation's second-largest city burst into violence last week, a raw sore was exposed in this country proud of its social order and growing affluence. During the nearly weeklong street violence in the Airin district that eased Sunday, the face of a largely hidden underclass finally emerged. It is a group of outcasts who feel abused by the rest of society, particularly the police and gangsters who so closely monitor their lives. ``You can never understand this feeling,'' a 50-year-old laborer lying on a park bench shouted at a visitor during the height of the rioting. ``How do you know what it is like to be treated like the dregs of society? Everyone treats us as if we are less than human, so go away!'' Airin - which means ``love your neighbor'' - is considered Japan's largest slum. More than 90 percent of its 25,000 residents are day laborers. At first glance, the district looks like an ordinary neighborhood. But on closer examination, one quickly discovers Airin is a world apart from the rest of Japan. Drunken men sleep on the dirty streets; the stench of urine and garbage is pervasive. Barracks made of cardboard boxes fill the local park; shabby hotels that charge $7.70 a night do a booming business. Airin's day laborers are among the poorest people in this economic superpower, supplying the manpower for local construction jobs. They are Japan's unfortunates: farmers and businessmen who went bust, minorities facing discrimination, family outcasts and ex-convicts. Reports that a police official was suspected of taking $84,600 in bribes from gangsters who control the labor market touched off the riot. Angered workers, who see themselves as victims of both police and the gangsters, quickly massed in front of the local police station and were soon stoning police. In following days, the crowds set fire to automobiles, looted stores and waged pitched street battles with the 2,500 riot police in violence rarely seen in Japan. Nearly 200 people, mostly police, were injured. More than 50 were arrested. Airin was quiet for a second day Monday. Allegations of police corruption in Osaka are not unusual, but the Airin residents are particularly angered by allegations of police collusion with the gangsters, known as yakuza, who control the daily recruiting of laborers for construction companies. Sen Arimura, who works at the district's Job Placement Center, says part of the money construction company's allot for workers' salary, which is usually no more than minimum wage, eventually winds up in the pockets of recruiters, many of whom belong to the mob. For example, laborers often spend much of their earnings on gambling, a stronghold of the yakuza, and end up with huge debts. Many of the popular cheap bars and pachinko parlors - the Japanese version of pinball halls - in the area are also run by gangsters. Police report that with about 40 offices run by gangsters, Airin is considered a high-crime district. In response, police have set up 24-hour ``crime prevention'' surveillance cameras at 16 locations. The system infuriates Airin residents, who say the close surveillance invades their privacy. ``People in this town are extremely sensitive about their privacy because most of them have hidden pasts that they do not want to be revealed,'' said a coffee shop owner who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Do you know the feeling when you are consistently watched?'' Arimura asked. ``Here, police seem to assume that everyone is a potential criminal. What can be more discouraging?'' Laborers also complain that police do not investigate complaints that gangsters are taking advantage of the workers. ``It's as if we are lower than gangsters,'' one laborer said. ``When I heard about the bribery case, I felt like shouting that it was our money the cop was getting from gangs, and he was helping those gangs exploit us.'' Said another middle-aged worker: ``We are outcasts of society who got kicked out of the ordinary world and ended up here. We are being sandwiched between police and gangsters. But where else can we go now?''

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Soars Past Mission's Halfway Mark, Probe Speeds Across Space
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with crew singing `Happy Birthday' to astronaut's wife, anecdotes. Picks up 8th graf, `The crew then...'
DOC.TEXT: After restoring some of NASA's credibility with a successful launch and deployment of the Ulysses sun probe, Discovery's crew tended to experiments today and beamed down a birthday greeting for one of the astronaut's wives. The men sang ``Happy Birthday'' to Kaye Akers, wife of astronaut Tom Akers. In lieu of a candle, they held up a reflective plastic stick used aboard the shuttle as a light source. ``We don't have a birthday cake on board,'' said Discovery's commander Richard N. Richards. ``NASA doesn't let us start fires except for Tom. He's the only one who's been able to start an authorized fire.'' Richards was referring to Sunday's experiment involving a small, controlled fire aboard the shuttle. Akers conducted the test. Richards joked that Mrs. Akers was celebrating her 25th birthday again. Mrs. Akers, whose real age was not available to NASA, is mother of two children, a 13-year-old son and a 10-year-old daughter. Mission Control's Kathy Thornton told the crew following their rendition of ``Happy Birthday'' that ``I don't think the New Kids in Space are going to replace the New Kids on the Block as the teen hearthrobs, but we appreciate it anyway.'' ``We know we weren't competing with anybody, but that's the best we can do,'' Richards replied. Ulysses, meanwhile, raced across the solar system on its five-year roundabout journey to explore the sun's poles. The plutonium-powered craft was traveling at a record-breaking speed of 34,130 mph. Achieving a polar orbit around the sun will let scientists study the sun from a previously unexplored vantage point. Its deployment and Discovery's spectacular blastoff this weekend renewed the space agency's spirits, shaken in recent months by failed launch attempts, nagging hydrogen leaks and the flawed Hubble Space Telescope. The crew of five astronauts were awakened early today with the U.S. Coast Guard hymn, radioed to them from Mission Control. The wake-up call came at about 1:45 a.m. EDT. It was played in honor of this year's 200th anniversary of the Coast Guard and because mission specialist Bruce Melnick is the first Coast Guard officer to fly in space. ``Good morning, Houston,'' Richards said. The crew then went about their early morning duties, which included an hour of exercise. They are scheduled to stay in orbit until a Wednesday morning landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. The Saturday morning blastoff from Cape Canaveral, Fla., was the first shuttle launch in nearly six months. The Columbia and Atlantis shuttles have been grounded since early summer by the hydrogen leaks. At Kennedy Space Center, NASA started preparing for the next shuttle launch. The crippled Columbia was being moved from one launch pad to the other today, so Atlantis can be transported from the hangar to the vacated pad. NASA was embarrassed when workers left a 70-pound beam inside the engine compartment of Atlantis last week. The beam had caused minor damage when it banged around as the shuttle was lifted into an upright position. But NASA officials did not expect it to delay Atlantis' early-November liftoff by more than or so when the shuttle is set to embark on a secret military mission. Six hours after Discovery's launch and without a hitch, the five crew members dispatched Ulysses into space. With the mission's primary goal behind them on the first day, astronauts have since turned their attention to various scientific and medical experiments aboard the orbiter. ``It's going real well. We've accomplished the main objective that is to deploy Ulysses, and the other objectives are going smoothly,'' flight director Gary Coen said today. ``We're all happy we've gotten back into the air in this fashion.'' Later this morning, mission specialist Bill Shepherd began another test of an experimental system using voice commands to control television cameras. The astronauts met with little success when they first tested it in space Sunday. NASA television showed pictures of Shepherd working with the experiment, which is designed to give astronauts the opportunity to do more than one thing at a time by freeing them from manually operating the cameras. Prior to launch, Melnick and Shepherd recorded simple commands onto computer chips to control the cameras before blastoff. Melnick had better luck Sunday than Shepherd, who even reprogrammed the system with the sound of his voice in space. Shepherd had problems today and decided to reprogram the system once more. ``It's going a little better than yesterday, but it's still not optimum for controlling the cameras with this kind of recognition,'' he told Mission Control. But the system still failed to recognize about nine of his commands and so Shepherd turned the test over to Melnick, who only had trouble with two words. The system will be tested again Monday. Mission Control suggested that next time, Shepherd speak a litte louder and closer to the microphone used in the experiment. In another shuttle first, the astronauts Sunday started a small fire aboard the orbiter as part of an experiment to study the spread of flames in space. As cameras recorded the experiment, the fire burned about 70 seconds within a sealed aluminum container. Shuttle safety managers wanted to observe how fire acts in the absence of Earth's gravity. The astronauts Sunday also extended Discovery's 50-foot-long robot arm for another experiment. Two patches of material identical to that on solar panels of a communications satellite are attached to the arm. The $157-million satellite has been stranded in a low Earth orbit since March, when it failed to separate properly from an unmanned Titan rocket. Intelsat, an organization of countries that owns the satellite, wants to measure how much the same kind of material on the satellite will decay in space before NASA sends up astronauts in early 1992 to repair the craft. ``Provided the results from this experiment are not wildly different from what we expect, it will be the final piece of data that gives us the confidence to go ahead and rescue the spacecraft,'' said Intelsat scientist Andrew Dunnet.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Attack Prison in El Salvador
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels attacked army troops and prison guards at a penitentiary here, killing one soldier and wounding seven, authorities said today. The Mariona prison holds many political prisoners and guerrillas. The assault with mortars, rocket-propelled grenades and rifle fire began Sunday night at the prison five miles north of the San Salvador and continued until shortly after mdnight. Air force helicopters overflew the battle and dropped flares to illuminate the area but did not fire. The army authorities who reported the government casualties said no dead guerrillas had been found as of mid-morning today. The explosions and gunfire roused many residents of the capital's northern sector. Army troops in light tanks and armored vehicles were out in strength this morning patrolling the capital's northern outskirts.

DOC.HEAD: Uncertainty Marks Moscow-Havana Ties
DOC.TEXT: For many Cuban commuters, getting to work these days means riding a bicycle instead of a bus, one of many hardships resulting from declining Soviet oil deliveries to the island. With economic ties shrinking, and their respective ideologies no longer in harmony, Soviet-Cuban relations are facing greater uncertainty now than at any time in more than two decades, according to U.S. and Cuban experts. Although official relations remain cordial, there has been a sharp reduction in economic ties, particularly Soviet fuel exports to the island, forcing President Fidel Castro to impose increasingly draconian austerity measures. The economic hard times in Cuba have prompted widespread speculation among diplomats that the Cuban revolution's days may be numbered. But Cuban officials point out that, despite the difficulties, there has been no serious challenge to Castro's legitimacy. When Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev began implementing radical changes several years ago, many experts wondered whether the Soviets would decide to cut assistance to Cuba, estimated by the U.S. government to be $5 billion annually in economic aid alone during much of the previous decade. Now, with the Soviet economy itself facing a crisis, the question has shifted. ``The issue is more one of Soviet capacities than of Soviet intentions,'' says Cole Blasier, chief of the Hispanic Division at the Library of Congress. Curiously, Castro seems to agree. ``Has the USSR wanted to harm us?'' Castro asked in a speech late last month. ``No, the Soviet government has made every effort - and I say this with all honesty - to fulfill the supplies we agreed on.'' The Soviet-Cuban relationship has changed dramatically from the pre-Gorbachev era when the friendship of the two countries seemed unshakable. Starting about two decades ago, Cuba willingly lent itself to Soviet strategic objectives, sending troops by the tens of thousands to support pro-Soviet governments in Africa and elsewhere. In return, the Soviets lavished more aid on Cuba than any other country, shelling out premium prices for imports of Cuban sugar, citrus and nickel. According to the Soviet media, Cuba's debt to Moscow is about $24 billion. In the past, economic agreements were reached well in advance of target dates, leaving both countries ample time to gear up for their implementation. In his speech last month, Castro commented on how much things have changed lately. ``To date, we do not know what the basis of our trade with the USSR will be next year,'' Castro said. ``No one knows how much they are going to pay for our sugar, for our products. What price are we going to be charged for the products supplied by the USSR? What amount of fuel are we going to receive? No one knows at this time, although practically only three months remain before the end of the year.'' The Soviet deficit in fuel deliveries to Cuba is more than 2 million metric tons this year, prompting Castro to impose severe energy saving measures. Among the economic projects which have been sacrificed for lack of fuel are a nickel plant, a thermoelectric power plant and an oil refinery. The government has asked citizens to cut monthly household electricity use by 10 per cent. Supplies of gasoline for private motorists have been reduced by 30 per cent. Fuel shortages have forced the cancellation of many bus routes. Cuban authorities have responded by importing thousands of bicycles and distributing them to workers throughout Havana. Adding to the uncertainty is the Soviets' stated intention to shift foreign economic relations from an ideological to an economic basis starting in January. Some in the Kremlin, however, argue that Cuba deserves special consideration because of Castro's long years of loyalty to the Soviets. Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla., said last month after a visit to the Soviet Union that he envisions no reversal of the decline in Soviet-Cuban relations. ``The Soviets have clearly concluded that Fidel Castro is no longer a luxury that they can afford,'' Graham said. ``Particularly as he grows further and further away from their objectives of glasnost and perestroika.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Gearing Up to Send Christmas Gifts to Gulf GIs
DOC.TEXT: An organization that sent $3 million worth of gift packages to servicemen in Vietnam is cranking up to ship Christmas packages to American soldiers in the Persian Gulf. Roger Chapin, president of Help Hospitalized Veterans, said his goal is to raise enough money to send 250,000 packages, enough for every American serving in Operation Desert Shield. Chapin said the packages will have a retail value of at least $15, including packaging and shipping, and will contain nuts, cookies, dates, raisins, hard candies and other treats. Each package will include a Christmas card from the donor, along with a return card for the recipient to send. Chapin said the cost to the donor for one package would be $15. Two can be sponsored for $25, four for $50, six for $75 and eight for $100. People wishing to donate may call 1-800-755-GIFT (or 1-800-755-4438) from Oct. 14 to Nov. l5, or may send a check or money order to ``G.I. Christmas Gift Pac'' at P.O. Box 91560, Washington, D.C. 20090. ``This will be the ideal vehicle for Americans to demonstrate their care and appreciation as well as their solidarity and support to our troops in the Persian Gulf,'' Chapin said. Help Hospitalized Veterans is an offshoot of Vietnam Gift Pac, which Chapin, a former San Diego real estate developer, founded in 1967 after a chance meeting with a Navy corpsman wounded in Vietnam. The organization raised money to package and ship gift packages, each containing $9.12 worth of 28 personal items, including medicated foot powder, instant lemonade to flavor foul-tasting water and first aid cream for jungle sores. Chapin, an Army veteran, founded Help Hospitalized Veterans in 1970. The non-profit organization provides hospitalized veterans with arts and crafts kits. In a related development, the Postal Service urged Americans mailing Christmas gifts to service personnel in the gulf region to mail early. ``With the military build-up in Saudi Arabia, we're expecting a big strain to be placed on our mail transportation system worldwide,'' said Allen Kane, assistant postmaster general for delvery, distribution and transportation. The Postal Service said that to ensure timely delivery to the Middle East, air parcels should be mailed by Nov. 16, letters and cards by Nov. 26, parcel airlift mail by Nov. 10 and space-available mail by Nov. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Striped Bass Ban Set
DOC.TEXT: Fishing for Atlantic striped bass will be prohibited in most federal waters starting Nov. 1, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced. Harvest and possession of striped bass will be banned in federal waters extending from 3 miles to 200 miles off shore. The only exception is an area of Block Island Sound, Rhode Island, where fishermen will be permitted to transport to the mainland bass taken legally in state waters at Block Island. The regulations are intended to protect the striped bass, which is slowly recovering from a severe decline in the 1970s and early 1980s, NOAA's National Marine Fisheries Service said. Taking of striped bass in state waters is subject to varying regulation.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Klansman Ponders Political Future After Strong Showing in Senate Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf, `Roemer didn't...' with two grafs to UPDATE with reax from Roemer.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NU1, NU2
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston won a fourth term, but former Ku Klux Klan grand wizard David Duke says his strong showing may translat into the beginning of a national political agenda. Or maybe a run at the Louisiana governorship. Duke claimed 44 percent of the vote in Saturday's race against Johnston, a Democrat who had always been easily re-elected. ``I'm very committed to making political changes in this state and in this country. I've got to be very encouraged by this election,'' Duke said at a news conference Sunday. ``I want to move forward. I want to make an impact. I want to make a difference.'' Johnston, who got 54 percent of the vote, said he ``got the message'' from the more than 600,000 people who voted for Duke, but he added that he would not become more conservative, claiming much of Duke's showing was the result of rocky economic times in Louisiana. During the bitter campaign, Duke attacked affirmative action, forced busing and welfare abuse. He also attacked Johnston for playing a key role in the Senate campaign to reject conservative Supreme Court nominee Robert Bork and for backing the 1990 Civil Rights Act. ``I knew David Duke had a tremendous appeal. There's frustration out there. When people are unemployed and underemployed, it's easy to blame it on someone else,'' Johnston said. ``It's easy to blame on affirmative action.'' Complete but unofficial returns gave Johnston 749,552 votes, or 54 percent, and Duke 605,681 votes, or 44 percent. Two minor Democratic candidates split the remainder. Nick Accardo had 21,709 votes and Larry Crowe had 14,472 votes. Ed Renwick of Loyola University's Institute of Politics said Duke, a member of the state Legislature, may have lost the election, but gained national attention. ``You don't win elections with 44 percent, but it makes a lot of politicians sit up and take notice,'' he said. On Sunday, Duke backed off of his announced plan to go to court over absentee ballots cast but not counted for state Sen. Ben Bagert, the official Republican nominee. Bagert dropped out two days before Saturday's primary amid pressure from national GOP leaders who feared that his candidacy would force a runoff between Johnston and the maverick Republican Duke. Under Louisiana's open primary system, all candidates run against each other in the primary, regardless of party. If no one gets more than 50 percent, those finishing first and second face each other in a runoff. Bagert withdrew too late to get his name off the ballot. Under a 1981 law, his votes could not be counted, but some were because it was too late to change computer programs or courthouse operations. Those reported to The Associated Press gave Bagert 10,536 votes - less than 1 percent of the 1.4 million cast. Although Bagert said dropping out was his idea, Duke called the withdrawal a political deal and a dirty trick. Johnston got the unprecedented cross-party endorsement of eight Republican senators and Jack Kemp, secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Duke said he was studying a possible run for Louisiana governor in 1991. Such a race would require him to give up his state House seat, which he won in a special election in 1989. ``I think that (Gov.) Buddy Roemer better be sobered up to the fact that we received well over 100,000 more votes than he received for the governorship,'' Duke said. Roemer said today he wasn't worried about Duke. ``Time takes care of a lot of things,'' the governor said. ``My job is to take care of this state.'' There also has been speculation that Duke might seek a U.S. House seat in 1992, probably from one of the north Louisiana districts where he polled heavily on Saturday. In other races, New Orleans was assured of having its first black congressman since Reconstruction when state Sen. William Jefferson and Marc Morial, both Democrats, qualified for a Nov. 6 runoff. By a 2-1 margin, voters also approved Louisiana's first lottery since a corrupt private lottery was shut down by Congress in the late 1890s. New Orleans District Attorney Harry Connick, who was acquitted earlier this year of federal charges stemming from the return of a bookmaker's records, easily won re-election over two opponents. Connick is the father of Harry Connick Jr., a Grammy Award-winning musician.

DOC.HEAD: Tory Party Conference A Fortress; Thatcher At Risk, Say Police
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party opens its annual conference Tuesday ringed by a spiked fence and sharpshooters, while police warned she faces a grave risk of an assassination attempt. The unprecedented security for her arrival Monday evening in this south England seaside resort followed a spate of Irish Republican Army attacks this year, including the July 30 car bomb killing of a close political aide. ``This year I see it (the threat to Mrs. Thatcher) personally as extremely high,'' said Dorset County deputy police chief, Alan Rose, who headed the $3.94-million security operation. The four-day conference, which may be the last time Mrs. Thatcher rallies her trailing Conservatives before she calls a general election, was buoyed by a booming pound and government-inspired hopes of lower interest rates. The jaunty mood, which many warned may not last, was sparked by Britain's entry Monday of the pound into the mechanism which links other major European currencies. Mrs. Thatcher made the surprise announcement late Friday shortly before early arrivals among the some 10,000 people - including delegates, journalists and police reinforcements - began assembling in Bournemouth. Many commentators regarded the move by Mrs. Thatcher as playing her last ace to try to pull the economy back from the edge of recession and damp both interest rates and inflation to give her a better-than-even chance of winning again. ``...It has been a very difficult year for us,'' Tory party chairman Kenneth Baker acknowledged Monday, referring to the party's 18-month lag in opinion poll ratings behind the socialist Labor Party. Gallup and Market Opinion and Research International polls published over the weekend and on Monday showed the Tories 12 to 14.5 points behind Labor, which had its conference last week. Earlier polls showed the Labor lead down to around nine points. Mrs. Thatcher, whose ratings appear to be benefiting from her robust response to the Persian Gulf crisis, must call an election by June 1992. But she may do so at any time when she thinks she has the best chance of winning. Mrs. Thatcher linked sterling to the Exchange Rate Mechanism of the European Monetary System although British inflation at 10.6 percent is nearly twice the average of the 12-nation European Community. She said, among other things, that it was an antiinflationary measure. Britain's interest rates fell one point to 14 percent Monday, and government officials predicted drops in both interest rates and inflation early next year. The six-feet high fence, the first ever put up at a British political party conference, snaked three miles around the seafront convention center and the Highcliff Hotel, where leading party members were staying. Some 1,500 police, including nearly 1,000 drafted in from forces in a dozen other counties, and unspecified military units guarded this sedate resort 108 miles southwest of London. Sharpshooters were posted on roof tops, a 5,500-foot air exclusion zone was imposed from dawn Saturday and naval vessels were due to patrol offshore during the conference. Security at the governing party's annual conferences has been stepped up since the outlawed IRA detonated a bomb at the hotel where Mrs. Thatcher was staying during the 1984 conference in nearby Brighton. She escaped, but five party members were killed and 31 injured, and the IRA vowed to try again. The IRA, a mainly Roman Catholic organization, is fighting to end British rule in Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland and unite the province with the Irish Republic under a leftist administration. The spate of IRA attacks in England this year has roused new fears. Attacks include the July 30 killing of Conservative lawmaker Ian Gow and a foiled attempt Sept. 27 to assassinate Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave by taping a bomb to the speaker's lectern at a London conference. Police said Monday they were looking for a 21-year-old Belfast man who worked as a kitchen porter at the Royal Overseas League Club, where the bomb was planted, but has not been seen since Sept. 27.

DOC.HEAD: Western Michigan University Gets $5 Million for Teacher Evaluation Center
DOC.TEXT: Western Michigan University has received a $5 million grant from the U.S. Department of Education to establish a national center to improve evaluation methods for educators, officials announced Monday. The grant, the largest in the university's history, will establish the Center for Research on Educational Accountability on Nov. 1 within the university's existing Evaluation Center. The center will become the focal point for efforts to improve measurement procedures for evaluating the performance of teachers and administrators in both public and private schools. ``Personnel evaluation has always been something of a hot potato,'' said Daniel L. Stufflebeam, who will serve as the center's director. Public demand for accountability has pushed many districts and even entire states to adopt misguided teacher evaluation methods, he said. A goal of the center will be to provide schools with evaluation models that are unbiased and efficient. Western was selected for the grant after a six-month nationwide competition. The center $1 million in federal funds annually for five years.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Begins for White Supremacist Facing $10 Million Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: White supremacist Tom Metzger arrived in court today to defend himself against a $10 million lawsuit alleging he incited the bludgeoning death of a black man.
