Metzger, of Fallbrook, Calif., founded White Aryan Resistance and is a former Ku Klux Klan grand dragon. He is acting as his own attorney in the trial before a black judge, Ancer Haggerty of Multnomah County Circuit Court. The lawsuit accuses Metzger of sending agents to Portland to advocate violence against blacks shortly before the November 1988 beating death of Mulugeta Seraw, 27. Three ``skinheads'' were convicted in Seraw's slaying. The trial is the focus of a week's worth of activities planned by national civil rights organizations. And it has drawn threats from white supremacists, hundreds of whom reportedly were coming to town for the proceedings. This morning, however, only a handful of skinheads - with shaved heads and heavy boots - were at the Multnomah County Courthouse. They were searched and interrogated by police. ``We got nothin' to say to you,'' one of them told a reporter. Security was tight around the courthouse. An estimated 50 police, many in riot gear and some on horseback, were posted outside. A police helicopter hovered overhead. The street behind the courthouse was closed to traffic, and an intersection was cleared for Metzger's arrival. He was whisked into a 6-foot-high metal elevator that rose from the sidewalk and descended into the courthouse. The trial got under way at 10 a.m., half an hour late. The lawsuit was filed by Engedaw Berhanu, Seraw's uncle. Berhanu is represented by attorney Morris Dees of the Alabama-based Southern Poverty Law Center. It cites the legal doctrine of vicarious liability, which holds that one person or organization can be legally liable for the actions of another. Three years ago, Dees won a $7 million jury verdict against the United Klans of America after two Klansmen from Mobile, Ala., killed a 19-year-old black man. Also named in the wrongful death lawsuit are Metzger's son, John, and two of the three skinheads convicted in Seraw's death. Seraw was attacked by Kenneth Mieske, Kyle Brewster and Steven Strasser, members of East Side White Pride. The three men and their girlfriends drove up as Seraw, an Ethiopian, was being dropped off by friends. ``They deliberately went up there for the purpose of starting a fight,'' police Detective Tom Nelson said. ``Seraw was defending himself against Brewster when Mieske came up and blindsided Seraw with a baseball bat.'' The blow to the head knocked Seraw to the pavement. Mieske smashed Seraw's head twice more, splitting the bat lengthwise, police said. Mieske admitted he killed Seraw because he was black. He pleaded guilty to murder and racial intimidation, Brewster pleaded guilty to manslaughter and racial intimidation, and Strasser pleaded guilty to manslaughter. Mieske was sentenced to life with a 20-year minimum, Brewster to 10 to 20 years and Strasser to 20 years. Despite the confessions, Metzger contends the killing was in self-defense. ``We've been saying from the beginning that it was mutual combtt provoked by the Ethiopians,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Turning Kuwait Into Iraqi Backwater
DOC.TEXT: By violence and stealth, Saddam Hussein is rapidly transforming Kuwait from a glittering emirate to an Iraqi backwater, diplomats, exiled officials and refugees say. ``The Iraqis are doing their best to obliterate Kuwait's identity and seal it off from the outside,'' said one senior Western diplomat displaced by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion. ``The world doesn't realize how successful they are.'' While noting that no accurate count was possible, he estimated that hundreds, if not thousands, of Kuwaitis had been put to death. Some were shot in front of their families. Many others were deported to Iraq. Diplomats and Kuwaiti officials in exile endorsed a recent Amnesty International report of ``a horrifying picture of widespread arrests, torture under interrogation, summary executions and mass extrajudicial killings.'' Beyond that, the diplomats and officials said, Iraq was carting off everything from blood supplies in hospitals to traffic lights and forcing citizens to exchange Kuwaiti papers for Iraqi identity cards. They described a harrowing climate of fear and repression, which in recent days has triggered another exodus of Kuwaitis into Saudi Arabia. In one incident, a Western diplomat said, Iraqi soldiers shot to death five hospital workers when doctors told them that a wounded comrade they brought in was already dead on arrival. Saddam has entrusted the dismantling of Kuwait to a relative, Ali Hassan al Majid, who two years ago commanded a brutal military campaign that crushed a Kurdish uprising with the help of poison gas, diplomats said. ``That gives some idea of Saddam's thinking,'' one Western specialist observed. As a result of the pressure, Kuwaiti government sources said they were not encouraging armed resistance which might provoke even more violence. Some 430,000 Iraqi troops reported to be deployed in occupied Kuwait and southern Iraq outnumber Kuwaitis left in the emirate. Few sources were prepared to be named since the Iraqis have acted on published information from refugees and exiles to target reprisals, diplomats reported. Increased checkpoints and house-to-house search teams are rooting out suspected dissidents and Westerners on the run. Intelligence units search bank records and private papers to hunt down members of the emir's family and former officials. Iraq has closed Kuwait not only to journalists but also to the Red Cross and humanitarian workers. Deputy Prime Minister Taha Yassim Ramadan, a close aide of Saddam's, recently denied human rights abuses, then said Iraq would ``cut off the legs'' of anyone trying to enter Kuwait without permission. Accounts by refugees fit together to draw a clear picture of Iraqi intent. ``They've taken almost everything to Iraq,'' said Yusuf al-Ali, a 25-year-old Kuwaiti Airways pilot who crossed into Saudi Arabia on Sunday. ``You see trucks in front of the big houses. They strip them - carpets, videos, anything.'' On a larger scale, technicians have dismantled medical equipment and research facilities, burned public buildings and looted grain stocks. ``They don't need a lot of the things they're taking,'' said Ali Abu-Asi, an aide to Kuwait's Crown Prince, Sheik Saad, interviewed in Taif, Saudi Arabia. ``It's to dominate Kuwait, to humiliate it and make it just another province of Iraq.'' Iraqi forces are especailly brutal with anyone representing authority or anyone suspected of armed resistance, the sources agreed. They said nearly every captured Kuwaiti military and police officer was either shot on the spot or taken off for days and then returned to be executed in front of relatives. Over the past few weeks, large numbers of Iraqis have settled in the conquered emirate, either encouraged by Baghdad or drawn by the chance to grab unprotected property. Holdout Western embassies have maintained a defiant, if symbolic, presence despite Iraqi orders that since Kuwait has been declared Iraq's 19th province, foreign embassies are no longer permitted. But the diplomats' resources are dwindling fast. At the U.S. Embassy, Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and a half-dozen other Americans survive by boiling water from the swimming pool and eating up their last cans of food. ``Not one of them's going to look at a tunafish sandwich again for the rest of his life,'' said one U.S. official in touch with the embassy. Hundreds of thousands of Asian workers remain in Kuwait, desperately short of food and, in many cases, afraid for their lives. Hundreds of thousands have left, taking their chances on a grim odyssey across the desert to Jordan or Iran. Several thousand Westerners are still hiding in suburban homes in Kuwait, waiting for the fateful knock of Iraqi patrols trying to round them up for Saddam's human shield. U.S. officials estimate that Americans now number about 1,000, one-third of the number who were in Kuwait when Iraq attacked. The Amnesty International report said: ``Iraqi forces have arrested not only people suspected of armed attacks against them, but men, women and children found with opposition literature, the Kuwaiti flag or photographs of the emir.'' It said men were seized at the border and sent to Iraq for secret detention or military service. The possession of Kuwaiti flags, opposition literature or even the emir's photo is a capital offense. ``The Amnesty report squares absolutely with what we have, and what the Kuwaitis here have,'' a veteran diplomat said. ``In fact, things are even worse than that, but no one can get in to reveal the details.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Advertises on Car Trunk for Spouse - No Takers
DOC.TEXT: John Young fears women aren't taking his approach seriously - he's advertising for a spouse with a sign on his car. ``I've had no takers. Absolutely none,'' the 45-year-old divorced convenience store manager said Monday. ``Not even a crank call.'' For two months he's been driving around with a sticker on his car trunk reading ``wife wanted'' in block letters, followed by his telephone number. A few women customers at the Pick Kwik noticed the sign and commented that it was unique, but that was it. ``The men scoff at it. They say things like, `What, are you crazy? I've got one you can have,' '' he said. ``I think it's being taken lightly, like a joke, rather than a serious attempt at making contact,'' said Young, of nearby Largo. After four years of marriage, Young was divorced 10 years ago. He doesn't like singles bars - too artificial and noisy, he said. Personal advertisements in magazines have drawn responses from older, seemingly desperate women, not what he has in mind. ``I'm pretty much of a homebody. If you're a mid-40s homebody, alone, what do you do?'' Young, who describes himself as intelligent, sensitive and curious, said his ideal woman would be intelligent - ``that's the first thing'' - with a pretty face. ``And from there on, it's just a matter of chemistry.'' What does he have to offer? ``I care,'' he said. ``And I'm absolutely serious about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Two U.S. Pilots Die in Jet Crash, Search on For 8 in Missing Copters
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last two grafs, `Since then....serious injuries.' with 4 grafs to ADD that worst accident re the gulf occurred in West Germany. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. pilots died in a jet crash in Saudi Arabia today, and the Navy searched for two helicopters and eight crew members missing in the North Arabian Sea, military officials said. The officials said the RF4C Phantom reconnaisance jet, belonging to a unit of the Alabama Air National Guard assigned to Operation Desert Shield, crashed in the southern Saudi Arabian peninsula shortly after 1 p.m. (5 a.m. EDT.) The names of the pilots were withheld pending notification of relatives. A military spokesman, Navy Cmdr. J.D. Van Sickle, said he could provide no other details other than that the crash was being investigated. The crash came as Navy search and rescue efforts continued for eight Marines missing after two UH-1 helicopters vanished during a training flight in the North Arabian Sea earlier today. As night fell, there was no further word on the outcome of the search. Navy officers ruled out hostile action in the incident, which occurred well outside the Strait of Hormuz leading to the Persian Gulf, and 500 to 600 miles from where ground forces are deployed in the Saudi Arabian desert. They also said there was no indication the two UH-1 Hueys had collided in flight as they were returning to the amphibious assault carrier USS Okinawa. In Washington, the Pentagon confirmed there had been no progress in the search operation. A spokesman said the Marines were from the Camp Pendelton, Calif. base. ``Radar and voice contact was lost'' at 5:13 a.m., van Sickle said. ``Search and rescue efforts are currently under way.'' Each helicopter carried two pilots and two crew members. Their identities were withheld pending completion of the Navy's search in the North Arabian Sea. The U.S. forces were deployed in Saudi Arabia and nearby waterways after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Since then, seven American military personnel have been killed in accidents in the Persian Gulf region. In addition to the two pilots today, two Air Force F-16 pilots were killed in a crash Sept. 30, a soldier and a Marine died in vehicular accidents, and a sailor was electrocuted in an accident aboard a ship in the Persian Gulf. There have been five previous helicopter mishaps, none causing deaths or serious injuries. The worst accident involving U.S. personnel since the gulf crisis began occurred on Aug. 29 when a giant C-5A transport aircraft loaded with supplies for U.S. forces in the gulf crashed and burned in West Germany shortly after takeoff, killing 13 crew members.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth Cambodian Dancer Seeks Asylum
DOC.TEXT: A member of a visiting Cambodian dance troupe has requested political asylum, the fourth member of the company to do so in its month-long U.S. tour. The 22-year-old woman dancer, whose name was not released, stayed behind after a performance while the remainder of the troupe continued to its next stop, New York City, on Sunday. She was waiting at an undisclosed location to speak with officials from the Immigration and Naturalization Service, who said the meeting would be held on Tuesday at the earliest. Three other dancers from the troupe, the Cambodian Classical Dance Company, sought asylum while on a stop in St. Paul, Minn., last week. Angry organizers of the dance tour charged that Cambodians in the United States, including members of Lowell's large Cambodian-American community, coerced the dancers into leaving to score political points. ``What has clearly happened is some of the political groups that are against the government in Phnom Penh have done the one thing they can do: pressure the dancers to defect,'' said John McAuliff, director of the sponsoring U.S.-Indo-China Reconciliation Project in Philadelphia. Cambodian-American activists ``were all over us,'' McAuliff said. ``It's been clear that they have been trying very hard to undermine the tour.'' Cambodians in Lowell and St. Paul acknowledged they encouraged the defections to protest the government in Phnom Penh. ``They call it a cultural performance, but this (dance tour) is to convince the American people to support the Cambodian government,'' said Bunthan Eang, editor of the Cambodian Press in Lowell and a leader of the city's 25,000-member Cambodian community. He said the woman who defected in Lowell ``made her own decision without anybody interfering.'' Many Cambodians in the United States believe that Vietnam controls their country. Vietnamese troops withdrew in 1989 after 10 years of occupation. The dance company now touring the U.S. is part of the government-controlled University of Fine Arts in Phnom Penh. It performed before a sellout crowd of 3,000 in the Lowell Auditorium on Saturday, said Ruth Meehan, cultural events coordinator of the Lowell Historic Preservation Commission, which cosponsored the event. INS officials wouldn't discuss the case, citing policy keeping cases private. Three dancers stayed behind in Minnesota after an appearance at the Ordway Music Theatre in St. Paul. They were a brother and sister, Hing Rachhana and Hing Thonnora, and a male dancer, Nou Van Thy.

DOC.HEAD: Six Reportedly Commit Suicide Over Job Policy
DOC.TEXT: At least six students committed suicide Monday to protest a job quota program that reserves half of the government's jobs for lower-caste Hindus, news reports said. Press Trust and United News of India, both news agencies, said five students poisoned themselves and one set himself ablaze. The incidents took place in the states of Haryana, Punjab and Andhra Pradesh. Students from higher castes, angered by a government refusal to review the plan, attacked a passenger train in the central Indian city of Allahabad, and set two train cars on fire. There were no reports of casualties. In New Delhi, three students attempted suicide, Press Trust said. Students from the city's schools, which opened Monday after nearly a month of forced closure, attacked buses and damaged30, the news agency said. Monday's deaths brought to at least 90 the number of people who have killed themselves or died in violence since Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced Aug. 7 that nearly half of all government jobs would be reserved for lower-caste Hindus. Public opposition to the government has been widespread in the politically influential cities of northern India. The army was called out and curfews clamped on several towns to control rioting students, joined sometimes by housewives and government employees. Two members of Singh's governing party have resigned from Parliament and some colleagues have demanded his ouster because of the quotas. But Singh has refused to abandon the policy, saying it is an affirmative action program that would give social justice to the lower castes. Critics say he fears alienating the lower castes, which form a majority of the eligible voters among India's 880 million people. Upper-caste students say reverse discrimination will deprive them of jobs for which they are better qualified. The plan reserves 27 percent of federal jobs for low-caste Hindus. An additional 22 percent already are set aside for the lowest strata in the rigid hierarchy of Indian society.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman Emeritus Of National Geographic Society Dies
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Melvin M. Payne, chairman emeritus of the National Geographic Society's board of trustees, has died of pneumonia, the society said Monday. He was 79. Payne, who began his career with the society in 1932 as a secretary and served both as president and chairman of the board, died on Saturday. During his tenure as head of the society's research division, he provided support for such projects as Capt. Jacques Cousteau's underwater explorations, the first American ascent of Mt. Everest, and Jane Goodall's study of wild chimpanzees. He also was instrumental in beginning the series of hour-long public television programs that highlight the society's work. An attorney, Payne completed his legal studies while working as secretary to former chairman emeritus Thomas V. McKnew. He was named a vice president in 1958 and joined the board of trustees later that year. He was named president in 1967 and in 1976 was elected chairman of the society's board of trustees. He has served as chairman emeritus since 1987. Survivors include Payne's wife Ethel McDonnell Payne of Bethesda, Md., two daughters, a brother, a sister, three grandchildren and a great-granddaughter.

DOC.HEAD: Police 19 Killed in Clash at Holy Site in Jerusalem
LaserPhotos JRL1,2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE with police death toll at 19, Arab hospital death toll at 18. Pickup 20th, `Until today...'
DOC.TEXT: Police opened fire on stone-throwing Palestinians at the Temple Mount in Jerusalem's Old City today, and Israeli police said 19 people were killed and 140 were injured. Arab hospital officials first said 22 were killed. However, they later gave a lower casualty toll than the one provided by Israeli Police Minister Roni Milo, saying 18 Palestinians were killed and 125 wounded. The incident was the bloodiest in the holy city since Israel captured its Arab sector from Jordan in the 1967 Mideast war. The death toll also was the highest in a single day since the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation began in December 1987. In disturbances following today's rioting, two Palestinians were killed in the occupied Gaza Strip, hospital officials said. The Jerusalem clash erupted after Palestinians threw stones from the Mount at Jews worshiping below at the Wailing Wall, Judaism's holiest site, witnesses said. Thousands of Jews were at the wall celebrating the Sukkot festival. Milo said 20 Jews were injured. He said 120 Arabs were arrested, including Faisal Husseini, a prominent Palestinian nationalist involved in unofficial peace contacts with Israeli moderates. He said Husseini was arrested on the Temple Mount. A senior paramilitary border police officer, Yossi Tobias, told Israel radio some 3,000 Arabs were involved in the rioting. The Palestinians apparently were angered by rumors that Jews were trying to establish a presence on the Temple Mount, which is holy to both Jews and Moslems, but is under Moslem control. The Arabs burned down a police station in the Temple Mount compound and hurled hundreds of rocks at Jewish worshipers. As thousands of Jews fled from the Wailing Wall, police riot squads fired tear gas to disperse Arab rioters on the mount above. Witnesses said the Palestinians regrouped and charged the police. Police opened fire with rubber and plastic bullets and then live ammunition, the witnesses said. Police Commissioner Yaacov Terner said: ``They burned the police station. There was no policeman who wasn't stoned. Their lives were in real danger. They had no other way but to respond the way they did. The toll was very heavy, but the Israel police had to defend themselves, and to protect the thousands of worshipers.'' Terner told reporters that authorities had repeatedly assured Moslem leaders that no Jewish demonstrations on the Temple Mount would be permitted. At the same news conference, Milo said caches of rocks and flammable materials were found on the Temple Mount. This, he said, showed that the riot was ``a planned provocation'' aimed partly at distracting the world's attention from the Persian Gulf crisis. The Palestinians have largely sided with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in the confrontation over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Calm returned to the Temple Mount about two hours after the incident, but throughout the day scattered incidents occurred in the Old City. Israel radio said it had reports of Jewish civilians shooting at Arabs. Until today, the worst toll in the uprising was 17 dead on April 16, 1988, when rioting swept the West Bank and Gaza Strip after PLO military leader Khalil Wazir was killed in Tunis in a commando raid. The raid was blamed on Israel. The Palestine Liberation Organization issued a statement from its headquarters in Tunisia, accusing the Israelis of a massacre. Bassam Abu Sharif, a top aide to PLO leader Yasser Arafat, said the U.N. Security Council should take urgent steps to protect Palestinians and force an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories. After today's rioting broke out, police closed off the area around the Wailing Wall, the last remnant of the ancient Jewish temple destroyed by the Romans in the year 70. On the Temple Mount, pools of blood stained the ground around the Al Aqsa Mosque. Palestinians said thousands of Moslems, including some wounded, remained in the mosque, apparently afraid to come out with the heavily armed border police still around. At Augusta Victoria Hospital, 26-year-old Khaled Shlatef of Ramallah in the West Bank said the Arabs had rushed to defend the mount after hearing that Jews were going to enter. ``We are Moslems, and we came here to defend our mosque,'' said Shlatef, who was wounded in the head with rubber bullets. The rumors followed the distribution of leaflets by a Jewish extremist group called the Temple Mount Faithful saying it planned to go up to the mount. The group wants to build a new Jewish temple on the Mount to replace the ancient one. However, the group's members did not arrive in the area until after the rioting was under way. The trouble began shortly before 11 a.m. (5 a.m. EDT) when Arabs burned the police station and at the same time threw hundreds of stones at the Jews below, police said. Mel Rosen, a witness watching from his balcony 300 yards away, said he saw a barrage of stones pour onto worshipers at the wall. Rosen, an American photographer, said riot squads then entered the Temple Mount compound and scattered the crowd with tear gas. The Arabs regrouped and threw more stones over the wall, prompting the police to open fire, he said. He said the torrent of rocks was so thick that onlookers at first thought they were seeing flocks of birds flying out of the crannies of the wall where they nest. Women praying in their section of the gender-segregated plaza ran for shelter in the tunnels alongside part of the Wall. ``There was a shower of stones and that is when people started to panic. People started shouting `Where is my child?' and running,'' said Oded Wiener, who was at the Wall.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Says Exiles Can Apply to Return Home
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk announced Monday that political exiles can begin applying to return to South Africa, addressing a key demand of the African National Congress. His statement followed a three-hour meeting with ANC leader Nelson Mandela at which they apparently differed on causes of black factional fighting that has killed about 800 people in eight weeks. De Klerk said that exiles, many based in Zambia and other southern African nations, could immediately begin applying for amnesty for ``political offenses.'' But he cautioned: ``No indemnity for anyone, or for any event or offense is granted automatically.'' He said any possible indemnity would only apply to acts committed before Monday's meeting. The move could help resolve one of the major stumbling blocks of peace talks between the white-led government and Mandela's ANC, the largest black opposition movement. The ANC has demanded the return of its estimated 20,000 exiles before beginning full-scale negotiations on black-white power sharing and ending apartheid. Until Monday, the government had agreed in principle but never announced a mechanism. De Klerk's statement said full details of the process would be announced later. It also said exiles from other organizations may be included. Smaller black opposition groups also have members who fled South Africa after committing politically motivated acts. The government also agreed to release 15 more political prisoners this week, the statement said. Dozens have been freed in recent months, but up to 3,000 remain imprisoned, according to the ANC. A working group on the return of exiles was set up as part of the government-ANC talks launched in May. De Klerk's statement said activation of the exile return process followed ANC acceptance of the working group's report. The ANC requested Monday's meeting to discuss the peace process, which has been strained by the factional fighting that erupted Aug. 12 in black townships around Johannesburg. A separate joint statement read by Mandela after the meeting said ``note was taken of the different current perceptions concerning the causes and handling of the violence.'' ``All sides must do their utmost to bring this violence to an end,'' it said. ``Both sides reaffirmed the need to keep the negotiating process on course.'' Mandela, who has accused security forces of orchestrating the violence, was expected to hand de Klerk information about his accusations Monday. After the meeting, he refused to answer questions. De Klerk and government officials have denied security force involvement in the fighting. The main combatants in the township battles have been supporters of the ANC and Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement. Both groups oppose apartheid but differ over plans for a future South Africa. The fighting has slowed in recent weeks, but there are still sporadic incidents.

DOC.HEAD: On (Flight) 1492, Americans Discover Columbus
DOC.TEXT: In 1492, Columbus came to America. On Monday, a group of Americans went to Columbus, aboard 1492. USAir's regular Flight 1492 soared east from Los Angeles International Airport and headed for Columbus, Ohio, on the 498th anniversary of the Italian explorer's discovery of the Americas. ``The only people who do notice are the elderly people. I guess younger people don't associate with it,'' said USAir's Marcie Grow, a customer service representative. One traveler who noticed was Burt Jones of South Pasadena, a self-described ``kindly old gent'' who refused to divulge his age. ``When I booked the flight I started laughing hysterically,'' Jones said. ``She (the agent) didn't understand.'' The Columbus-bound Boeing 737-300 left Gate 13 at 9 a.m. with 58 people aboard. The flight begins in San Francisco and ends at National Airport in Washington, D.C. Jones had a suggestion for USAir officials should they decide to change the flight number. ``Well, there's always 1493, when Columbus sailed the deep blue sea,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Issues Annual Call: Mail Early for Christmas
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service is making its annual Christmas request: Please mail early. Thousands of letters and parcels intended for the troops in the Middle East are expected to place an added burden on the mail, which generally faces its busiest day of the year the Monday before Christmas. ``The Postal Service will be moving a tremendous volume of holiday mail overseas. To ensure timely delivery, customers should send their cards, letters and packages bound for military and international locations as early as possible,'' said Assistant Postmaster General Allen Kane. While there is no deadline for Christmas mail within the United States, postal officials say the earlier it is sent, the better. For international mail, the agency's suggested deadlines for Christmas delivery are: Africa: air parcels, Nov. 20; letters and cards, Dec. 1; parcel airlift mail, Nov. 9, space available mail, Oct. 26. Alaska: air parcels, letters and cards, Dec. 8; parcel airlift, Dec. 1; space available mail, Nov. 24. Australia: air parcels, Nov. 16; letters and cards, parcel airlift and space available mail, Dec. 1. Caribbean: air parcels and letters and cards, Dec. 7; parcel airlift, Nov. 23; space available, Nov. 19. Europe: air parcels, letters and cards, Dec. 1, parcel airlift, Nov. 24; space available, Nov. 13. Far East: air parcels, letters and cards, Dec. 1; parcel airlift and space available, Nov. 15. Greenland: air parcels, letters and cards, Dec. 1; parcel airlift, Nov. 24, space available, Nov. 13. Middle East: air parcels, Nov. 16; letters and cards, Nov. 26; parcel airlift, Nov. 10; space available, Nov. 3. Southeast Asia: air parcels, Nov. 16; letters and cards, Nov. 19; parcel airlift, Nov. 9; space available, Nov. 2. Central and South America: air parcels, Dec. 1; letters and cards, Dec. 6; parcel airlift, Nov. 23; space available, Nov. 9.

DOC.HEAD: Mormon Church President Upgraded To Satisfactory Condition
DOC.TEXT: Mormon Church President Ezra Taft Benson was upgraded from serious to satisfactory condition Monday at LDS Hospital, where he is recovering from brain surgery. The 91-year-old Mormon leader was transferred from the hospital's intensive care unit to a private room, church spokesman Don LeFevre said. Benson is recovering from surgery last month to remove blood clots from his brain and from gastrointestinal bleeding discovered last week. He was hospitalized Sept. 18 after complaining of severe headaches and difficulty swallowing. The following day, doctors removed two large blood clots from each side of his brain; he underwent a second operation four days later after one of the clots reformed. Monday was the second time during Benson's hospital stay that he has been moved out of intensive care. On Sept. 28, he was upgraded to fair condition and moved to a regular room, only to be returned to intensive care in serious condition after doctors found the gastrointestinal bleeding. Church officials had hoped that Benson could attend this weekend's 160th Semiannual General Conference.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Prince Edward, youngest son of Queen Elizabeth II, switched on lights to illuminate the historic rail bridge crossing the Firth of Forth near Edinburgh. The ceremony Sunday was watched by about 250,000 people in the centennial year of the Forth Bridge, regarded by Victorians as the eighth wonder of the world. The lighting followed a day of festivities and a sound-and-light show using five tons of fireworks as well as lasers and searchlights. The cantilever bridge was the largest steel structure in the world when it opened on March 4, 1890. It is 8,296 feet long, or just over 1{ miles, and stands 361 feet from high water to the top of the main towers. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Ivana Trump's pay for running the Plaza Hotel has been increased from $1 per year and all the dresses she can buy, to an actual salary, according to a published report. New York magazine quoted an unidentified source inside estranged husband Donald Trump's organization as saying she recently succeeded in getting a salary. Eleanor Lambrt, a Plaza spokeswoman, said Mrs. Trump ``made a big stand to get a salary.'' But the magazine adds ``that clearly won't be enough to let her continue to live like a Trump.'' Mrs. Trump stands to collect $20 million from a prenuptial agreement, later updated during the marriage, if it ends in divorce. She has indicated she will contest the agreement. Since the news of the Trumps' estrangement became public in February, Trump has suffered a series of financial setbacks. --- TEMPE, Ariz. (AP) - Ted Turner, chairman and president of Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc., will receive the 1990 Walter Cronkite Award for Excellence in Journalism and Telecommunications, Arizona State University announced Monday. The award is presented each year by the Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Telecommunication to an individual deemed to have made outstanding contributions to journalism and telecommunication. Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting's operations include WTBS-TV, Cable News Network, Turner Network Television, the Atlanta Braves baseball team and the Atlanta Hawks basketball team. The award will be presented by Cronkite, the former CBS anchorman, during a Nov. 7 luncheon in Phoenix. Previous recipients of the award include the late Malcolm Forbes, Allen Neuharth, Katharine Graham, Bill Maudlin, Otis Chandler, William S. Paley and Frank Stanton. --- CHICAGO (AP) - The Secret Service agent credited with saving former President Ronald Reagan's life has been tapped to head the agency's Chicago office. Timothy J. McCarthy was wounded when he put himself between Reagan and gunman John Hinckley Jr. in a 1981 assassination attempt against the former president in Washington. Reagan and press secretary James Brady also were shot. Secret Service Director John Simpson named McCarthy, 41, special agent in charge of the Chicago office, which is being expanded to investigate fraud within the savings and loan industry. ``For me this appointment represents the pinnacle of my career,'' McCarthy said.

DOC.HEAD: House Republicans Relegated To Sidelines Because of Ideological Split
DOC.TEXT: House Republicans, Capitol Hill's forgotten minority, are suffering from a deep ideological split that has left them on the sidelines of America's budget crisis. The division, which dates to the election a year ago of Rep. Newt Gingrich to the party's No. 2 leadership post, pits old-line pragmatists against rebellious activists who are tired of more than three decades of minority status. ``It's a very difficult time around here,'' said Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., who was first elected in 1956, the same year as Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. ``I've never seen it quite like this, the bitterness and rancor that exists.'' When he was elected to the leadership last year, Gingrich promised colleagues that he would assume the team player responsibilities that go with the job. But last week he abandoned Michel and President Bush, and led rebels who killed the first attempt at a bipartisan budget package. Then on Sunday, as GOP leaders sought to take a role in drawing up a new version of the budget, Gingrich's demands in a closed-door Republican meeting hampered the efforts and the package was assembled and passed without them. The rebels apparently have calculated that the budget issue can be a good political weapon leading to the election of more Republicans on Nov. 6. But Rep. Pat Roberts, R-Kan., countered one Gingrich supporter making that argument at the private meeting, saying GOP candidates were the ones who would be hurt. One of Gingrich's top allies, Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn., said Republicans ``are slowly getting themselves back on a united, positive footing.'' A key to that, he said, is that the ``bipartisan budget will be transformed over the next 10 days into the Democratic tax increase.'' Frustration with Gingrich's actions broke into the open late Sunday as each party sought to blame the other for the partial shutdown of the government over the weekend. Gingrich contended that Democrats, after failing to override Bush's veto of a stopgap spending bill, now have ``an obligation to respond to that failure by cooperating with the president.'' That was too much for House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, who thundered back: ``Of all the people in this House, of all the people in this country who has little claim to cooperation with his president, it is the gentleman from Georgia.'' The jab was particularly effective, because it hit Gingrich where he is weakest within his own party: on the issue of loyalty and trustworthiness. The Georgian had no comeback, but just smiled and then strode off the House floor. During a closed-door Republican conference earlier in the day, Rep. Rod Chandler of Washington said, ``Those who do not support the president and the leadership should be silent, or resign,'' according to one lawmaker present, in a clear reference to Gingrich. Gingrich is out on a limb, some colleagues say. But that's not an unusual position for the white-haired, 47-year-old conservative. And he is hardly alone. He picked fights with a former House speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill, and was instrumental in forcing another former speaker, Jim Wright, to resign. ``This guy has no agenda except to create chaos, and to destroy Democrats,'' said Rep. Tim Penny, D-Minn. But that brand of firebrand partisanship was attracting support from Republicans who are tired of more than three decades of minority status in the House, a frustration amplified by budget summits that left the rank and file out of decisions. With 176 members, united House Republicans have the power to sustain President Bush's vetoes of legislation. But they often are ignored by the White House, which prefers to deal with Republicans in the Senate, where the playing field is less tilted against them. Some House GOP members have taken to calling themselves ``the potted plant caucus,'' a self-deprecating sign of their feelings of irrelevance. ``Members are hungering for a leader who will stand up for the conference'' and not simply follow orders from the White House, said one GOP lawmaker. But others pointed to an irony: that Gingrich's opposition to the original budget package meant the failure of the best proposal Republicans could hope for. ``The longer the process takes, the more liberal the package becomes,'' said Rep. Jim Leach, R-Iowa. The outcome means Gingrich likely will face a challenge when the party convenes to elect its leaders next year, said several Republicans.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Tank War `Like Ocean Battle'
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Like giant sand beetles, the eight-wheeled reconnaissance vehicles scuttled across the dry lake bed, pausing periodically behind dunes, then darting ahead in a leapfrog pattern. At each stop, turret commanders scanned the terrain for signs of activity - a dust cloud, or the dark specks of armored vehicles on the horizon. For nearly an hour, there was nothing. Then, monitoring the radio, Lance Cpl. Shannon Whitehead, 20, of Baytown, Texas, reported: ``Second platoon has spotted enemy tracks. Some kind of mechanized threat. The tanks are moving up.'' The Marine Corps LAV-25s, too lightly armed to tangle with enemy armor, withdrew swiftly to the rear. A platoon of M-60 tanks churned forward, deploying into the line of battle and hoping the element of surprise - vital in desert warfare - had not been lost. It was only a war game. In real battle, heavy artillery and aircraft would be hurled in the first minutes of fighting to disrupt and destroy the enemy. The scenario played out by the 3rd Battalion, 9th Marines, is as old as war itself. Alexander owed his greatness in part to the horsemen scouting ahead of his marching legions. So did Gen. Robert E. Lee, who called J.E.B. Stuart's cavalry the ``eyes of the army.'' If war comes to the Saudi desert, U.S. officers say it will be a classic battle of armor, not unlike those between Gen. Erwin Rommel's Afrika Korps and the British in North Africa or the Arabs and Israelis in Sinai. ``The technology is new, but the tactics really haven't changed since World War II,'' a Marine officer said after a day of chasing the simulated enemy across the ands. The reconnaissance teams, like these speedy Marine corps vehicles, may largely determine where and when a battle would begin. Then, officers say, the edge would go to whoever makes the best use of supporting arms - air power and artillery. Some officers believe the key to stopping an Iraqi armored thrust rests mainly with tank-killer aircraft - the Army's AH-64 Apache and AH-1 Cobra helicopters and the Air Force A-10 Warthogs. The Iraqis have built heavily fortified positions, with tanks dug in behind earthen berms along the potential battle line between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. But U.S. officers say they don't expect a static battle. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf III, the U.S. commander in Saudi Arabia, called desert warfare a ``war of attrition'' based on high mobility and lethality. ``It's not a war of straight lines drawn in the sand, where you dig in and say `I'll defend here or die,''' Schwarzkopf said in a recent interview. ``Most people who do that die.'' Lack of protective cover in the desert makes deception difficult, and speed and surprise paramount, field officers said. They talk of fast-moving armored forces vying for position that gives them the ``flank shot'' that hits an enemy tank in its most vulnerable spot, anywhere but the heavily protected nose. ``Even if the other guy's tank is supposedly better than yours, if you get the first shot and make it count, you win,'' said one Marine officer who spoke on condition of anonymity. Army Lt. Col. Rick Sanchez of Rio Grande City, Texas, who commands a battalion of M1 tanks in the 19th Armored Brigade, likens tank warfare to ``the way the navy would fight a battle in the ocean - vector in on him and try to outmanuever him in the vast expanse.'' The allied side and the Iraqis are doing roughly the same thing, putting lighter forces farthest forward, backed up by heavy forces that could defend by launching a counterattack. The Saudis and other Arab forces are farthest north, where they would be the first to make contact with a southward Iraqi thrust out of Kuwait or Iraq. The Americans, with their greater mobility, airpower and firepower, are to the rear - a political positioning that also leaves them in the role of counterstrike force. The United States also has some 10,600 Marines aboard amphibious ships to join any offensive.

DOC.HEAD: Only In This Day and Age - %&!!%!&%! At Touch of a Button
DOC.TEXT: The season's most popular novelty is a pocket-size electronic voice box that, at the push of a button, spews profane insults suitable for use in locker rooms, saloons and stockbrokers' offices. This adult toy is called the Final Word, and it delivers pre-recorded obscenities in a shrill voice that sounds like an angry chipmunk from Brooklyn. ``They're flying out the door,'' said Joan Geisler, owner of Postermat in Greenwich Village, as she waited for a broker to pick up his order of 60. ``People are calling up and reserving them by the dozens.'' Uptown, Dapy's on Columbus Avenue reported selling more than 250 in two days. The Final Word, which sells for $16.95, is a battery-powered, pre-programmed voice synthesizer that looks something like a beeper and sounds something like Andrew Dice Clay. It is designed to appeal to people who like the sound of dirty words, but may be reluctant to actually speak them. The Final Word, according to its manufacturer, allows people to talk back to ``all those obnoxious people in life, such as nagging in-laws, pushy sales people and know-it-all-bosses.'' All of whom, no doubt, have already purchased their own Final Word. The device comes in two versions, one rated ``G,'' the other ``X.'' The former repeats these phrases: ``You're an idiot''; ``Drop dead''; ``You're a dope''; and ``Stupid jerk.'' The content of the other version cannot be repeated here. Care to guess which of the two sells better? Once buyers hear the stronger version, ``They've got to have it,'' chortled Geisler, who has taken to using the X-rated version extensively over the telephone. ``A few years ago no one would have bought something like this, but now everything goes,'' she mused. Terri Boyle, spokeswoman for the manufacturer, said the device has proved popular in elevators, restaurants and cocktail parties. One example: A man shopping for a car was offered one by a dealer for an exorbitant price. The shopper told the dealer he'd punch the figure into his pocket calculator. Under the calculator he held the Final Word, which at the push of a button produced a scatological response to the inflated price - much to the dealer's surprise. In six weeks more than a half million units of the Final Word have been sold, and Banning Enterprises Ltd. of Farmingdale plans to ship out another million by Christmas. ``Business is very bad in gifts, and everybody's looking for a winner,'' said Geisler, who described the Final Word as one of the most popular novelties in her 30 years in the gift business. Displaying the X-rated version presents retailers with a problem. One store in Cleveland demonstrates it in a back room, out of earshot of most customers. Geisler plays it for selected customers, asking, ``Have you heard the Final Word?'' The Final Word is the creation of Budd Goldman. He, Geisler claims, is a novelty genius who also gave the world shower heads with people's faces on them and miniature, desktop replicas of refrigerators and lockers. The Final Word is particularly popular on Wall Street, where these days people are eager for a laugh of any sort. One firm ordered several hundred, perhaps to sum up the feelings of bulls trapped in a bear market.

DOC.HEAD: University Students Test Blood In Drive To Help Leukemia Victim
DOC.TEXT: More than 160 students at George Washington University had their blood tested Monday to see if they are candidates for donating bone marrow to an alumnus who is suffering from leukemia. It was the kickoff of a national effort to recruit donors for Ronni Cohen, 32, and thousands of others in need of a bone marrow transplant. ``We think there are 10,000 people in the United States every year who need transplants,'' retired Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, board chairman of the national marrow donor program, told a news conference. ``Out of the 10,000, only 3,000 are able to find a match.'' Zumwalt, whose son died of blood cancer, said his organization has signed up thousands of Americans to be ``volunteer donors for people they don't know.'' ``Initially, we were able to transplant 20 a month,'' he said. ``Now it's 20 a week. We need to get to 20 a day.'' Ms. Cohen, a 32-year-old public-interest lawyer and executive director of the Siegfried Foundation, has chronic myelogenous leukemia, a cancer of the blood-forming bone marrow. The disease usually strikes people between 45 and 60. A search of 500,000 potential donors in national and international registries has found no match. A hematologist at Washington Hospital Center, Dr. Mamoud Mustafa, said patients with blood cancers can get into long-term remissions with a bone marrow transplant, which he describes as relatively painless for the donor.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The federal government's partial shutdown is hitting Uncle Sam directly in the pocketbook with the loss of at least several million dollars in revenue from frustrated tourists and campers. From the campgrounds at Cape Hatteras National Seashore to Yosemite National Park in California, hundreds of thousands of dollars were lost this three-day weekend in camping fees, entry fees to parks, tolls along scenic highways and sales in museums and shops, officials said. In many places private concessionaires continued to operate, but parks were without guides, toll collectors or supervisors, forcing the grounds to be closed and campers to be directed away. The shutdowns and lost revenue stemmed from attempts by lawmakers and the Bush administration to reach an agreement on how best to cut the federal budget deficit. ``That's the irony of it,'' remarked Interior Department spokesman Steve Goldstein. ``We don't have personnel to man the parks, so we lose two ways. We can't open our resources to the public and we didn't gain any revenue.'' He said the park personnel would have had to be classified as ``essential'' to safety and health to be exempt from the shutdown directive. Spokesmen for the National Park Service said the revenue losses are likely to be substantial because the Columbus Day weekend traditionally is a busy period for many of the parks. The service said very preliminary figures indicated a loss for the weekend of more than $1.6 million. Officials acknowledged the amount could be higher. ``Usually you're looking at this weekend through Veterans Day as the peak fall visitor period,'' said Duncan Morrow, a service spokesman. He estimated that 750,000 visitors normally can be expected to visit the scores of parks known for their autumn colors. Along Skyline Drive in Virginia's Blue Ridge Mountains, motorists out to see the fall foliage at its peak did not have to pay the usual $5 fee as federal toll stations were closed. Officials said as many as 75,000 people enter Shenendoah National Park along the drive on a typical Columbus Day weekend, but this weekend nobody counted. At Yosemite, rangers cleared 6,000 campers from the park, losing camping fees ranging from $3.50 to $12 a night, officials said. At the Grand Canyon, losses in revenue were estimated at more than $25,000 a day during the weekend. Roads were blocked and campgrounds closed at other parks such as Olympic National Park. ``It's rather sad that they picked the parks (to close down). It's like they kind of cut their nose to spite their face,'' said Garner Hansen, president of National Park Concessions Inc., a company operating at five parks including Mammoth Cave National Park in Kentucky. Hansen said Mammoth Cave remained open, but all tours, costing $1.75 to $4.50, were cancelled. ``The visitors are very unhappy. They traveled long distances for the cave trips.... We're the only ones here and they're giving us an earful,'' he said in a telephone interview. Not far from Capitol Hill, where the budget drama has been unfolding, angry and disappointed tourists couldn't get into the White House, climb the Washington Monument or visit the complex of museums belonging to the Smithsonian Institution. Tourists could still walk among the animals of the National Zoo, although indoor zoo facilities, including the famous Panda House, were closed. Almost all of the tourist attractions in the capital, including museums, are free. Union officials, meanwhile, bemoaned the shutdown. ``It doesn't save any money,'' said John Sturdivant, president of the 700,000-member American Federation of Government Employees. ``When they shut down in 1981 it ended up costing them $5 million (in lost revenue).... It just creates problems, hassles and severe dislocation.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Says He's Not Worried About Possible Challenge
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer said Monday that he is not worried about a re-election challenge from ex-Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke and suggested that Duke might learn something from his U.S. Senate bid. ``He lost, as he does most races. Maybe he can change,'' Roemer said during an impromptu news conference. Roemer said that the race by Duke, a first-term member of the Louisiana House, against U.S. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston did show that voters have ``a lot of anger and anxiety ... against the federal government.'' ``I was pleased that Bennett won and I'm proud of the people of Louisiana for making that decision,'' the governor said. ``But there are a number of people who think the federal government is not responsive on energy policy, on balancing the budget. ``I think to ignore that anger is to ignore the fact. ... It's time for the federal government to wake up, put up and get this country right again. I think that's what that vote shows.'' Running as a maverick Republican, Duke picked up 44 percent of the vote in Saturday's primary against Johnston, a Democrat, despite his opponents' constant focus on his past as grand wizard of the KKK with ties to Nazi groups. Duke disavows his Klan past but says government policies need to be changed to give equal rights to whites. He advocates stricter limits on welfare and a flat-rate income tax, along with opposition to forced busing of schoolchildren and affirmative action programs. Duke, who said he will decide in the coming weeks on a 1991 governor's race, noted that he received a larger percentage of the vote than Roemer did in 1987. Johnston and Duke were the only major candidates running in Saturday's Senate election after state Sen. Ben Bagert dropped out. Bagert, the Republican candidate who had his party's endorsement, quit the race last week after running a poor third in opinion polls. Bagert said he wanted to throw his support to the Democrat, Johnston, in order to lessen the chances that Duke would force Johnston into a runoff. Under the state's open primary system, candidates compete in one primary regardless of party and a runoff is held between the top two finishers only if no one receives 50 percent of the vote. In the 1987 gubernatorial election, Roemer led a field of five major candidates with slightly more than a third of the vote. He won the governor's race by default when incumbent Edwin Edwards conceded the runoff. Duke won a special election for a Louisiana House seat in 1989. He previously ran for the state Senate and as the Populist Party candidate for president in 1988. ``He's been a very ineffective member of the Legislature and I say that with as much kindness as my honesty would permit me,'' Roemer said. ``Very ineffective. I would expect that to continue.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Expects Small Crowd for Discovery's Wednesday Landing
With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Between 5,000 and 10,000 spectators are expected to watch the shuttle Discovery land in the Mojave Desert this week, NASA said Monday. Discovery is scheduled to touch down on concrete Runway 22 on Rogers Dry Lake at 6:58 a.m. PDT Wednesday, said Don Haley, National Aeronautics and Space Administration spokesman. Good weather wa The main purpose of the four-day flight was to launch the sun-exploring Ulysses spacecraft. The probe was successfully deployed on Saturday. A record 500,000 spectatorss expected. watched Columbia land at this desert military base on July 4, 1982. Not counting the tightly restricted crowds allowed to watch landings of secret military flights, the smallest crowd to show up for a landing was last Jan. 10, when 2,200 people watched Columbia touch down, Haley said. ``I think flights with the shuttle are becoming a little more routine with the American public,'' he added. Haley said Discovery will land on a 15,000-foot, paved runway instead of an unpaved strip because NASA wants to test how well the shuttle's brakes work on concrete. Such tests are a prelude to eventual landings at the shuttle's launch site at Cape Canaveral, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Official Predicts Pact by Mid-1991
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's deputy prime minister, Romualdas Ozolas, predicted Monday that Soviet officials will recognize Lithuanian independence by mid-1991, following negotiations that began at the Kremlin last week, Tass reported. Lithuanian declared independence from the Soviet Union on March 11. The official news agency quoted Ozolas as describing the talks as productive and saying that if the negotiations continue as planned, they will ``end with the signing of a treaty recognizing the Lithuanian republic.'' ``I believe this will happen no later than in the first half of 1991.'' Lithuanian and Soviet officials agreed after their initial meetings to conduct their economic and trade relations for 1991 as equal partners. A communique issued later also mentioned preparations for future ``negotiations.'' That is a significant concession by the Soviet side, because President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has maintained that bilateral ``negotiations'' can occur only between two nations and not between the Kremlin and a republic. The talks were the first at such a high level since Lithuania suspended its declaration of independence following the Kremlin's economic embargo against the republic. Tass also said a joint Soviet-Lithuanian working group would begin meeting Wednesday at the Kremlin to set a date and lay the foundation for future negotiations. Ozolas and Soviet Deputy Prime Minister Vitaly Doguzhiyev will head the group.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives See Pictures of Bodies at Air Bombing Inquiry
DOC.TEXT: Grim-faced relatives, one in tears, saw photographs Monday of the muddy, human-shaped indentations made in grassy fields by bodies plummeting from the wreckage of bombed Pan Am Flight 103. Police photographs showed wreckage from the Boeing 747 imbedded in homes and strewn across fields and forests over 845 square miles of southern Scotland and northern England. There were pictures of bodies, but Scotland's senior law officer, Lord Fraser, the Lord Advocate, barred them from being shown to the first public inquiry into the crash because they would distress the reatives. The pictures were briefly described instead. For Betty Thomas of Wales, who lost her daughter and granddaughter, one glimpse of ``a leg or an arm,'' shown by mistake for a moment, was enough. She said she didn't look at the rest. Tears streamed down the cheeks of Marina de Larracoechea, sister of Pan Am flight attendant Maria Nieves Larrachoechea of Spain. Her sister was one of the 270 people who died when a terrorist bomb blew the New York-bound plane apart over Lockerbie on Dec. 21, 1988. ``It got me upset,'' Ms. Larracoechea said later. ``It was the most thorough run-through of Lockerbie - to realize how the ground was covered with debris . . . the tremendous waste of lives.'' She said she was grateful pictures of the bodies weren't shown. Just looking at the wreckage, she said, ``I know how maimed they were, how blown to pieces.'' The bodies of 17 victims were never found and two bodies and 658 bags of human remains were never identified, said John Boyd, chief constable of Dumfries and Galloway region at the time of the crash and now inspector of constabulary for Scotland. Aerial photos showed indentations of bodies in fields. One closeup showed the outlines of a victim, his torso and outspread legs etched in mud. The photographs showed the huge crater on Sherwood Crescent, at the edge of the main A74 highway from England to Scotland. The fuel-laden wing section exploded there, damaging or destroying 20 houses and vaporizing some victims. There were also photos of parts of the plane, of debris hanging in trees, and lines of searchers looking for victims. Boyd read large sections of his report on the police emergency response into the record and was questioned by Fraser. The inquiry, expected to last three months, is focusing on the causes of death and ways to prevent a similar disaster, not on criminal responsibility. Boyd said Scottish police investigators went to Helsinki, Finland, in January 1989 to investigate a warning telephoned to the U.S. Embassy there Dec. 5 that a bomb would be carried on a Pan American World Airways flight from Frankfurt in the following two weeks. ``There was no evidence to connect the Helsinki warning with the Lockerbie incident,'' he said. Under cross-examination, Boyd said the warning mentioned a particular person who was investigated, and said he still believed no connection existed. He agreed that other, unspecified warnings were made to embassies in Helsinki in 1988 in what appeared to be a ``personal vendetta against a named individual.'' New York attorney Stephen Pounian, representing the families of American victims, tried to ask Boyd if police had information on a warning to Pan Am about a Toshiba radio. Fraser leaped to his feet and protested, saying that went to ``the core'' of the criminal investigation. Police have said the bomb, hidden in a Toshiba radiocassette recorder in a suitcase, probably was put aboard Flight 103 in Frankfurt. The flight changed from a Boeing 727 to a Boeing 747 at London's Heathrow Airport. Scottish officials have said they were investigating several radical Palestinian groups. Fraser has said he was convinced the bombers would be caught.

DOC.HEAD: Snowstorm Dumps 10 Inches on Cheyenne, Whitens Colorado Ski Areas
DOC.TEXT: A surprise weekend snowstorm thrilled Colorado ski resort operators and left Cheyenne yards littered with tree limbs that snapped under the weight of wet snow. The storm, which struck southeast Wyoming late Saturday and eastern Colorado the next day, dumped 10 inches of snow here. The mountains of northern Utah and parts of western Nebraska also got snow over the weekend. The National Weather Service said a record 7.9 inches fell here Sunday, nearly doubling the old record for the date. The snow continued until early Monday. Colorado authorities blamed the storm for a power outage in Fort Collins and a small-plane crash near Aurora. Tree surgeons here were swamped with calls Monday. Tera Soule of Wyoming Tree Surgery, Inc. said the storm caused the most damage she's seen in eight years. ``I would say yesterday I had two dozen phone calls and today I've had about 65 phone calls,'' she said. ``This is just tremendous. This is the worst one since we've been in business.'' Terry Smith, general manager of Year-Round Landscapes, said the storm generated about two weeks of work for his company. He estimated the tree damage at more than $50,000. Ski resort operators were thrilled. Betsey Farney of Vail Associates said Vail mountain reported 10 inches of snow, Breckenridge reported nearly a foot and Aspen had 13 inches. The National Weather Service said the Mary Jane ski resort near Winter Park reported 8 inches of snow, Loveland reported 7.5 inches and Winter Park got up to 6 inches. Colorado's ski season officially opens after Thanksgiving. The National Weather Service forecast more snow for southeastern Colorado. About 5,000 Fort Collins residents were without power Sunday night, authorities said. Power was restored to most customers by late Monday morning. Meanwhile, a Denver-area man was hospitalized in serious condition Monday at Aurora Presbyterian Hospital after his plane crashed about one-quarter mile from Buckley Air National Guard base near Aurora. ``It appears he iced up pretty bad,'' Arapahoe County Sheriff's Lt. Tom Kirby said. By sunrise Monday, four to six inches of snow had fallen in parts of western Nebraska, the weather service said.

DOC.HEAD: Security Force Oversee Voting for Iranian Religious Council
LaserPhoto TEH3
DOC.TEXT: Iranian security forces Monday watched for possible election disruptions by anti-Western fundamentalists blocked from running for a panel that picks the country's spiritual leader, diplomatic sources said. Ayatollah Ali Khamenei was among the first to cast ballots in an election some fundamentalists allege was rigged to keep them off the 83-member Assembly of Experts and preserve Khamenei's power. Khamenei, who favors improved relations with the West, was named in June 1989 to succeed Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini a few days after the revolutionary patriarch died of cancer. Sources said the hard-liners sought enough seats to depose Khamenei in favor of a council. A rule change by Khamenei, however, forced many of the fundamentalists out of the race. There were no incidents of violence reported in the election, but there were conflicting observations on voter turnout. Diplomatic sources in Tehran said there was a light turnout. But the state Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said voting was extended up to three hours in 20 of Iran's 24 provinces because of ``heavy turnout.'' There was no immediate word on when the results of the voting for 100 candidates would be announced. But initial results are likely to be known Tuesday. Among those voting were former prisoners-of-war recently released by Iraq, which waged an eight-year war against Iran, the news agency reported. Anyone over 15 years old can vote in Iran, which has an estimated electorate of 25 million. Prior to the election, Khamenei ordered his allies on the Council of Guardians, a constitutional watchdog body, to require all candidates to pass an examination on Islamic jurisprudence. Of 169 would-be candidates who sat for the exam, 60 flunked, including Parliament Speaker Mehdi Karrubi and many other hard-liners, sources said. Some radicals refused to submit to the examination. Others who passed withdrew their names in protest. Khamenei and President Hashemi Rafsanjani are leaders of Iran's so-called pragmatists, which favor better ties with the West and seek foreign investment to revive Iran's economy following the 1980-88 war with Iraq. The Assembly of Experts sits for an eight-year term. The conflict over the balloting has strained relations between the rival factions and exposed the long-running power struggle in Tehran's hierarchy. Fistfights took place in the radical-dominated, 270-member Majlis, or parliament, during a debate on the elections last week, sources in Tehran reported. The official media has not reported the brawl, but in a speech broadcast by Tehran Radio on Monday, Khamenei admitted there had been sharp differences in parliament. ``Two brothers in the Islamic Republic have a verbal exchange over an issue, which is a normal thing ... and see what a ruckus the foreign media raises.'' Diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said radicals attempted to meet twice last week at Tehran University, apparently to organize protests. But both gatherings were broken up by security forces. Iran's largest opposition group, the Iraq-based Mujahedeen Khalq, or People's Holy Warriors, said two divisions of the Revolutionary Guards Corps were deployed in Tehran to prevent any radical backlash. That report could not be independently confirmed. But an Asian diplomat, speaking by telephone from Tehran, said security forces were watching for any demonstrations. The radicals, led by former interior minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, have been on the defensive since Khomeini's death and fear a purge by Rafsanjani. Rafsanjani has replaced many hard-liners in ministry posts with Western-educated officials. He has also gained a tighter grip on the judiciary. Radicals suffered a further blow last month when Tehran resumed relations with Britain after a 19-month break.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Chosen in Assault Trial of Student-Slayings Suspect
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Judge Yawn, Elna Hlavaty cq
DOC.TEXT: A jury was selected Monday in the assault case of Edward Lewis Humphrey, a suspect in the slayings of five college students in Gainesville, who is accused of the unrelated beating of his grandmother. In the assault case, six jurors and two alternates were seated late Monday afternoon out of a pool of 20 potential jurors. Most of those in the pool said they were aware Humphrey has been the focus of intense scrutiny by the police task force investigating the unrelated slayings in August. ``This is the kind of case that generally would not see the courthouse or courtroom if it was anyone other than Ed Humphrey,'' said public defender J.R. Russo. Opening arguments were set to begin Tuesday. If convicted of the charge of battery of a person over 65 years old, Humphrey faces a minimum of 3 years in prison. Most of the potential jurors had said they wouldn't let news reports cloud their judgment, but at least one was excused by Circuit Judge Theron A. Yawn Jr. after commenting on the assault charges. ``I get upset by people who beat up women,'' Willard Bronson said before he was dismissed. Another woman was dismissed for cause after she said she would have to be convinced of Humphrey's innocence, rather than his guilt. Humphrey has been in the Brevard County jail in nearby Sharpes since Aug. 30, held on $1 million bond in the assault case. He hasn't been charged in connection with the Gainesville stabbing deaths. He has not been charged in connection with the stabbings of four female students and one male student in Gainesville. Police say he is one of several suspects in the case, and have made widely reported searches of his home. Defense and prosecution attorneys asked potential jurors what they had read, heard or seen about the Gainesville case. One potential juror, elementary school teacher Phyllis Guarino, said she was aware that Humphrey was charged here with beating his grandmother, 79-year-old Elna Hlavaty. She also had heard he has been named as a suspect in the late-August slayings in Gainesville. ``I don't know which is true,'' she said. ``(Even) if he didn't do it, he's a very sick boy.'' At the noon recess, Mrs. Hlavaty repeated earlier statements that her grandson is innocent. She added that she couldn't understand why the case is being tried when she asked that the charges be dropped. ``The state's attorney has harassed me and my family so terribly that they should be in a cell,'' she said. ``He sure did not hit me, and he knows that he did not hit me.'' Humphrey started the fall semester at the University of Florida in Gainesville on Aug. 25, the day before a three-day series of discoveries of the bodies. He was arrested five days later when he walked into his grandmother's Indialantic home in the early morning hours and, according to police reports, yelled, ``You are going to hell and you are going to die.'' He began choking her and pummeling her face, according to a sheriff's report. ``I hit her and I'm sorry,'' he reportedly told deputies who were called to the home by his mother. The grandmother was treated for broken facial bones and a swollen eye. She later said she'd hurt herself in a fall. Since he has been in jail, Humphrey has been charged with two more crimes, a 1988 attempted rape and burglary in Indian River County and the Aug. 25 assault on two male students at the University of Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov vs. Karpov: War of Minds Begins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be updated with conclusion of day's play. If there isn't a winner by 10:30 p.m. EDT, play is suspended until the following day.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: World chess champion Garry Kasparov's defense of his title against blood rival Anatoly Karpov is a $3 million war of personalities, politics and playing styles. The two went head to head Monday night at the Hudson Theatre in Manhattan, where some 700 seats for the opening match were sold out -at $25, $50 and $100 each. The first match of the championship began at 5:30 p.m. Kasparov, 27, ended Karpov's 10-year world chess reign in 1985. Now, Karpov, 39, is trying to wrest the title back as the nemeses meet for the first time in three years. It is the first world championship in the United States since 1907. After the first 12 games are played in New York, 12 more will be played in Lyon, France, beginning Nov. 24. For the New York showdown, the theater is hung with the flags of the United States, France and the Soviet Union, home country of both players. Above the stage is a 10-foot screen bearing the image of a chess board. When Kasparov or Karpov makes a move, the pieces on the screen move, too, for the audience's benefit. Two video screens show close-ups of the players. The computerized chess board will record every move they make. The board is atop a stark, black table, with two name tags pasted on the front. One, labeled ``A. Karpov,'' depicts the Soviet flag. Next to the table is Karpov's black, high-backed easy chair, which swivels and rolls. On the opposite side is a black, low-backed, office-style chair. That side is labeled ``G. Kasparov,'' with a depiction of the flag of the Russian Republic. Kasparov, founder of a Soviet democratic party, declared last week he was playing under the flag of the republic rather than the Soviet Union as a political statement. Karpov often has been quoted as saying, ``I have two loves: communism and chess.'' ``Normally, chess is a battle between two individuals: a brutal, intellectual battle,'' Kasparov said earlier. ``But in my case, with Karpov, it's a fight between two different mentalities in Russia. I identify him with the system I've been fighting.'' Years ago, a chess analyst likened Kasparov's agile, bold style to the dancer Mikhail Baryshnikov, and Karpov's methodical, rigid style to former Soviet Premier Leonid Brezhnev. The two are as different in personality as they are in political leanings. Kasparov, who beat ``Deep Thought,'' a chess-playing computer, in New York last January, is confident, flamboyant and fluent in English - a media darling who tirelessly publicizes chess. The media have often described Karpov as cool or even cold: an introvert who plays with surgical precision and tunes out the audience. But he was personable at a news conference last Tuesday, hamming it up and presenting a copy of his book to Kasparov. The first championship between the two, in 1984, was abruptly helted by the World Chess Federation president after Karpov lost two games in a row. In a controversial move, the World Chess Federation permitted Karpov to retain the title although the match wasn't completed. Kasparov won their 1985 rematch, becoming the youngest champion ever. He successfully defended the title against Karpov in 1986. In 1987, their championship match ended in a tie and Kasparov retained his title under the match rules. This time, the winner will receive $1.7 million and the loser will get $1.3 million. Kasparov aid his earnings will fund ``my private interests and the political interests of the world.'' Karpov has talked about helping Chernobyl victims and promoting chess in schools.

DOC.HEAD: Kid Reporters Get First Interview With Retired Justice
DOC.TEXT: A group of young reporters scored a journalistic coup by interviewing retired U.S. Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr., who told them he was not sure he could ``fully agree'' with the choice of his successor. After suffering a stroke, Brennan retired in July under doctor's orders to reduce his workload and decline all interviews until at least next year. But five reporters and editors from the Indianapolis Children's Express bureau spent 30 minutes last month interviewing the 84-year-old Brennan, the most powerful liberal voice on an increasingly conservative court. Their interview was published in Monday's Indianapolis Star. The team peppered Brennan with questions about children's rights, abortion, drug testing, the death penalty for minors and the mentally retarded, the Equal Rights Amendment and his replacement on the court, David H. Souter, who was confirmed last week. They said Brennan dodged most questions on the newest justice, but indicated he wasn't pleased with him. ``I could hope that the philosophy of the appointment was something with which I could fully agree, but I'm not sure that I can say that,'' Brennan said. ``It wasn't so much like we were scooping anybody. We were just talking,'' said Wendy Potasnik, 17. ``It was more like a conversation than an interview,'' agreed Lisa Schubert, 10. ``I mean, I'd ask him the same questions as if I'd ran into him one day.'' The interview was arranged with the help of Brennan's daughter, Nancy, who is a friend of Peter Sterling, president of The Children's Museum. The museum houses the Children's Express bureau, which publishes a one-page, weekly report in The Indianapolis Star on issues of interest to youngsters. The Children's Express organization has bureaus in several U.S. cities as well as Australia and New Zealand, said Lynn Sygiel, the adult who oversees the group's Indianapolis bureau. The New York-based organization used to publish a magazine but now syndicates its material, as well as publishing a newsletter for the children involved in the organization, she said. Brennan gave the children a warm welcome at his office in the Supreme Court building in Washington. The Sept. 28 session ended with Brennan dressed in a bright red Children's Express sweatshirt and mugging for a camera. Before interviewing Brennan, the young reporters carefully researched his 34-year tenure on the bench. Ms. Sygiel said the team met twice a week for six weeks reviewing newspaper and magazine articles on Brennan and some of the more than 1,200 opinions he wrote. After the interview, the Express team said Brennan's diminutive stature and informal air surprised them. Kia Woodson, 11, said she expected to hear long, windy answers laced with legal jargon. Instead the group got brief responses, which they characterized as evasive and talking down to them. Despite the short answers, the young journalists felt they gained something positive from the experience. ``Brennan has done so much in the last 34 years, seeing him, it doesn't make me understand the Constitution, but it makes me understand why it's the way it is,'' said Rob Merrill, 15.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Protest Intelligence Service
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people protesting secret intelligence operations in a united Germany gathered Monday in Leipzig, the cradle of last year's East German pro-democracy movement. The German news agency ADN said the protest against the demonstration occurred following evening prayers in the St. Nicolas Church in central Leipzig, about 70 miles southwest of Berlin. Some of the protests specifically targeted the BND, the former West German intelligence agency that now oversees the unified country. One of the banners held by the demonstrators said, ``A democratic state needs no secret service.'' The protesters included some who held vigils last year in front of the headquarters of the former East German secret police, known as the Stasi. On Oct. 9, 1989, about 70,000 people took part on the first of what became known as the ``Monday demonstrations.'' Civic groups in East Germany had demanded only citizens from that country be allowed access to some of the 6 million files collected by the former Communist rulers. But federal investigators began combing the headquarters of the Stasi just three days after unity on Oct. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Cold And Snow In Mountains, Rain In South-Central
DOC.TEXT: A weather system spread rain across the south-central part of the nation Monday after dumping snow on the western Plains and Rockies, and temperatures fell to record freezing lows in the north. Showers and thunderstorms extended across western Arkansas, eastern and central Oklahoma, and parts of Texas during the afternoon. Heavier rainfall for the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.17 inches at McAlester, Okla., and 0.78 of an inch at Pine Bluff, Ark. Light rain and drizzle prevailed from the central Plains to the upper Great Lakes. Light snow fell across parts of the central high Plains region after a weekend in which up to 13 inches fell at Colorado's Vail ski area. A record 7.9 inches fell Sunday at Cheyenne, Wyo., nearly doubling the old record for the date.
