The snow continued until early Monday for a weekend total of 10 inches, the National Weather Service said. Snow also fell on parts of western Nebraska, with up to 6 inches at Scottsbluff. Elsewhere, a few showers and thunderstorms were over the Florida Peninsula and a few showers and thunderstorms moved over Tennessee and northern Mississippi. Brisk Santa Ana wind prevailed across southern California and along the southern California coast, with gusts to 35 mph at Ontario and to 37 mph at Needles. Temperatures were in the 80s across the Gulf Coast and the desert Southwest, with readings above 90 over parts of Texas. And temperatures were in the 70s and 80s along the Atlantic seaboard as far north as southern New England. But much colder weather prevailed from the northern and central Plains to the upper Great Lakes, where afternoon temperatures were only in the 30s and 40s, and in parts of the West where readings were only in the 40s and 50s. Overnight readings dipped below 32 degrees in the Great Basin of Nevada and western Utah and the Rockis, in the central high Plains region, and from the northern high Plains to Upper Michigan. Bismarck, N.D., tied its record low of 15, set in 1895; International Falls, Minn., hit a record 21; Pocatello, Idaho, hit a record 21; and Winnemucca, Nev., tied its record of 16. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 7 above zero at West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Redskins Wary of Key Contests Against Giants
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Redskins aren't trying to downplay the importance of their first meeting this season with the New York Gaints. ``This is our biggest test of the season, a huge game as far as confidence for us,'' guard Mark Schlereth said as the Redskins returned to practice Monday after their one-week bye. ``They're 4-0 and we've been on a roll,'' said defensive end Fred Stokes. ``Everything the fans and the media say about this being a big game is true.'' The Giants, who play at Washington this Sunday, have beaten the Redskins in seven of the last eight strike games and have won the last four by a total of 14 points. The Redskins haven't been to the playoffs since the last time they beat the Giants, in 1987, and their 3-1 record puts them once again behind New York in the NFC Eastern Division standings. The Redskins play the Giants twice in the next three weeks. Their two games against Philadelphia come up in the next month, too, giving Washington four games against the top two division contenders in a five-week span. ``It's going to be a challenge,'' said quarterback Stan Humphries, who will be starting only his second NFL game Sunday at RFK Stadium. ``It's probably going to be the biggest challenge I've ever had.'' A sign of the importance the Redskins place on the game was the intensity around their training facility Monday. In security reminiscent of the old George Allen era, a couple of aides patrolled fences next to woods surrounding the practice field and one shooed away some families who peeked through holes in the fence. The Redskins' frustration the last two years have been crystalized in their losses to the Giants. Last year, Raul Allegre kicked a 52-yard field goal as time expired to beat them 27-24 in Washington and Phil Simms threw a couple of fourth-quarter touchdown passes to win the second game 20-17. In these days of run-and-shoot offenses, the Redskins and Giants both play physical defense and preach ball control on offense. ``It's always a classic,'' said defensive tackle Darryl Grant, ``a knock-down, drag-out brawl, two fighters in the ring going for it.'' ``If you're going to win the conference you have to beat the Giants and the Eagles,'' said Schlereth. ``We haven't beaten them in the last two years. You don't want to start losing too many in a row or it starts to be a jinx.'' The Redskins' success at grinding out 179 yards rushing against Phoenix - after depending on wide-open passing formations in the first three games - may have been a dress rehearsal for the New York game. The Giants have used their methodical offense to hold the ball an average of more than 10 minutes longer than their opponents. ``We're going to have to try to keep our defense off the field,'' said Humphries, who enters the game with only 48 career pass attempts. ``It's tough against them when you don't control the ball. ``They try to stop the longer throws and make you pick your way down the field. If you drive, you have to have 11 or 12 good plays in a row,'' said Humphries. That could mean 11 or 12 plays in a row against Lawrence Taylor and the strong Giant defense. ``There's so many things you can't do with him that you would normally do with a regular outside linebacker,'' said coach Joe Gibbs. ``They have two great backers and that allows their secondary to play soft and not take chances. You can't run on them and their secondary takes away the big play.'' Gibbs was preparing his team after a weekend off and only light practices last week. ``It's hard for me to judge'' the effect of the layoff, said Gibbs. ``I don't think we'll know until we get in a game.''

DOC.HEAD: Souter Takes Preliminary Oath, Becomes Justice Tuesday
DOC.NOTE: EDs: TOPS with 15 grafs; one graf rewritten for transition; picks up 5th graf, now 17th graf: ``His working,''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX23
DOC.TEXT: David H. Souter, a day away from becoming history's 105th Supreme Court justice, swore Monday to uphold the Constitution and pass it on to future generations ``in as vigorous condition as I have received it.'' Souter, a 51-year-old judge from New Hampshire, took the oath in a brief White House ceremony in which President Bush praised his first nominee to the high court as ``a very thoughtful and caring man.'' Bush, alluding to the budget crisis that has trimmed federal services and threatened to shut down the government, invited guests to attend a bare-bones reception afterward. The impasse has caused a shutdown of all but ``essential'' government services, reducing the White House staff to about one-sixth its normal size. Joking that a Spartan gathering might appeal to Souter's Yankee upbringing in New Hampshire, the president said it would be ``reception without a lot of largesse.'' Souter's oath-taking was a preliminary step. He will not become a justice until he is sworn in Tuesday morning in a separate ceremony at the Supreme Court. The oath, administered by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, is one all federal employees must take. The chief justice will administer a second oath, taken by all federal judges, in Tuesday's Supreme Court ceremony. After receiving a warm, standing ovation from those in the White House East Room, Souter demonstrated the soft-spoken humility that helped him win easy Senate confirmation. He recounted how 11 weeks ago when Bush nominated him he was practically in a state of shock. The president and Mrs. Bush offered him a drink to revive his flagging spirits and then Bush telephoned Souter's mother in New Hampshire, Souter said. The justice-to-be recalled how Bush told Souter's mother,``I want you to know he's OK. We'll look after him.'' ``That epitomizes why my sense of gratitude goes beyond anything that could be called official,'' Souter said. Monday's ceremony was notable for the praise showered on Justice William J. Brennan, whose retirement in July opened the way for Souter's nomination. Brennan sat in the front row facing Bush as the president described him as ``one of the most personally beloved and respected members of the court.'' Brennan often has been reviled by conservatives as a ymbol of liberal judicial activism. But Souter said Monday he hopes to pass on the Constituion ``in as vigorous condition as I have received it this afternoon, as it were, from Justice Brennan.'' In the Supreme Court's ornate courtroom Tuesday, Souter was to pledge to ``do equal right to the poor and to the rich.'' His working career at the court was to start soon thereafter, when the justices were to begin the 1990-91 term's second week of hearing arguments in cases to be decided by July. Souter is expected to move the court further to the right. Brennan, on the court for 34 years, was its leading liberal. Souter, in a recent interview with The Boston Globe, described himself as ``a moderate conservative.'' ```I wouldn't ... put myself smack in the middle ... closer to the center than some but still on the right side,'' Souter was quoted as saying. He joins a court deeply divided over such contentious issues as abortion, affirmative action and church-state relations. In three days of testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Souter divulged little about his views on such issues, but the Senate confirmed him by a 90-9 vote anyway. In an interview with The Associated Press last week, Souter said the court's members were eager for him to join them to avoid the possibility of tied votes in controversial cases. ``They very much wanted me to start sitting on Tuesday because there is always the possibility of a 4-4 decision if they're sitting without the full complement,'' Souter said. ``The difficulty with that is if the case has to be reargued, everybody knows that the whole reargument is going to be addressed to the one judge who is sort of there to make the difference.'' Before being named a federal appeals court judge by Bush earlier this year, Souter spent seven years as a member of the New Hampshire Supreme Court. He previously had served as a trial judge and as his state's attorney general. At last report, Souter had not yet found a place to live in the nation's capital. But Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., was helping him look for a home he could rent. Souter also does not yet have a permanent staff, having been assigned only a temporary secretary and a temporary messenger. Each justice is allowed four law clerks, two secretaries and a messenger. Souter said earlier he hoped to select his law clerks by next week. His suite of offices is waiting for him - those Justice Antonin Scalia recently gave up when he moved into Brennan's old chambers. The gold-plated name put on the door days ago says ``Justice Souter'' but court officials, seemingly not willing to rush things, elected to keep the nameplate covered with adhesive paper until Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Coast Guard Boards Greenpeace Ship off Nuclear Test Site
DOC.TEXT: A Greenpeace ship in Barents Sea off the Novaya Zemlya islands was stopped and boarded by the Soviet coast guard after it sent environmentalists ashore to a nuclear test site. According to activists and Soviet officials, KGB border guards aboard an icebreaker fired several warning shots to deter the Dutch-registered MV Greenpeace in the two-island group in the arctic about 370 miles from Norway. The islands were a primary Soviet nuclear test site from 1958 to 1963. Environmentalists claim it was last used in 1988. Recent protests forced the Soviets to suspend tests at their main site in Soviet Central Asia, rekindling interest in Novaya Zemlya. The Greenpeace vessel was detained for ``deliberate violation of the state border of the U.S.S.R., failure to obey border authorities, landing people at unpermitted places and an attempt to enter an area closed to navigation,'' Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said at a briefing. Before communications with the ship were lost, Greenpeace activist Steve Shallhorn said about 15 guards boarded the 190-foot vessel after the protesters sent four members ashore in rubber rafts. He said the icebreaker threatened to open fire on the Greenpeace ship. Greenpeace said the activists reached the island in the dark while others in two decoy rafts distracted the icebreaker crew. The environmental group claims new nuclear tests are planned on Novaya Zemlya, and they intended to demonstrate there. The activists put three boats in the water with crew members inside, the statement said. It did not say what happened to them. The weather was very bad with heavy seas when the icebreaker, named the 26th Congress of the Communist Party, detained the Greenpeace ship, the statement said. It said the MV Greenpeace will be escorted to the Kola Gulf, where an investigation of the border violation will be conducted. Shannon Fagan of Greenpeace in London said the group was told by the Soviet government that a warship would be sent to tow the vessel to a Soviet port if it did not leave the area under its own power. ``We are not planning to leave,'' she said. Shallhorn said from Oslo, Norway, the ship was about four miles from the island when the rubber rafts were dispatched. ``We don't know if they are aware that our party went ashore. We are going to try to stay in the area until we get our landing party back, which could take a couple days,'' he said. The MV Greenpeace, with 38 Western activists and six Soviets aboard, had permission to tour the Soviet arctic, Greenpeace said.

DOC.HEAD: Truck Overturns, Killing 25 in Southern Peru
DOC.TEXT: A truck filled with religious pilgrims overturned on the PanAmerican Highway, killing 25 passengers and seriously injuring two others, police said Monday. The accident, which took place 215 miles southeast of Lima, occurred Sunday night, police said. Police quoted survivors as saying the truck careened off the highway when the driver was apparently blinded by the headlights of an oncoming car. The truck was carrying pilgrims returning to Nazca, an archaelogical desert site, from the Virgin of Yauca religious festival in Yauca, a city about 60 miles south of Nazca. The portion of the highway between the two cities twists through the arid foothills of the Andes and edges past deep ravines. Police were unable to confirm how many survived the accident.

DOC.HEAD: `The Discovery Chorus' Beams Down Special Birthday Greeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after the 5th graf pvs, `The $250...,' to update with status of Ulysses, Subs the 13th, ``After the performance,'' with 2 grafs to delete redundant first reference to Thornton and update with family reaction to tape.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTN3
DOC.TEXT: Discovery's five astronauts enjoyed another quiet but productive day in space Monday, conducting experiments and beaming down a special birthday greeting to a crew member's wife. The men - calling themselves ``The Discovery Chorus'' - sang ``Happy Birthday'' to Kaye Akers, wife of astronaut Tom Akers, who turned 34 Monday. They floated in front of a shuttle TV camera during the short serenade. Discovery put NASA back in the space flight business when it lifted off Saturday on the first shuttle mission in nearly half a year. The launch ended the fleet's second-longest grounding ever and was topped several hours later by the successful deployment of the sun probe Ulysses. Ulysses continued to streak through the solar system Monday on its way to Jupiter. The giant planet will provide a gravity assist and push the satellite into an orbit over the sun's unexplored poles. The $250 million European spacecraft is expected to pass over the sun's south pole in 1994 and the north pole in 1995. Mission Control's Kathy Thornton informed the crew before they went to sleep that Ulysses still was doing ``great - no changes.'' After months of trouble on just about all fronts, NASA officials said they were delighted to have such a smooth flight. Flight director Ron Dittemore described it as one of the ``cleanest'' shuttle missions ever. ``The greatest pleasure comes when you work a flight and everything goes perfectly nominal,'' Dittemore said. ``Hopefully, we're getting better every time we go.'' Discovery is scheduled to land Wednesday morning at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Before bursting into song with his crew Monday, Discovery's commander, Richard N. Richards, referred to Sunday's experiment involving a small, controlled fire aboard the shuttle. Akers conducted the test. ``We don't have a birthday cake on board,'' Richards said in the broadcast to Mrs. Akers. ``NASA doesn't let us start fires except for Tom. He's the only one who's been able to start an authorized fire.'' ``We don't have any other fires on board, so we had to come up with something special here for you, Kaye. This is one of the fine bakery products provided by the NASA bakery,'' Richards said. A plastic stick that reflects light, poked into a piece of space-issue bakery goods, mimicked a candle on a cake. After the performance, Thornton told the men: ``I don't think the New Kids in Space are going to replace the New Kids on the Block as the teen heartthrobs, but we appreciate it anyway.'' NASA invited Mrs. Akers and other crew members' relatives to see the tape Monday afteroon at Mission Control in Houston. After viewing the tape and another one showing the astronauts eating dinner and relaxing at the end of their work day, the families sent up this message: ``You guys are really getting good at throwing unusual birthday parties. How in the world are you going to top this one next year?'' Earlier Monday, the mood aboard the shuttle was less lively. Astronauts Bruce Melnick and Bill Shepherd began another test of an experimental system using voice commands to control TV cameras. Shepherd reported better success than he had on Sunday, but said the system is still missing many of the voice commands. He said he would readjust his microphone for the system's third and final test on Tuesday. On the ground, NASA was busy preparing for the next shuttle flight. The grounded Columbia was moved Monday from one launch pad to the other so Atlantis can be transported from the hangar to the vacated pad later this week. Atlantis is scheduled to lift off on a secret military mission in early November. NASA officials said they expect the launch to be delayed only a day or so by damage caused by a metal beam that was left inside the shuttle by workers last week.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Threatens Retaliation for Jerusalem Shootings
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's ruling party on Monday threatened to retaliate after Israeli police shot and killed at least 19 Palestinians in a clash in Jerusalem. ``This vicious crime will not go without retaliation, and the Arab nation is certainly capable to retaliate and it will,'' said Al-Thawra, the official newspaper of Iraq's Arab Baath Socialist Party. In an editorial for Tuesday's paper, obtained by The Associated Press on Monday, Al-Thawra described the killings as ``a massacre that has been made possible with American aid and support to Israel.'' ``It will turn into a massive wave of indignation, which will take the pan-Arab struggle a step toward the liberation of Jerusalem and all other holy places and claim the Arab homeland from treachery and occupation,'' the editorial said. Iraq has claimed Saudi Arabia has desecrated Islam's holiest shrines at Mecca and Medina by allowing the U.S.-led multinational force on Saudi territory, in reaction to the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2 of Kuwait. Israeli Police Minister Roni Milo said 19 people died and 140 were injured in Israel's bloodiest rioting in 23 years. Witnesses said the clash erupted after Palestinians threw stones from the Temple Mount on Jews worshiping below at the Western Wall, Judaism's holiest site. The Temple Mount is home of the al-Aqsa Mosque, Islam's third holiest site. ``Where is the international legality, which Washington has always said that it is keen to implement?'' the paper asked. ``The racist massacre in Al Aqsa mosque reveals that the national legality has always been an instrument by the United States to impose its hegemony and not to be used in defense of the people who fight racism and fascism.''

DOC.HEAD: Some Parks Closed, Others Open With No One To Collect Fees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after the 13th, ``Tourists also...,'' to update with crowds at Antietam following PBS Civil War series.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Visitors got in free Monday at the Grand Canyon and some other national parks because there was no one at the gates to collect fees, and some Coast Guardsmen were told to stay ashore to save fuel. Many other national parks and monuments were closed or without services, however, as non-essential federal workers stayed home because the government didn't have authority to pay them. If the impasse on Capitol Hill weren't resolved, the full impact of the shutdowns would hit Tuesday, when federal offices reopen after the three-day Columbus Day weekend. Most of the 2.4 million federal workers were told to report to work Tuesday, but without a budget agreement most would likely be sent home soon afterward. Richard Darman, the White House budget director, said workers performing services needed to ``protect life and property'' would stay on the job, but even some of those federal employees saw changes. The Coast Guard station in Michigan City, Ind., on the shore of Lake Michigan, reported it was ordered to save fuel by stopping its daily training maneuvers. FBI agents were told late last week that as many as half of the 400 employees in the Chicago office could be furloughed on Thursday, Friday and Oct. 15. ``We will have agents available for kidnappings, hostage situations, bank robberies - emergency situations,'' said FBI spokesman Robert Long. ``This could hurt some of our long-term investigations, though.'' Locked gates at the Vicksburg National Military Park in Mississippi angered tourists. ``I'm going home to vote against my congressman,'' said Bobby Denton, 52, of Jena, La. Services at Grand Canyon National Park were cut back to the most critical, and even the switchboard was shut down. But the main gate remained open Monday, so visitors got in without paying the usual $10 per car or $5 per person fees. ``We got a lot of questions asking what was open and what services there were. But for the people who visited, it was a good deal, because they got in free,'' said William Bohannon, general manager of the privately operated Grand Canyon National Park Lodges on the canyon's South Rim. Tourists also got in free at Everglades National Park in Florida after ticket takers were sent home. About 3,500 tourists visited the Antietam National Battlefield at Sharspburg, Md., during the three-day weekend, many attracted by the recent Public Broadcasting Service series on the Civil War, only to find it closed. The crowd estimate was made Monday by park superintendent Richard Rambur, who was not working but made a brief stop at his office. ``Somebody is beating on my window now to use the bathroom.'' Tourists were ousted from visitors' centers and campgrounds in Great Smoky Mountains National Park in Tennessee. Privte campgrounds and hotels outside the park were jammed. But the campground and hotel managers and other merchants said they were afraid their windfall would be short-lived if the budget impasse isn't resolved. ``Obviously it's a disadvantage to us not to have the park open,'' said Randy Fiveash, executive director of the Gatlinburg Chamber of Commerce. The Eisenhower Library and home in Abilene, Kan., remained open. They are run by the National Archives and Records Administration, said director Richard Norton Smith. ``We're taking it one day at a time,'' he said. The Harry S. Truman Library in Independence, Mo., also wasn't immediately affected, said acting director George Curtis. ``Our instructions are to still be open to the public through Monday,'' Curtis said. Visitors to the Gateway Arch in St. Louis were turned away. Jerry Schober, superintendent of the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial, estimated Monday that the Arch had lost $15,000 to $20,000 in admission fees since it was closed Saturday. In the nation's capital, the Mall, normally swarming with tourists making their way through the Smithsonian Institution's museums and galleries, had just joggers, pigeons and a few out-of-town visitors. Trash littered the Mall because federal cleanup crews weren't working. ``I don't think it's a good representation for our country,'' said Ken Thomas of Baltimore, who took his mother-in-law, visiting from Germany, to Washington despite the shutdown. He said she was disgusted by the litter. Mike Podett of San Francisco, who had hoped to tour the Smithsonian museums on his vacation, said Congress and the White House were both to blame for his ruined trip. ``They're acting like a bunch of little children, saying, `It's my way or no way,' '' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Seeking Kitchen Porter Missing Since Bomb Found at Club
DOC.TEXT: Police said Monday they were seeking a 21-year-old employee of a London club who had been absent from work since the morning an IRA bomb was found at an anti-terrorism conference. Scotland Yard detectives said they wanted to question Gerrard McGarrigle of Belfast, who worked in the kitchen of the Royal Overseas League Club where the bomb was found and defused Sept. 27. ``He had been employed by the club for a year but was last seen on Sept. 27 when he left without giving notice,'' said a Scotland Yard spokesman who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``He has not returned to his London address and extensive inquiries have so far failed to trace him,'' he said. Robert Newell, general manager of the club, said McGarrigle had been thoroughly checked by a senior member of staff and had worked up until then without any problems. A television sound engineer happened to find the bomb under the speaker's lectern before the start of the one-day conference. It was timed to explode minutes after the conference opened and would probably have killed several people, police said. Later, the outlawed Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility for planting the bomb, saying it had been aimed at Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave. Waldegrave had been scheduled to speak first at the conference although his speech was switched to the afternoon at the last minute. The IRA, which has been fighting to end British rule in Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland, has recently escalated its attacks on the British mainland.

DOC.HEAD: Only Essential Workers to Stay - But Who's Essential?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-8 bgng: ``Sturdivant said,'' with 10 grafs to update
DOC.TEXT: There was still one chef per shift at the White House on Monday. The astronauts aboard Discovery were working overtime and government lawyers were preparing to argue before the Supreme Court. They're essential, unaffected by the government shutdown. In fact, many thousands of federal employees - ranging from meat inspectors to press secretaries to U.S. troops in the Middle East - remained on the job after government authorization to pay them expired Friday night. Most federal workers were off for the Columbus Day holiday on Monday and wouldn't know for sure until Tuesday morning whether their bosses considered them essential or not. Agency heads were spared hearing that ego-deflating or boosting news because they were making the decisions. ``It really gets to be nebulous,'' said John Sturdivant, president of the 700,000-member American Federation of Government Employees. ``Theoretically, you might have a person doing scheduling or answering the phone for a Cabinet secretary who is deemed essential, but then you could have some undersecretary who's doing policy and planning who is not.'' In general, federal workers were told to report to work Tuesday morning, then use about three hours for ``phase-down activities'' before going home - if they were ruled nonessential and if a budget agreement had not been reached to keep normal government operations going. Sturdivant said no one had ever pulled together figures on what percentage of the 2.4 million strong federal work force was considered essential. One official who declined to be identified by name or agency said the Office of Management and Budget had promulgated guidelines to the effect that normally only 15 percent of a civilian agency should be considered essential. This could not be confirmed immediately. Spokesmen for OMB were not in their offices. Fifteen percent would mean 360,000 people would stay on the job and about 2 million would be sent home. However, in past shutdowns only a few hundred thousand have gone home. Some departmental details were available Monday. For example, the Defense Department said all military and civilian operations related to Desert Shield, the deployment in the Persian Gulf, would be exempt. The Federal Aviation Administration said air traffic controllers would be working as usual. They are exempt, as are most of the 103,000 employees under the jurisdiction of the Department of Transportation, including those responsible for health and safety and uniformed members of the Coast Guard. Department officials said they expect about 20,000 workers to be sent home while most others won't be affected, either because they are paid out of non-appropriated funds or previously approved multi-year appropriations. A notable exception: Certain inspectors are not exempt and inspections of hazardous materials and pipelines would not take place. Rule making and contract writing also would stop, said Robert S. Marx, the department's director of public information. At the National Zoo, a spokeswoman said workers who feed the animals and clean up after them were essential. At the White House, a spokesman said 65 out of 383 employes would be classified as essential. They include all assistants to the president, Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater and his top aides, and the legislative staff working with Congress to resolve the budget impasse. The staff of 70 in the family living quarters at the White House was cut to 10, including one chef, one engineer and one maid per shift. The Marine guard who usually stands outside the door to the West Wing was absent from his post. But when Bush attended the wedding of his personnel chief, Chase Untermeyer, on Saturday, a low-ranking press aide was dispatched to shepherd reporters. Discovery's five-man crew didn't need any orders. They just continued working 16-hour shifts. Also continuing at their posts were the ground controllers in Houston and crews preparing for the shuttle's landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., on Wednesday. Lawyers from the solicitor general's office are scheduled to present the government's views Tuesday when the Supreme Court hears arguments on a question of securities law and a case involving suits by workers. David Souter will be hearing his first cases on the high court after his swearing-in Monday. The Justice Department plans to keep 60,000 of its 80,000 employees working, said a department official. Law enforcement agents at the FBI, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Immigration and Naturalization Service would be considered essential personnel along with federal prison guards, he said. The nation's 94 U.S. attorneys' offices would stay open and more than half the prosecutors and attorneys would continue to work. Under the Constitution, judges' pay cannot be decreased. The nation's federal courts, therefore, will continue to function with only some cuts in the work of some clerks, said David Sellers, a spokesman for the Administrative Office of U.S. Courts. At the Agriculture Department, officials said the only clear-cut exception to the shutdown was the federal meat and poultry inspection system. Press secretary Kelly Shipp said county offices of the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, which handles commodity subsidies, and the Farmers Home Administration, which makes loans to low-income farmers, would be closed. Labor Department spokeswoman Johanna Schneider said about 3,000 of the agency's 18,100 employes are considered essential. The figure includes 1,800 employes of the Mine Safety and Health Administration, who conduct day-to-day monitoring of mines.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Rate Of Deaths Caused By Accidents Down 21 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The rate at which Americans died from accidents decreased an estimated 21 percent in the last decade, according to a group that promotes safety. Experts attributed the improvement to seat belt laws, smoke alarm requirements and other toughened safety regulations. The National Safety Council, a public service organization with headquarters here, reports that accidents still rank as the fourth leading cause of death, as they were at the beginning of the 1980s. But the combination of new laws and lower public tolerance for unsafe behavior at home, at work and especially behind the wheel of a car has improved Americans' safety record, said Alan Hoskin, director of the council's statistics department. ``In general, people are demonstrating more concern for safety in numerous aspects of their lives,'' Hoskin said Monday. The number of fatal accidents went from 105,312 in 1979 to an estimated 94,500 in 1989, a decrease of 10 percent, according to figures the council released in August. To arrive at the 21 percent decline, statisticians used the overall number of fatalities, calculated a rate per 100,000 people and adjusted that rate for the fact that there are more elderly now - a factor which could tend to inflate the rate. DOC.HEAD: Pumpkin Weighs In at 544 Pounds
DOC.TEXT: Tom Borchard credits big seeds and ``just a little fertilizer'' with helping him grow a 544-pound pumpkin that weighed in Monday as the heaviest at the 20th annual Great Pumpkin Weigh-Off. Borchard, 46, of Salinas, who has grown the winning pumpkin six times, has a simple plan: ``I just keep the biggest seeds out of the biggest ones and they just keep getting bigger on me.'' ``Just a little fertilizer, a lot or water and pray a lot,'' he said. The seeds are about twice as big as regular pumpkin seeds, Borchard said. Borchard said he and his three sons - ``who are pretty good sized'' - struggled to load the pumpkin onto a pallet. After that, they used a forklift to transport the oversized squash, which is about 4 feet across. The all-time record at the community event, which also draws contestants from other states, weighed more than 600 pounds, said contest spokeswoman Sarah Williams. Borchard plans to carve the pumpkin into a jack-o-lantern, but won't bake any pies. That's because the seed variety he uses - Atlantic Giant - is good for size but too stringy for a good filling, Borchard said, adding: ``We make pies out of a can.''

DOC.HEAD: Egypt Warns Israel Clashes Could Lead to `Grave Consequences'
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak warned Monday the clashes in Jerusalem that left at least 19 Palestinians dead could lead to ``grave consequences'' in the Middle East. Mubarak's statement, which was delivered on Cairo television, was apparently referring to the Persian Gulf standoff between Iraq and the U.S.-led multinational force. Earlier Monday, Iraq's ruling Baath party threatened to retaliate for the killings. In his statement, Mubarak warned the shootings could ``lead to grave consequences in the present critical circumstances engulfing the area.'' Cairo television interrupted its regular programing to deliver the statement. The statement was issued by Mubarak's office and not the foreign ministry as is usual. It reflected Egypt's fears of a possible outbreak of Arab-Israeli hostilities at a time when Cairo is leading Arab opposition to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The statement said Israel's ``savage repressive measures exceeded all limits'' and added that the Jewish state is ``fully responsible'' for protecting Islamic shrines in Jerusalem. The statement called on ``all parties in Jerusalem to practice self-restraint.'' In the Monday incident, Israeli security forces opened fire on Palestinians near the al-Aqsa mosque after the Arabs stoned Jewish worshipers at the Western Wall, below the mosque. The Western Wall is Judaism's holiest site.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Begins for White Supremacist Facing $10 Million Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A white supremacist and his son began defending themselves Monday against a $10 million lawsuit that accuses them of inciting the fatal beating of a black man. Police in riot gear stood by as Tom Metzger, 52, and his son, John, 22, jumped from a van and into a sidewalk elevator that took them to the courtroom of another black man, Multnomah County Circuit Judge Ancer Haggerty. Dozens of helmeted police, some on horseback, stood guard and a patrol helicopter circled overhead as the Metzgers arrived. The violent demonstration police prepared for failed to materialize, although a few ``skinheads'' - young, white racists who affect shaved heads and military garb - waited outside the courthouse. Three young men were arrested outside the courthouse, two for carrying concealed weapons and one in an earlier assault case after the victim pointed him out to police as his alleged attacker. Metzger, of Fallbrook, Calif., founded White Aryan Resistance and is a former Ku Klux Klan grand dragon. He and his son - also active in the white supremacy movement - are acting as their own attorneys. The wrongful-death lawsuit, filed by the victim's uncle, accuses the Metzgers of sending agents to Portland to incite violence against blacks shortly before Mulugeta Seraw, 27, was beaten to death with a baseball bat in November 1988. Two of the Ethiopian's friends were severely beaten. Three skinheads, all members of the neo-Nazi group East Side White Pride, were convicted in Seraw's death. Before jury selection began Monday, the judge rejected motions by the Metzgers to exclude various people from testifying. Among them are police who investigated Seraw's death, the victim's family and friends and two men Metzger allegedly sent to Portland as his agents. Metzger claimed he has been unable to interview the men, Dave Mazzella and Michael Barrett. The lawsuit claims they brought Metzger's message of violence against Jews and blacks to Portland skinheads. Barrett, who said he had since quit the white supremacist movement, said in a sworn statement filed with the lawsuit that he and Mazzella spoke to the gang hours before Seraw was killed. ``We told them to use violence if they got the opportunity and to be sure and beat the hell out of the enemy. We were telling them what Tom and John Metzger told us to say to skinheads we were organizing,'' he said. The Metzgers deny the accusations. The judge rejected Metzger's claim that ``the plaintiffs have played a hide-and-seek game with Mr. Barrett and Mazzella and we had no way to depose or cross-examine them.'' Haggerty reserved judgment on the Metzgers' motion to exclude certain evidence as constitutionally protected free speech. That evidence includes racist television programs Tom Metzger produces, a telephone hotline he records and newspaper columns he writes. The lawsuit was filed by Engedaw Berhanu, Seraw's uncle. Berhanu is represented by Elden Rosenthal and attorney Morris Dees of the Alabama-based Southern Poverty Law Center. Three years ago, Dees won a $7 million jury verdict against the United Klans of America after two Klansmen from Mobile, Ala., killed a 19-year-old black man. The suit was filed on behalf of the victim's mother. Also named in the current wrongful death lawsuit are two of the three skinheads convicted in Seraw's death, Kenneth Mieske and Kyle Brewster. They and Steven Strasser pleaded guilty in the earlier criminal case. Mieske was sentenced to life with a 20-year minimum, Brewster to 10 to 20 years and Strasser to 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: German House Ratifies Pact Restoring Sovereignty
DOC.TEXT: Parliament's upper house on Monday ratified the six-nation treaty restoring German sovereignty, and Chancellor Helmut Kohl asked for rapid help in rebuilding the eastern part of the newly united nation. The Bundesrat also gave final approval to a law enabling national elections to be held Dec. 2. The treaty formally ends special rights in Germany of the four World War II victors - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. It was ratified without opposition in the Bundesrat three days after it was approved by the lower house, the Bundestag. The document was signed on Sept. 12 in Moscow by the wartime allies and the two Germanys. The new election law replaces an earlier agreement ruled unconstitutional by the Suprem Court. In effect, the law sets up two separate election areas in Germany - one in former West Germany and one in now-defunct East Germany. The rejected law would have required parties to win at least 5 percent across Germany for seats in the Bundestag. Under the new law, parties need to win only 5 percent in either former East Germany or West Germany. Kohl convened a summit of Germany's most powerful business leaders Monday to issue a personal appeal for quick help in rebuilding former East Germany. ``I have a completely personal request to make of you,'' he told the assemblage at the Chancellery. ``Think over the contribution you and your workers can offer so that rapid improvements can be achieved.'' Hopes of huge investment in the former communist nation have not yet been realized. Unemployment is soaring as unprofitable businesses and factories close. He appealed to his guests to send experienced workers to eastern Germany to provide badly needed knowledge and advice. Kohl said a consensus has to be reached on how to remove difficulties facing the reconstruction of eastern Germany. The two Germanys united last Wednesday, and Kohl made it clear he wants to quickly build up what was formerly East Germany and give its people a standard of living more in line with that of the West. Also on Monday, Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said former high-ranking East German Communist Party officials should be removed from any key posts they may hold now, the newspaper Die Welt reported. It quoted Schaeuble as saying that former Communists ``who were once high up and are now again swimming like beads of fat on top of the soup'' should lose their jobs. His comments follow other news reports that some one-time members of East Germany's secret police now hold official jobs in the new united Germany. Schaeuble made special mention of the official trusteeship overseeing the privatization of businesses in former East Germany. He said former Communist Party officials found working there would be fired, according to Die Welt.

DOC.HEAD: `Dying Man' Steals $125,000, Gives Most to Family, Then Disappears
DOC.TEXT: A man who feared he was dying of cancer allegedly robbed $125,000 from a currency exchange and fled after giving his family most of the money, authorities said Monday. Port Authority and New York City police detectives were seeking Bernard Gamble, 59, of Queens in connection with the Sunday robbery at a Deak International office at John F. Kennedy International Airport. Gamble had worked at Kennedy Airport for 12 years as a cleaner for the Pioneer Cleaning Co., said Port Authority spokesman John Hughes. ``He told the people he doesn't want to do this but he's terminally ill and has to do it,'' said Hughes. Gamble was awaiting results of medical tests conducted last week. His family told police three of his relatives had died of cancer. ``He had been feeling ill for several weeks,'' Port Authority Sgt. Robert Rodriguez said. ``I guess he just snapped.'' Gamble allegedly tied up a woman employee with masking tape, then ordered a male employee to open a safe, said Hughes. He later tied up the man and escaped with $125,000. According to Hughes, Gamble's son later turned over $83,500 to the police. Hughes said the son ``then mentioned that the father had come to the house and told them that he gave them the money and told the son to take care of the mother and sister and he was going away and would not be in touch with them.'' Gamble was last seen at Newark International Airport, where a cab driver dropped him off. ``He could be anywhere by now,'' Rodriguez said. He said it was unlikely Gamble had left the country because he didn't have a passport.

DOC.HEAD: Says No Public Money Will Be Used
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins promised Monday that his head will not rest at taxpayer expense, whatever the final price tag on a bed that a magazine said is going to cost $11,500. Newsweek noted that the bed's arrival at the mayor's official residence coincided with municipal money woes that led Dinkins to freeze hiring, propose new taxes and talk about 15,000 layoffs. If it costs what Newsweek said, that ``will all be covered by private donations from friends of the city, many of whom have contacted me this morning to offer their contributions,'' the mayor said in a statement issued by his press secretary, Albert Scardino. Dinkins said $1,400 in contributions had been received before the bed, or more specifically its decorated cherry headboard, was delivered to Gracie Mansion on Friday. Newsweek said the bill so far for labor, which was performed by a carpenter on the payroll of the city Human Resources Administration, has been just under $6,500 for 266 hours. The magazine said the final accounting could be for 500 hours at $23 an hour - $11,500. Calls to HRA spokesmen for comment went unanswered Monday, the Columbus Day holiday. A new bedroom set was necessary because former Mayor Edward I. Koch took the bedroom furniture with him when he left office in January, said Jennifer Kimball of Dinkins' press office. Koch said he had brought his own bed with him when he moved in. Kimball said Dinkins and his wife, Joyce, bought nightstands and bureaus at their own expense, but the matching headboard had been discontinued and they had to have it built. Arnold Biegen, chairman of Dinkins' finance committee and a personal friend, confirmed that the final cost would be borne by contributors. ``While the published labor cost on the face of it is ludicrous, the mayor's friends will pay for it through donations to the Gracie Mansion Conservancy,'' said Biegen, a lawyer. ``I wish somebody would ask me why don't I seek reimbursement for the $8,000 or $9,000 I spent on the bedroom suite,'' Dinkins said. ``No questions have come to me in that regard. I contributed that.'' Kimball described the headboard as ``a museum piece'' that will remain the property of the city.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Warns of Dangers of Inaction on Economic Reforms
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail Gorbachev told high-ranking Communists on Monday they must embrace a market economy or risk losing power and causing greater party discord. Speaking at the opening of a two-day Central Committee meeting, Gorbachev delivered one of his sternest warnings on reform. ``All our previous ideology presented socialism as an antipode to the market and viewed the recognition of a market as an encroachment upon socialism,'' Gorbachev said, according to the state news agency Tass. ``Yes, we are encroaching upon socialism, but only socialism that was built bureaucratically, under which the country veered off the path it embarked upon in 1917,'' the year of the Bolshevik Revolution, he said. Gorbachev, who also serves as the party's general secretary, said ``the inertia of old thinking'' is a ``real danger to the party'' if it hopes to regain the confidence of the people. The party ``should help society shed prejudice and fear of the market,'' he said. The meeting of the 400-member Central Committee was its first since July's larger party congress, which Gorbachev used to bolster his power. But the congress failed to inspire new confidence in the party. About 375,000 of its approximately 18 million members have quit this year, including Russian Federation President Boris Yeltsin and the mayors of Moscow and Leningrad. Another 275,000 people were either expelled from the party or stopped paying dues and attending party functions. Gorbachev, meanwhile, has hit a low in public opinion polls as some of the 15 republics exercise more independence. Under growing popular pressure, the party earlier this year surrendered its constitutional monopoly on power. Later Monday, deputy party leader Vladimir Ivashko said ``the party does not renounce socialism'' by encouraging market-oriented reforms. In his speech, Gorbachev blamed the country's problems on the state monopoly on property and said workers would be given ``reliable'' guarantees they would benefit from the denationalization of state-run businesses. In a sign of the party's troubles concerning property, the Ternopol city council in the western Ukraine voted Monday to seize all property belonging to the regional party branch. It transferred buildings and other assets to control of municipal government authorities, Tass reported. Gorbachev said work on an economic reform plan has entered its ``final stage'' and will incorporate aspects of programs by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzkhov and economist Stanislav Shatlin, a member of the advisory Presidential Council. ``This will not be some kind of compromise document with rounded corners and fuzzy positions, but a program able to rally all sections of society,'' he promised. The Supreme Soviet legislature has set up a committee to combine several programs on rescuing the Soviet economy and report back by back by Oct. 15. The most radical reform proposal, written by Shatalin, calls for scrapping the central planning system and moving to a market economy within 500 days by selling factories to private owners and breaking up collective farms. The Ryzhkov plan would leave the government in control of most of the economy while gradually allowing some free enterprise. Gorbachev has backed a compromise that contains many elements of the 500-day plan, but at a slower pace. He also wants a national referendum to decide whether to return land to private farmers. In his speech, Gorbachev repeated his proposal to draw up a new union treaty that would grant some autonomy to the 15 Soviet republics while retaining most power in the Kremlin. ``The Soviet Communist Party resolutely opposes separatism,'' he declared, warning that unless the republics reverse their secessionist drives the Soviet Union could fall into a fragmented land of competing groups, which he likened to Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Klaus Threatens Bahamas, Lili Forms
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Klaus, which strengthened after being downgraded to a depression, threatened the Bahamas and contributed to flooding along Florida's Atlantic shores Monday. The National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables was also tracking Tropical Storm Lili, which formed in the central Atlantic but posed no immediate threat to land. At 6 p.m. EDT, Klaus had top winds of 40 mph, just over the threshold of storm strength. Its center was near 22.2 degrees north latitude and 70.8 degrees west longitude, or about 470 miles southeast of Nassau in the Bahamas. Klaus was moving northwest at 15 mph and was expected to continue on that track for the next day or two, forecasters said. Tropical storm warnings were in effect for the central Bahamas in the Caribbean, the northern Bahamas were under a tropical storm watch and a coastal flood watch was in effect for Florida's east coast and Keys. Some increase in strength was likely during the next day for Klaus, which at one point was strong enough to be the sixth hurricane of the season. The storm was expected to strengthen, but wasn't expected to move over Florida, said Bob Sheets, director of the hurricane center. ``We think it's going to move on a northwest course and most likely will not move over Florida, particularly South Florida.'' However, Klaus-related winds were already partly responsible for beach erosion, rough surf and potentially deadly rip currents along Florida's eastern coast, and heavy winds and rain elsewhere in the state, the center said. Klaus killed at least six people and left 1,500 homeless in the northeastern Caribbean before being downgraded Saturday to a typical storm when its top winds dropped below 73 mph. It was downgraded late Sunday to a tropical depression when its winds dipped below 39 mph. Meanwhile, tropical storm Lili at At 6 p.m. was located near 32.7 degrees north latitude and 47.5 degrees west longitude, or about 1,000 miles west-southwest of the Azores, a group of islands off Portugal. Lili, with top winds near 65 mph, was expected to strengthen during the next day as it moved southwest at 7 mph, forecasters said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Approval Rating Drops Amid Dissatisfaction With Budget Deficit
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's approval ratings in two polls reported Monday dropped to the lowest point of the year for each even though they remained high. One poll showed him with the lowest approval rating since he took office for the second time this year. In brief: -The ABC-Washington Post poll conducted Thursday through Saturday showed 65 percent approving the way Bush is handling his job, down from 75 percent a month earlier and equal to the 65 percent recorded in July. That 65 percent was the lowest approval rating since Bush took office. -The CBS-New York Times poll conducted Sunday gave Bush an approval rating of 62 percent, down from a peak of 76 percent in August just after troops were sent to Saudi Arabia. Congress fared little better. -In the ABC-Washington Post poll, 57 percent said Congress was more to blame than the president for the budget impasse. -In the CBS-New York Times poll, 54 percent blamed the budget snarl on Congress and the president equally. The ABC-Washington Post poll interviewed 775 people and the CBS-New York Times poll interviewed 756. Both surveys were done by telephone and reported a likely margin of error of 4 percentage points either way.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Opens First Restaurant in China
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's hamburgers, fries and golden arches came to China on Monday when the fast-food chain opened its first restaurant in a nation famed for its distinctive cuisine. Hundreds of Chinese waited for hours outside the restaurant in Shenzhen, an economic boom town near Hong Kong, for their first taste of a McDonald's hamburger, fries or shake. ``I travelled for four hours from a village to get here,'' said Huang Rongti, 70, who has lost most of her teeth because of age. ``You think hamburgers are too challenging for my age?'' Later, after purchasing her first Big Mac, she inspected it carefully before taking a bite. ``It tastes good, I like it,'' she announced before slowly eating the rest. The opening of a U.S. fast-food restaurant in China, where cooking has long been considered a culinary art, may seem odd to gourmets. It is estimated there are more than 5,000 different Chinese dishes. In Canton, 125 miles northwest of Shenzhen, chefs specialize in some of the more exotic Chinese dishes, such as cat stew, bear paws, chicken feet and a famed snake dish - ``Dragon and Tiger Locked in Battle'' - made from three kinds of poisonous snakes stewed with leopard meat, and garnished with 20 spices, lemon leaves and chrysanthemum petals. However, many Chinese, who earn an average $32 a month, are still unable to afford fancy meals at restaurants. In Shenzhen, a Chinese special economic zone where foreign investors have built factories, salaries are higher and workers earn an average of $53 a month. At the restaurant, a Big Mac costs $1.14, a bag of fries 48 cents and a shake 74 cents. Another U.S. fast food outlet, Kentucky Fried Chicken, opened a restaurant in Beijing in 1987, and it now has four outlets there. McDonald's hopes to open a restaurant in Beijing later. Although Kentucky Fried Chicken has become popular, the average Chinese still regards a meal there as a treat, rather than a convenience, and McDonald's could face the same problems. The 500-seat McDonald's restaurant in a three-story building is operated by McDonald's Restaurant Shenzhen Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of McDonald's Hong Kong. McDonald's Hong Kong is a 50-50 joint venture with McDonald's in the United States. It is managed by a Chinese national, Chen Tikang, and his son, Chen Yin, who is the restaurant manager. The younger Chen returned recently from a course at McDonald's hamburger university in Oak Brook, Ill. Most of the ingredients used at the restaurant are now imported from Hong Kong. But McDonald's executives hope eventually to get their supplies of beef and potatoes from China. Daniel Ng, chairman of McDonald's Restaurant Shenzhen Ltd., said it took two years to prepare for the restaurant's opening and his ambition now is to serve 10 million burgers a year. Last month, when McDonald's advertized for 240 staffers for the restaurant, it received applications from more than 9,000 persons, including college graduates, officials said. ``I feel I have a better job prospect working here, and it pays better,'' said Henry He, 25, who has a master's degree in garment and textile. He is an assistant manager at the restaurant. A waiter at the restaurant can earn 53 cents an hour. A factory worker, who waited several hours before she was able to purchase her hamburger, said she liked it because of its ``sweet taste'' - the result of tomato ketchup, which is not commonly used in traditional Chinese cooking.

DOC.HEAD: Weakened Austrian Conservatives Seeks Continued Ties Socialists
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of Austria's two largest parties said Monday they would open talks on continuing their governing coalition despite the drubbing of the main conservative party in national elections. Chancellor Franz Vranitzky's Socialist Party won 43 percent of the vote Sunday and added one seat in the 183-seat Parliament, where it now controls 81 seats. Vranitzky's coalition partners, the conservative People's Party, suffered its worst defeat in 45 years, losing 17 of its 77 seats yet remaining in a pivotal position to decide the makeup of the new government. Vice Chancellor Josef Riegler, leader of the People's Party, said it would talk to the Socialists about rebuilding the coalition forged in 1986 rather than turning first to the upstart Freedom Party and its leader Joerg Haider. Haider's party nearly doubled its parliamentary representation to 33 seats on a platform appealing to nationalist sentiments, warnings of rising crime and complaints over Austria's relatively liberal immigration policies for Eastern Europeans. The Freedom Party took nearly 17 percent of the popular vote. Some in the Peoples' Party had earlier suggested the possibility of a coalition with the Freedom Party. With 93 seats between them, they would have one more than the majority. Vranitzky reiterated Monday that he would not govern in partnership with Haider's Freedom Party, which he and his party consider too far to the right. The Socialists had been expected to lose heavily due to a series of internal scandals, but Vranitzky's extraordinary popularity appeared to offset the problems. Vranitzky's government was to submit its resignation Tuesday after the regular Cabinet session. President Kurt Waldheim will ask Vranitzky, as leader of the strongest party, to form a new government. Vranitzky and Riegler met separately with Waldheim on Monday to discuss the outcome of the election. The environmental Green Alternative Party won an additional seat Sunday for a total of nine.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Extradition Request for Ex-Military President
DOC.TEXT: A federal court on Monday rejected a request by Italy to extradite five former military officers accused of human rights violations during the Argentine ``dirty war,'' including ex-President Jorge Videla. The extradition request is ``inadmisible,'' the court ruled, because the crimes the Italian court wants to prosecute occurred in Argentina. The case stems from the 1978 disappearance of four Argentine citizens of Italian descent who were last seen in the Atlantic resort of Mar del Plata, 250 miles south of Buenos Aires. Relatives in Italy filed the suit. The court requested the extraditions last Tuesday. Videla and former navy admiral Emilio Massera were convicted by a federal court and sentenced to life in prison for human rights abuses committed during the 1976-83 military junta's crackdown on suspected leftist subversion. Of the other three former officers cited, one was convicted of rights abuses, one is awaiting trial and one was allowed to retire. The ``dirty war'' the hard-line military waged against suspected leftist subversives left at least 9,000 people missing and presumed dead.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Grateful Years of Work Recognized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Thomas, 70...,' to CORRECT conversion of kronor prize to dollars as of Monday to $704,000 sted $695,000.
DOC.TEXT: Tamara Roberts long ago recognized the value of the bone-marrow transplant research by E. Donnall Thomas, one of two American doctors awarded the Nobel Prize in medicine. It saved her life. In 1972, Roberts was a teen-ager dying of leukemia. Today, at age 34, she has lived longer than any other leukemia victim who received a bone marrow transplant. ``He is like my dad,'' Roberts said a news conference Monday with Thomas. ``When you've known someone and they've brought you back and given you another ... 60 years on a silver platter and said just enjoy, wouldn't you feel close to that person? I know I do.'' Thomas, 70, and Joseph E. Murray, 71, who performed the first successful human organ transplant, a kidney, will share the $704,000 prize. Their revolutionary procedures have saved thousands of lives over three decades. Both said Monday that they were surprised and grateful for the recognition, but that their lives would be unchanged by the money. Thomas, with the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, credited his research team for much of his accomplishments. ``It's a great honor, not only for me but for the team I have worked with all these years,'' he said. Thomas performed the first human bone marrow transplant in 1956. Initially, the only success came in cases where identical twins were involved. By the early 1970s, however, the years of research began to pay off. Roberts' donor was her brother. Today, the procedure is standard treatment for leukemia and other diseases. Leukemia once was always fatal. Thomas' procedure now produces a cure in 50 percent of all cases, and in 80 percent of childhood cases. In 1987 about 4,000 patients received the treatment. Murray, in San Francisco for a medical conference, said Monday he struggled with moral dilemmas four decades ago as he pioneered transplant surgery, which is now routine but still ethically complex. ``We were stuck with the moral problem of removing a healthy organ from a healthy person. And this was new then,'' Murray said. In 1954, Murray and his team of surgeons at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston removed a healthy kidney from 23-year-old Ronald Herrick and transplanted it in his identical twin, Richard, in what was the first such success after 15 failures. ``We felt it was worth risking the health of that normal person ... to prevent the death of his twin brother,'' Murray said. ``He was very anxious to donate. ... The operation was the light at the end of the tunnel.'' In 1962, Murray performed the first successful kidney transplant from an unrelated donor. Now, up to 50,000 organ transplants are performed each year, 75 percent of them involving kidneys. Transplants still present ethical questions, he said, such as the whether it is right to spend millions of dollars on ``high-tech'' medicine when many Americans lack basic medical care. ``I think the imbalance is horrible, but I don't think we should deny high-tech medical advances,'' he said. The lack of health care for some is ``a distribution problem,'' he added, comparing it to the inability to get surplus food to all the hungry.

DOC.HEAD: Winds Fan Fires, 19 Homes Damaged
DOC.TEXT: Wind-whipped wildfires damaged at least 19 homes in Southern California on Monday as residents and schoolchildren fled from flames that scorched more than 170 acres of dry, brushy terrain. In the Los Angeles suburb of Diamond Bar, a fast-moving brush fire spread to a residential area and damaged four homes, said Los Angeles County Fire Capt. Cliff Norton. Firefighters aided by helicopters contolled the blaze by 5 p.m., sheriff's Sgt. Sylvia Fort said. In Riverside, 60 miles east of Los Angeles, a grade school was evacuated because of a fire in the dry Santa Ana River bottom outside the city. At least 125 acres had burned and between 15 to 20 structures incurred minor damage, said City Fire Capt. Richard Ballinger. ``It was quite a large column of smoke. We had a lot of people panic-struck just from the look of it,'' Ballinger said. Four people, including a firefighter, suffered minor smoke-inhalation and broken-bone injuries and were treated at local hospitals, he said. The blaze began about 10:30 a.m. Monday and its cause wasn't known. The 900 youngsters at Mountain View Elementary School were evacuated. In Fontana, 50 miles east of Los Angeles, a small brushfire destroyed one structure, leaving just a stone chimney, witnesses said. It was controlled before doing further damage. Some 100 firefighters battled a fourth fire at the base of the Cajon Pass near the Glen Helen regional park, where at least 50 acres were blackened, said Greg Cooper of the California Department of Forestry. At one point, the blaze threatened the Treehouse Fun Ranch nudist camp, but no evacuation was ordered, Cooper said. The fire was also contained by 5 p.m. A ``red flag'' warning for extreme fire danger was issued because of 50 mph winds and low humidity associated with fall's first full-scale Santa Ana winds. The so-called devil winds originate in the deserts to the east and north of the Los Angeles basin, speeding up and heating by compression as they funnel through mountain passes.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Fear Owl Maps Stolen, Nests Targeted
DOC.TEXT: Someone may have stolen information on spotted owl nests in the Siskiyou National Forest and used it to kill the young birds, the U.S. Forest Service says. A map and related documents that identify six nesting sites of the threatened species near the Oregon Caves National Monument are missing, said Rich Thurman, wildlife biologist for the Illinois Valley Ranger District. Routine forays to the area in southwestern Oregon by experts imitating owl calls failed to turn up any young, he recently. The birds are at the center of a controversy that pits loggers against environmentalists and government officials seeking to preserve the virgin forests of the Pacific Northwest. The spotted owl was declared a threatened species this year, a ruling that will restrict logging in some areas. The documents may have been missing since June, the last time they was used, Thurman said. Thurman said there was no direct evidence any owls were killed, but he would have expected to find some young birds produced from the nests. There was no evidence of a break-in at the Illinois Valley Ranger District in Cave Junction, where the documents were kept in files, he added. However, many people have the office key. Don Feuerborn, district law enforcement officer, said he was almost certain the information was stolen. He said there was no evidence of any spotted owls being killed in the district. But he noted the carcass of a barred owl was hung on a Forest Service sign in the nearby Onion Mountain area a month ago.

DOC.HEAD: Australia Agrees With U.S.: Military Option Must Remain In Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Australia's foreign minister agreed with U.S. officials Monday that the military strike option must be kept open in the Persian Gulf in case a peaceful settlement is not possible. Foreign Minister Gareth Evans, at a news conference following U.S.-Australian security talks, echoed a similar statement by Secretary of State James A. Baker III who said he told the Australians ``we do not and cannot foreclose (on) the possible use of force.'' Baker, also at the news conference, added, ``We also, of course, discussed in detail our preferred option of a peaceful, diplomatic, political solution.'' Evans said, ``We would infinitely prefer a peaceful settlement through the application of sanctions and whatever needs to accompany that ...'' and added, ``but equally we acknowledge that the military strike option must be kept open in the event that peaceful resolution fails.'' Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke has sent two guided-missile frigates, a supply ship and about 600 men to support U.S. operations against Iraq's Aug. 1 takeover of Kuwait. The commitment has the support of Australia's opposition party but has been criticized by members of Australia's Arab community, small political parties and other groups. A joint communique from the meeting which also included U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Australian Defense Minister Robert Ray strongly condemned Iraq's invasion and occupation and called for an unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. Baker said he was ``indeed very happy'' with Australia's support in the crisis. He said there was no discussion of increasing the commitment. The only points of differences noted in the talks were over trade. Australian officials said they were concerned over several provisions of the pending farm bill in the Congress. And U.S. officials complained about Australian policies on government procurements and the local content requirements for broadcast TV commercials.

DOC.HEAD: American Transplant Doctors Take Nobel for Medicine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9 `The doctors' to CORRECT that Murray stopped performing surgery four years ago and graf 12 `Murray, a' to CORRECT to seven years kidney survived sted of 24. Picks up 13th pvs, `Thomas was...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY6,7, FX2
DOC.TEXT: Two American doctors won the Nobel Prize in medicine Monday for their work in transplanting human organs and bone marrow, revolutionary procedures that have saved thousands of lives over three decades. Joseph E. Murray, 71, who performed the first successful organ transplant - a kidney - and E. Donnall Thomas, 70, who pioneered bone marrow transplants to cure leukemia, will share the $704,000 (4 million kronor) prize. Most Nobel Prizes in medicine have been awarded for basic research, not for clinical treatment. ``I really thought this work was too clinical to ever win the prize,'' Thomas said from his home in Bellevue, Wash. He is affiliated with the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, one of the world's major bone marrow transplant institutions. But in the case of transplants, the clinical treatment was a radical advance. ``This was astonishing, to take one organ and move it to another person. It was science fiction 30 years ago,'' said Dr. Carl-Gustav Groth, a member of the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institute, which awarded the prize. Swedish dynamite inventor Alfred Nobel declared in his 1896 will that the prizes should be given to those who have ``conferred the greatest benefit on mankind.'' The Nobel Assembly said Murray's and Thomas' discoveries had met the requirement by saving tens of thousands of lives, providing cures for such fatal diseases as leukemia, liver malignancy, coronary artery disease and aplastic anemia. The doctors did their groundbreaking research separately during the 1950s and 1960s, but they began their careers together at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, where Murray remains affilitated although he stopped performing surgery four years ago. ``He was a resident in medicine and I was a resident in surgery,'' said Murray, who was in San Francisco on Monday for a medical conference. ``This was after World War II. ``We both started working in transplants together, but from different angles. It's marvelous to share it with him.'' Murray, a native of Milford, Mass., mastered the problem of organ rejection and in 1954 made the first successful organ transplant, a kidney from one identical twin to another that functioned for seven years. In earlier attempts, implanted organs were rejected within hours or days. Thomas was also able to diminish the severe reaction that bone marrow grafts can cause in recipients. He performed the first human bone marrow transplant in 1956, and his procedure now is the standard treatment for leukemia patients. It also is used to treat a variety of cancers and inherited diseases, and researchers are investigating its potential use in treating AIDS and other diseases. The Nobel Assembly said the idea of transplanting organs has been discussed for thousands of years, and unsuccessful attempts were made at the turn of the century. A medieval Italian painting shows doctors trying to sew a black man's leg onto a white man's body. Leading modern scientists, including 1960 Nobel medicine laureate Sir Peter Medawar of Great Britain, had believed organ transplant was biologically impossible. In the late 1940s, Medawar said a biological force existed that ``forever will inhibit transplantation from one individual to another.'' Groth said now even successful transplants from animals to humans are not far away, but rejection by the immune system is still the main problem. Murray's transplant work opened ``the field for other organs such as liver, pancreas and heart,'' said the award statement. Up to 50,000 organ transplants are performed each year, 75 percent of them involving kidneys. Leukemia once was always fatal. Thomas' procedure now produces a cure in 50 percent of all cases, and in 80 percent of childhood cases. In 1987 about 4,000 patients received the treatment. ``Murray's and Thomas' discoveries are crucial for those tens of thousands of severely ill patients who either can be cured, or be given a decent life when other treatment methods are without success,'' said the 50-member Nobel Assembly at Sweden's largest and oldest medical university. Americans have won or shared 69 of the 142 Nobel medicine prizes since 1901. Great Britain is second with 17 winners. Last year, the prize also went to Americans. J. Michael Bishop and Harold E. Varmus won it for discovering a family of genes that has helped scientists understand how cancer develops. The medicine or physiology prize is the first of five endowed by Nobel to be awarded this month. The Nobel Peace Prize will be announced Oct. 15 in Oslo, Norway. Prizes for physics and chemistry discoveries will be announced Oct. 17 in Stockholm. The date for the literature prize has not been announced. The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, created by the Central Bank of Sweden in 1969, will be awarded in Stockholm on Oct. 16. The prizes are presented Dec. 10, the anniversary of Nobel's death.

DOC.HEAD: Rawada's Capital Calms as Rebels Dig Into Countryside
DOC.TEXT: Stores in Rwanda's capital reopened Monday and people traveled freely around the city for the first time since street battles began last week. A rebel leader denied his forces were involved in the clashes that began in Kigali on Friday, blaming loyalist government soldiers and others seeking to join the week-old rebellion. Military officials, however, claim to have arrested rebels in the capital as hundreds of foreigners fled amid the fighting. Rebels calling themselves the Rwandese Patriotic Front invaded the tiny central African country from its northern neighbor Uganda on Sept. 30. The force, mostly Rwandan refugees from the minority Tutsi tribe, includes many deserters from Uganda's army. They reportedly were concentrated in Rwanda's northeastern corner, although a diplomat said a group of rebels was sighted last week at a lake 30 miles east of the capital. Nearly 100,000 Tutsi refugees have lived in Uganda since the late 1950s and early 1960s after fleeing massacres by the majority Hutu tribe. The rebels seek to oust President Juvenal Habyarimana, who they accuse of corruption and abuse of power. A Hutu, Habyarimana has ruled Rwanda since a 1973 coup. The refugees' repatriation had been hampered by severe overcrowding in Rwanda, Africa's most densely populated country. An average of more than 566 people live on every square mile, compared with an average in the United States of 63 people per square mile. Since Friday, nearly 1,500 troos from France, Belgium and Zaire have arrived to protect their citizens and embassies in Kigali and help Rwanda's army maintain control. The rebels protested the intervention in news releases Monday and warned foreign governments if their forces strayed from their stated mission ``full responsibility for what happens to them shall fall on your shoulders.'' Although no government had ordered the evacuation of its citizens, up to 1,000 foreigners, mostly dependants of aid workers, left over the weekend on specially scheduled flights. The flow of foreign citizens leaving the former Belgian colony slowed Monday as relative calm returned to Kigali. Residents reported hearing light and sporadic shooting Sunday night, but said the situation overall had quietened. The defense ministry announced that businesses were to resume normal working hours Tuesday, but a dusk-to-dawn curfew continued and public transportation remained suspended. Since the invasion, many Tutsi and some Hutu businessmen and intellectuals in Kigali have been arrested, according to diplomats who spoke on condition of anonymity. The diplomats could not speculate on the number of arrests. A defense ministry statement Monday reported a ``good number'' of rebels and supporters had been arrested in the capital. ``The situation is more and more returning to normal, but some areas are still infested with the assailants,'' it said. In an interview behind rebel lines with Uganda's state-owned newspaper New Vision, a rebel identified as Maj. Peter Baingana denied that rebels infiltrated the capital and claimed several Rwandan soldiers had joined the insurgency, but did not say how many. He claimed the rebels controlled the border post of Kagitumba, 55 miles north of Kigali, and said they had captured two armored vehicles, four mortars, several machine guns and an anti-aircraft gun during battles last week. The rebel force is led by Uganda's former deputy army commander, Maj. Gen. Fred Rwigyema, a Rwandan of Tutsi origin. Estimates of the rebel troop strength range from several hundred to several thousand.

DOC.HEAD: Police Fire on Arabs at Holy Site, Killing at Least 19
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with specific numbers, Arabs ask U.N. protection, curfews set, troops move in. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JRL1,TLV1
DOC.TEXT: In Jerusalem's worst bloodshed since 1967, police fired Monday on stone-throwing Palestinians at the Temple Mount sacred to both Jews and Moslems, and at least 19 Arabs died. The shooting began after about 3,000 Palestinians hurled a barrage of stones from the mount onto Jews gathered just below at the Western Wall, or Wailing Wall, where up to 20,000 Jews were celebrating the festival of Sukkot. The wall is Judaism's holiest site. The Arabs were apparently infuriated by rumors that Jewish extremists planned to march onto the Temple Mount, which is under Moslem control. Police fired tear gas, then rubber bullets and live ammunition. Helicopters flew overhead. The bloodbath touched off riots in the occupied territories that killed three more Palestinians. A Jewish cab driver also was found shot to death. Police Minister Roni Milo said 19 Arabs were killed in Jerusalem and about 140 wounded. Arab hospital officials at first said 22 were killed, then lowered their count to 18, with 125 wounded - lower than that given by the Israelis. Milo said 120 Palestinians were arrested. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir expressed regret but insisted Israeli forces were blameless. ``We are greatly sorry about the blood spilled in vain,'' he said. The single-day death toll was the highest since the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation began in December 1987, and the most deaths by violence in Jerusalem since Israeli soldiers captured the holy city's Arab sector in the 1967 Middle East war.
