DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - He was an American newspaperman who went to Japan 100 years ago to teach English and fell in love, with the country. In the following years Lafcadio Hearn wrote extensively about Japan and its people and admirers say he was one of the few Westerners who truly understood the culture. While his work is little known in the West today, the Japanese have never forgotten him.

Lafcadio Hearn gazed out through his cedar-framed window, contemplated a lotus pond surrounded by irises and moss-covered rocks and listened to the cicadas buzzing on a plum branch. He turned to his waist-high desk and put pen to paper. He wrote a melancholy prophecy that is still valid 100 years after he arrived in this small lakeside city in Izumo, the mythical Province of the Gods. ``Already a multitude of gardens, more spacious and more beautiful than mine, have been converted into rice fields or bamboo groves,'' he wrote. ``And the quaint Izumo city, touched at last by some long-projected railway line ... will swell, and change, and grow commonplace, and demand these grounds for the building of factories and mills. ``Not from here alone, but from all the land the ancient peace and the ancient charm seem doomed to pass away. For impermanency is the nature of all things, more particularly in Japan.'' The Greek-Irish journalist from the United States had fallen in love with Japan, although he became increasingly ambivalent as it modernized. And while Hearn has largely slipped into obscurity in the West, the Japanese have never forgotten him, particularly in this centennial year. Admirers say he was one of the few Westerners who truly understood Japanese culture, possibly because he considered it superior in many ways to the industrialized West. ``He loved the ordinary life, the daily life of the Japanese people,'' says Kenji Zenimoto, professor of intercultural studies at Shimane University in Matsue and president of the national Lafcadio Hearn Society. Elementary school pupils around the country still read Hearn's Japanese ghost stories, and high-school students practice English with his evocative travel writings. University students study his philosophical essays, and scholars argue passionately over his 12 major books and hundreds of articles and letters. The largest celebration of his centennial began in Matsue on Aug. 30, exactly 100 years after Hearn arrived at age 40 to teach English in the city's middle school. Hearn wrote about the town in ``The Chief City of the Province of the Gods,'' part of ``Glimpses of an Unfamiliar Japan,'' published in 1894. Here, between a lake and lagoon near the Japan Sea about 390 miles west of Tokyo, one can see that much about Japan has changed and much remains eternal. Part of Hearn's garden remains, including the pond and ancient pines. But other houses now encroach upon the northern portion, where wild flowers and grasses once extended to the wooded hills far beyond. The Lafcadio Hearn Memorial Museum displays Hearn's desk, the shell he blew when he wanted his pipe lit, his glasses and socks and even a lock of his hair preserved in a stone monument. There are displays which tell of Hearn's Japanese wife, their four children, and his teaching posts elsewhere in Japan, including Imperial University in Tokyo. Next door is the lotus-pond garden and the house where Hearn lived after his romance with Japan turned into marriage. Although he left Matsue in November 1891, he was to stay in Japan until he died in 1904. He wed Setsu Koizumi, the daughter of an impoverished samurai family, became a Japanese citizen and a Buddhist and adopted the name by which he is known to most Japanese today: Yakumo Koizumi. Yakumo, which means ``eight clouds,'' is a poetic version of Izumo. As a child, Hearn had been virtually abandoned by his Irish father and Greek mother. After working as a reporter in Cincinnati, New Orleans, New York and the West Indies, he thought he had finally found a peaceful home in old Japan. But Japan was in the throes of modernization begun in the 1868 Meiji revolution. And just as marriages occasionally succumb to disenchantment, Hearn increasingly found fault with Japan. Historian Kaoru Sekita, a Hearn scholar at Waseda University in Tokyo, says Hearn predicted that Japan could never successfully adopt some Western ideas, particularly democratic political processes. Hearn thought ``the modes of Japanese human relations had not fundamentally changed since mythological times,'' Sekita says. Hearn's collection of essays, written shortly before he died, also discusses the problems that arise from Japan's emphasis on group loyalty over individual enterprise. Hearn warned of a ``rise of new power'' in Japan - an ``oligarchy of wealth'' that would enslave the people. Hearn is not universally admired in Japan. Some critics say his romantic portrayal of old Japan perpetuates the myth that Japan is unique, a misconception they say still keeps Japan from participating fully in the international community. Others condemn his work as a defense of ultra-conservatism. ``Lots of people who love Hearn today are nostalgic about the old Japan,'' says Yuzo Ota, associate professor of history at McGill University in Montreal. ``They are modernized intellectuals who like his romanticized picture of Japan. They feel threatened by their own mixed identity.'' Hearn didn't have a simple love affair with Japan but a complicated love-hate relationship, Ota says. The accepted view that Hearn loved Japan ``is based on suppression of evidence'' in Hearn's letters to friends and other scholars, he says. Zenimoto says some of Hearn's letters were cut for publication to remove passages critical of Japan, including some that castigated its rigid bureaucratic, military and educational systems. Also cut were some of Hearn's wry observations about sex in Japan, which was more open in the late 1800s than it is now, he says. Zenimoto has written to about 10 U.S. libraries with extensive holdings of Hearn letters in an attempt to compile a definitive collection. He and his assistant, Yuko Kawauchi, also are working on a Hearn catalog that will list everything written by and about him. So far they have listed 1,900 items and have an estimated 7,000 to go. Hearn's 28-year-old great-grandson, Bon Koizumi, curator of the Hearn Memorial Museum, prepared a special collection for the festival. It includes manuscripts, classroom notes of Hearn's students and English-language textbooks he prepared for his wife and children. Zenimoto, Ota and Koizumi were among a dozen scholars participating in the five-day festival, which included presentations on Hearn's newspaper stories on macabre events in Cincinnati, the effect of Hearn's Irish roots on his work, Hearn's and other Westerners' interpretations of Shinto, Japan's indigenous religion, and Hearn's ghost stories. ``Lafcadio Hearn was an ideal foreigner to understand Japan, but he also understood cultural shock and the culture gap,'' Zenimoto says. ``We must understand more minutely his life, but we must not idolize him.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - When a woman goes to prison, often it is her family that suffers the most. And here in a remote corner of West Virginia, near the federal prison for women at Alderson, there is a group that cares. At the Alderson Hospitality House, friends and loved ones of women behind bars can find food and lodging and a sympathetic ear.

Once a month, Joe Gump leaves his home in Bloomingdale, Mich., and drives all night to visit his wife here in the Allegheny Mountains of rural West Virginia. Gump is a 62-year-old retired chemical engineer and businessman. His wife, Jean Gump, is a 63-year-old inmate at the minimum-security Federal Prison Camp of Alderson, serving eight years for helping trash some missile silos in Missouri during an anti-nuclear protest in 1986. As a result of his monthly visits, Gump has found a home away from home in this remote town of 1,000 people, where the federal prison, which holds about 800 women, is the biggest industry. He's a regular at the privately funded Alderson Hospitality House, which opened in 1977 to provide lodging and meals for friends and families of prisoners, the first of its kind in the nation. The three-story white house, built in 1889 as a boarding house, has 11 guest rooms and two bathrooms to house up to 35 people, including children. It is operated by Dee and John Vodicka, strong advocates of prisoners' rights. ``You put someone in prison to punish them for a crime, but you're really punishing the people they leave behind,'' says Joe Gump. In their case, that's a lot of people. Joe and Jean Gump raised 12 children. And they're the kind of people the Vodickas want to help. ``These families are us, given the same circumstances,'' Mrs. Vodicka says. ``That saying, `There but for the grace of God, go I,' is so true. We learn that every weekend.'' Most of the inmates at the Alderson prison are blacks or Hispanics from big cities, most serving time for drug offenses or tax evasion. Faye Pollard, an assistant to the warden, estimates that 60 percent of them are mothers. ``What cost is prison wreaking on the children?'' Mrs. Vodicka asks. ``What is their future? Fifteen or 20 years down the line, that anger is going to need to be handled?.'' The Vodickas feel most of the prisoners should be sentenced to home confinement, work release and drug rehabilitation. ``I think the vast majority of women here could be let out today with no effect on society,'' Vodicka says. ``There are few women up here who have committed heinous crimes like you read about. They have offended society by breaking laws, but they could have been diverted short of prison.'' She cites the Gump case. Jean Gump and four friends entered a nuclear missile site at Knob Noster, Mo., on Good Friday, 1986, and attacked the silos with sledgehammers. She poured her own blood on the silo and then the five waited 45 minutes for the police to arrive and arrest them. After Jean went to prison, Joe got involved with civil disobedience. He used the same tools and banners that Jean used when he staged his own protest in 1987 on the day the atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima. He got a different judge, and was sentenced to two years in prison. But Alderson also has been home to some notorious offenders, including Lynette ``Squeaky'' Fromme and Sandra Good, disciples of Charles Manson, convicted in the Sharon Tate murders, and Sarah Jane Moore. Fromme and Moore tried to assassinate President Gerald Ford just 17 days apart. Moore and Fromme were transferred to other prisons after they tried to escape and are serving life sentences. Good was paroled in 1985. John Vodicka, 42, is no stranger to prisons. He worked as a chaplain for the San Francisco Bay area county jails, as a prison rights advocate in New Orleans and in a program for the homeless in Atlanta before moving to West Virginia. Alderson House has a $26,000 budget and receives no federal funding, Vodicka says. About half the money comes from guests and the remainder from private or church donations. There are few frills. ``None of us receives a salary. Practically all of it goes back into the house for upkeep and utilities,'' Vodicka says. ``Food and maintenance are the big items.'' Furniture is donated by churches and individuals. Guests often bring food instead of money. Visiting children play with the Vodicka children, Gabriel, 5, and Luke, 2, and Samuel, born Sept. 12. The large kitchen table has several highchairs around it. Colorful alphabet magnets, an arm's length away on the refrigerator, are a big draw to the children who like to spell out their names and leave messages. The Vodickas share the chores. Volunteers frequently live with them. The Vodickas are the third couple to run the house. Dick Dieter and Maggie Louden opened the hospitality house in 1977, basing their philosophy on the Roman Catholic worker movement of the 1930s and 1940s. The movement emphasized a simple lifestyle based on pacifism and helping those in need. After another couple ran the house for two years, the Vodickas took over in 1986. Just to the right of the house's front door is the office from which the Vodickas coordinate guest lists and compile three newsletters that promote their views against the death penalty and for prisoner's rights. They live in two private rooms behind the office. Now the Vodika family is looking for someone to take over the house. With their new addition to the family, they are outgrowing the two small rooms. ``Every time the house has need someone or something, it has come through,'' Mrs. Vodicka says.

DOC.TEXT: Robert Urich, best known as a street-wise detective, moves away from the urban battleground in a new TV comedy series, ``American Dreamer.'' He plays a modern philosopher in a small town. The NBC show offers a mixture of humor, introspection, remembrances and fantasy focusing on Urich, who portrays a former network journalist seeking a new life after his wife is killed by a terrorist while they are on assignment together. The TV reporter quits his high-paying, high-profile job to move his son and daughter to a small town to write a weekly human-interest column. His new assistant, played by Carol Kane, says, ``Human interest? Oh, you mean fluff.'' Each episode becomes a meandering odyssey as he explores his innermost thoughts en route to arriving at his column. ``The way he thinks about things is the nut of the show,'' Urich says in an interview at his home on the edge of the Hollywood Hills. ``The writing of a column can be a catalyst for him to explore some personal experience. The column is his life, and his life is the column. ``In a novel a writer can take a chapter to examine a character's feelings. We can do it in a snap, by having him step into limbo. The stage suddenly goes black except for the spotlight on him. We're experimenting with different lighting techniques. The limbo is a chance for us to not complete scenes, but to let him explain what happened or re-create a scene from his past.'' Despite more than a decade in tough-guy roles, Urich sees ``American Dreamer'' as a return to his roots. ``I started out on the straw hat circuit, doing `Father of the Bride' and all that stuff,'' he says. ``When I came to L.A. the first thing I did was `Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice.' I was told it was comedy and it's difficult. You have to read. I said, `Wait, that's what I do for a living.' Then I was in `Soap' and `Tabitha.' So it's familiar, yet different. ``The way they work here is amazing. You don't have a finished script when you start out. At least 80 percent of it's rewritten. It's an exploration by the actors and writers. The writers listen and watch and fine-tune it. Finally, by the end of the week you've got it down. When the audience comes in it's like opening night. The writers and producers dress up, send flowers, and come in ready to have a good time.'' The show's from Gary David Goldberg's UBU Productions, which last did ``Family Ties.'' Of his past comedies, Urich may be best remembered as the sexy tennis pro whose dalliances and murder got ``Soap'' off to a rousing start in 1977. He was a uniformed police marksman in ``S.W.A.T.'' in 1975-76, but turned detective in ``Vega$'' in 1978. It lasted three years, then came ``Gavilan,'' in which he played a sort of waterlogged secret agent. It lasted about three episodes. ``Spenser: For Hire,'' based on Robert Parker's brooding, brainy, brawny detective also lasted three years. ``There's been a lot of talk about a `Spenser' movie,'' Urich says. ``Spenser: For Hire'' was filmed on location in Boston and Urich moved his family back from Boston only a year ago to concentrate on TV movie projects. He played a Texas Ranger in the acclaimed miniseries ``Lonesome Dove'' and a convicted wife killer in ``Blind Faith.'' During the summer he co-starred with Teri Garr in the NBC movie ``A Quiet Little Neighborhood, A Quiet Little Murder.'' Another movie, ``83 Hours Till Dawn,'' will be televised by CBS on Sunday, Nov. 11. He plays a father whose daughter, Samantha Mathis, is kidnapped by Peter Strauss. ``My series have never gone beyond three years,'' Urich says. He named his sailboat ``Season Three.'' ``I bought it with third-season money,'' he says. ``My family's not into sailing. It got to be too expensive. I'd just go down and sit on it once a month. I have to find something and name it `Season Seven.' Maybe it'll be a self-fulfilling prophecy.'' Urich is married to actress Heather Menzies, and they have two children. He has not yet sold his house in Massachusetts, and his undersized new home here is up for sale. ``If the kids have the TV on we can't talk,'' he says. ``So I put it on the market. It's a soft market, but I'm not in a hurry. I called my architect in Boston and asked him to draw up a four-phase plan for renovating this house in case we stay.''

DOC.HEAD: Adv21
AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
DOC.TEXT: Whether he wants to or not, Tony Goldwyn seems destined to become a movie star. He's got the looks - dark blond curly hair, ice-blue eyes and a slightly off-center smile. He's got the luck - playing the yuppie Wall Street villain in ``Ghost,'' the surprise movie hit of the summer, a romantic fantasy that bested Beatty, swamped Schwarzenegger and even wiped out Willis. He's got the training - nearly a decade of stage and television work, including studying two years at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art and playing half dozen summers at the Williamstown Festival in Massachusetts. He's got the pedigree, descended from a famous Hollywood family. The 30-year-old Goldwyn also has a level-headed sense of self in a business where sudden success, unreality and hyperbole rule the day. ``I realize acting is a profession and I want to be in it for the rest of my life,' he says. ``A lot of the roles I was offered after `Ghost' were one-dimensional bad guys. I thought it was better to make noise quietly and do something I believe in.'' Consider his latest project. Despite his current big Hollywood flick, Goldwyn is toiling these days for minimum wages in a small off-Broadway theater in Greenwich Village. He's co-starring with Richard Venture in ``The Sum of Us,'' a comedy by Australian playwright David Stevens, author of ``Breaker Morant.'' ``It's a beautiful play which I first did at Williamstown,'' Goldwyn says. Set in a blue-collar suburb of Melbourne, ``The Sum of Us'' concerns the complex relationship between a son who is gay and a father who accepts him for what he is. ``What I think is most interesting about the play is that David Stevens examines a relationship that is completely unconditional and non-judgmental and the problems that that can create,'' he says. Goldwyn began his career while at Brandeis University - on stage. It was a conscious effort to distance himself from an impeccable show-business pedigree that he says could close as many doors as it could open. One grandfather was movie mogul Samuel Goldwyn, the man behind such classics as ``The Best Years of Our Lives'' and ``Wuthering Heights.'' The other was Broadway playwright Sidney Howard, author of ``They Knew What They Wanted'' and ``The Silver Cord.'' Mom is one-time stage actress Jennifer Howard. Dad is Samuel Goldwyn Jr., a force in today's Hollywood as producer of such recent film hits as ``Mystic Pizza.'' Their son takes his family's celluloid celebrity in stride. They, in turn, protected him from it. ``I felt naive when I finally got into show business,'' Goldwyn says. ``I felt I didn't know anything about the movies because I had been so sheltered from it as a kid. `` I was very close to my grandparents and parents but they were so sensitive to the negative aspects of the Hollywood world that they kept us completely separated from it. I was never involved in my father's work. ``There never were movie stars around. Kids in school used to ask me, `What movie stars do you know?' and I was embarrassed because I didn't know any.'' Goldwyn's decision to become an actor was greeted with mixed feelings by his parents. ``My mother's whole family was from the theater and she had been an actress in New York as a younger woman,'' Goldwyn recalls. ``So the theater held great romance for her. She thought it was great.'' ``My father was terrified, but he said, `Do what you want to do,' '' Goldwyn says. ``But he was nervous about it.'' Father and son have not worked together - at least not yet. ``Our relationship is primarily personal and I wouldn't want to threaten it by getting into business together,'' Goldwyn says. ``We have such a good solid relationship as a father and a son that it's not worth it to either of us to muck it up.'' Goldwyn found out about the role in ``Ghost'' through his wife, Jane Musky, who was production designer on the film. But director Jerry Zucker thought he was ``too nice and sympathetic'' to play the man who tries to come between Patrick Swayze and Demi Moore. Only after the producer and the scriptwriter saw an audition tape Goldwyn made - and raved about his performance - did Zucker consider him for the job. Goldwyn and his wife live with their new daughter, Anna, in Hoboken, N.J. ``I have avoided the whole Hollywood scene, largely because it doesn't appeal to me,'' he says. ```When I first went back to California to work in television, it was rough. I didn't know anybody. And yet people thought I did, so that made it even harder. ``I'd walk into an office and they would say `Oh, I know your Dad.' So their perspective is `Oh, this is just another kid from a show-business family who thinks he wants to be an actor.' I don't want that to be the focus of things.'' ``Ghost'' has changed that. After he finishes his run in ``The Sum of Us,'' Goldwyn will portray Jody Powell, President Jimmy Carter's press secretary, in a television movie for Ted Turner about the Iran hostage crisis. ``The bottom line is that it's a struggle for anyone to be an actor,'' he says. ``Now that `Ghost' has become a success, the family connection has taken on a whole new meaning. People think it is wonderful and say `Gee, isn't it amazing that you've made your mark?' and `Now another Goldwyn does his own thing.' And that has been great.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
At the Movies: ``To Sleep With Anger''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Opens in New York and Los Angeles on Oct. 12 with release elsewhere through the coming months.
DOC.TEXT: Harry's the sort of guy, as his best friend's son says, you feel like taking out into the woods and leaving under a rock. That's probably being too kind. Harry Mention (Danny Glover) is a charming hustler whose very presence spells danger in Charles Burnett's ``To Sleep With Anger.'' After many years, he suddenly appears at the Los Angeles home of his old friend from the South, Gideon, and his family, stirring their passions, tampering with their dreams and fears, worsening their conflicts. Gideon (Paul Butler) and his wife, Suzie (Mary Alice), are godfearing people who believe in the inherent goodness of others. They're raised two sons, Junior, responsible and committed to his parents, pregnant wife and daughter, and Babe Brother, selfish, insecure, irresponsible and indifferent toward his wife, Linda. But the clash is more than merely generational. It's also lifestyle. Linda (Sheryl Lee Ralph) and Babe Brother (Richard Brooks) are selfish yuppies who leave their son with his grandparents each day and sometimes don't pick him up until midnight. During family gatherings, Linda prefers staying outside in the ca instead of joining in, because, she says, she doesn't know anything about crops or how to get rid of garden pests. The chasm between Babe and Linda and Babe's parents is like a lake filled with hot lava. And with Harry on the scene, it's about to boil over. Harry insinuates himself into the very fragile family relationship, seducing Babe to his misogynist, selfish and neo-criminal ways and almost possessing him until the family barrels into a near-tragedy. Burnett blocks ``To Sleep With Anger,'' which he also wrote, like a well-staged three-act play, and his denouement is delicious and devilish. His action is understated, a poetic sweep rather than a frenzied dance. This is his first major feature film. His other works have included ``Killer of Sheep,'' ``My Brother's Wedding'' and ``Horse.'' His is an original vision. His ensemble cast is balanced and works well. Alice is always a gentle joy, and Glover continues to astound with his range from his hip keystone cop capers with Mel Gibson to his lyrical boarder in ``Places in the Heart.'' There's good support from Ralph, Butler, Carl Lumbly as the older son and Vonetta McGee as his wife. ``To Sleep With Anger'' made its debut at the New York Film Festival, and is being released by The Samuel Goldwyn Co. Produced by Caldecot Chubb, Thomas S. Byrnes and Darin Scott, with Edward R. Pressman, Harris E. Tulchin and Glover as executive producers, the movie is rated PG for adult language. ---= Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G - General audiences. All ages admitted. PG - Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 - Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R - Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. NC-17 - No one under 17 admitted.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.BYLINE: ``Question & Answer'' (Geffen) - Pat Metheny with Dave Holland and Roy Haynes
DOC.TEXT: When guitarist Pat Metheny discovered a few open dates on his calendar last December, he hooked up with two other jazz veterans, drummer Roy Haynes and bassist Dave Holland, and headed for the studio. Their goal was a good time, rather than a record. But when Metheny played back the tapes of their eight-hour session, he liked what he heard and decided to release some of the music as ``Question & Answer.'' Sad to say, Metheny's enthusiasm was misplaced; there isn't much to hear here. As always, he coins some nice melodies and then takes them in interesting directions. The lovely, reflective ``Change of Heart'' is comparable to his best work. But while Metheny is often spinning intricate sounds, his rhythm section detracts and distracts. Haynes, always a busy drummer, is annoying with his incessant cymbals - it's as though he was being paid by the ching. Holland's bass is undermixed and mumbles most of the time, especially on the fast tunes and when he solos. Another reason the 62-minute record seems longer is that it's dynamically flat. As Metheny points out in the liner notes, he played one guitar at one setting throughout. His synclavier on the closing ``Three Flights Up'' provides the record's only change in texture. Metheny has released only two other trio albums, so his fans may regard ``Question & Answer'' as a treat. But it's not for the faint-hearted. - By Steven Wine, Associated Press Writer. ---=
DOC.HEAD: ``Lovers Who Wander'' (Enigma) - Del Lords
DOC.TEXT: What's America's best unknown rock band? Here's a vote for New York City's finest, the Del Lords. The Del Lords' music - little tales of life and redemption with three guitars and drums - seems almost quaint today. But it's done with intelligence and dedication, all the more impressive since they've never achieved the stardom some predicted for them six years ago. This is a quartet of working-class New Yorkers who haven't lost their pride in the city despite anger at what's become of it. ``Somewhere in Queens,'' Scott Kempner sings, ``The sun is always shining.'' But enough sociology. ``Lovers Who Wander'' is a collection that illuminates common life, from a landlord who sues a tenant for being ``a day late and a dollar short,'' to, of course, lovers who wander. The Del Lords never quite give in to their frustrations, and one suspects it's largely due to the healing powers of music. Most of Kempner's songs depict various stages of relationships, from the anticipation of ``I Need Love'' to the resignation of ``Learn to Let Go.'' While the Del Lords retain their musical toughness, the material here demands more subtlety than the band has shown in the past, and they handle it with aplomb. The only wish here is that Kempner loosen the reins on his band. Only twice does he let someone else write the songs and one of them, ``Rockabye,'' - written and sung by drummer Frank Funaro - is terrific. Guitarist Eric Ambel's voice, enough to carry a strong solo album a year ago, isn't heard until the final song. Kempner wrings as much emotion from his gruff Bronx-accented voice as can be expected, but he'd be better off spreading the vocals around more. Much of rock 'n' roll is fantasy-based, but the Del Lords have both feet firmly on the ground. And their victories are also their listeners'. Call it music you can use. - By David Bauder, Associated Press Writer.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
On Show: Bridgestone Collection Brings Masterworks to Nashville
DOC.TEXT: Americans will get a rare glimpse of how one Japanese art collector viewed Western art when a collection of 60 impressionist and modern paintings goes on exhibit next Sunday. Shojiro Ishibasi, founder of Bridgestone, the world's third largest tire manufacturer, began collecting artwork before World War II. Only once before has any part of the collection left Tokyo, and that was in 1962 when works traveled to Paris. Bridgestone has two tire plants in Tennessee and had its American headquarters in the state until it merged with Firestone and moved to Arkon, Ohio. ``Masterworks: Paintings From the Bridgestone Collection'' will hang in the Tennessee State Museum through Jan. 20. The exhibit features works by nearly every major painter of the impressionist school and includes Claude Monet's ``Twilight (Venice)'' and Amedeo Modigliani's ``Portrait of a Young Farmer.'' ``It's one Japanese collector's view of Western art,'' Tennessee State Museum Curator Lois Riggins Ezell said. ``Some did not paint in the impressionist style, but they all began painting in that time period and were all influenced by the school of impressionism.'' The museum has booked tours from New York and the Midwest, since Bridgestone probably will not let the exhibit travel again, Ezell said. Highlights include well-known paintings, such as ``Water Lilies'' from the later works of Monet and the outstanding ``Mont Saint-Victoire and Chateau Noir'' by Paul Cezanne. ``Cezanne spent half of his life painting his mountain and this is one of the best,'' Ezell said. Works by Henri Rousseau, Paul Gauguin and Henri Matisse provide a look at impressionism moving into Modernism. The collection also includes modern paintings such as Pablo Picasso's ``Cup and Spoon'' and Giorgio de Chirico's ``Troubadour.'' ``Cup and Spoon'' is a still life in cubist style, while ``Troubadour'' is a painting of a mannequin, one of the types of work for which Chirico is best known. The 60 paintings were selected primarily by the curators of the Tokyo museum, as the most artistically significant and the most stable, Ezell said. Paintings by Toulouse-Lautrec and Chagall were considered two fragile for shipment. And work by Rembrandt van Rijn was painted on a board, which lacks the resiliency of canvas and does not travel well. The collection will be on display through Jan. 20, 1991 and will then return to Japan.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: A Special Actress (and She Hops Trains, Too)
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: There was nothing special about Elizabeth Perkins as a child, unless you consider staring at people in restaurants, hopping freight trains and cheating on Rorschach tests to be nothing special. Her career in films has been, so far, nothing special. She started off in 1986 with a hit, ``About Last Night ... '' and then appeared in a pair of flops, ``Sweethearts Dance'' and ``From the Hip.'' Playing Tom Hanks' girlfriend in ``Big'' earned her solid reviews and the offers started pouring in - for Hanks. ``It's like death out there,'' Perkins, 29, said during a recent interview at a Manhattan hotel. ``There are no parts for actresses; they just don't exist. Where's Jessica Lange? Where's Jane Fonda? Why did Meryl Streep make `She-Devil'? I just happened to be the actress in `Big' so I got a few offers. I got offers to play uptight actresses with a heart of gold, just like my part in `Big.' '' She was willing to beg for ``Big'' and nearly two years later felt the same way about her latest movie, ``Avalon.'' The actress had become friendly with director Barry Levinson while he was making the Academy Award-winning ``Rain Man.'' When casting began for ``Avalon,'' he offered her the role as the mother of a family growing up in Levinson's native Baltimore during the 1940s and '50s. Perkins didn't need to finish the script. ``It was so brilliantly written,'' she said. ``I got about half way through before I called. I would have played a waitress if he had asked me to. I would have brought in coffee in a scene. ``He said I had the cynicism and I had the banter down. He said I looked like a woman from the 1940s. He said I had a very period face. I don't think I have a contemporary face.'' Perkins was born in Queens, N.Y., but her parents divorced when she was a baby and she lived on a 600-acre farm in Brattleboro, Vt., with her mother and stepfather. Basic acting and basic insubordination were her specialties. Drama awards, faulty attendance and expulsion from a boarding school are among her childhood memories. Under parental supervision she was liable to gaze at strangers. Free to do what she pleased, Perkins supplied erotic answers for her Rorschachs (inkblot analyses for personality testing) - ``just for shock value'' - and tested her jumping skills on moving trains. ``That was a big thing in my town,'' she recalled. ``Ride it, and then hop off. How can a kid really do anything that bad. The things they kick you out of school for. When you get to be older, you realize that wasn't so bad. Stealing food from the dining hall, skipping school, smoking a joint - they're part of growing up.'' After boarding school, Perkins lived with her father in Chicago and then spent three years training at the Goodman Theater School. Two years of looking for work convinced her to move to New York (this time, she paid for transportation) where she eventually landed a part on Broadway in Neil Simon's ``Brighton Beach Memoirs.'' Acting in films is easy, she insists, just a matter of summing up a character in a few words or images. For ``Avalon,'' Perkins played the part ``worried,'' seeing herself as a woman whose family was slowly breaking up. In ``Big,'' she relied on a visual effect. ``One of the things I did was to slowly lower the height of my shoes for the entire movie, so by the end my feet were completely flat on the ground. That for me gave a physical aspect to the role. I started out the movie in 4-inch high heels and I ended it flat. ``I started with my hair up and eventually lowered it and lowered it until it completely went down. Hanks brings her back down to earth. He brings the real her out.'' But fans seem to confuse the ``real'' Perkins with someone else. No one seems to realize they've encountered a genuine train-hopper. That's why cynicism and banter come easily for her, especially when greetings alternate between, ``Weren't you Tom Hanks' girlfriend in `Big'? '' and, ``Aren't you Elizabeth McGovern?'' ``The first time we met each other was about a year and a half ago at an audition,'' she said of McGovern, another dark-haired actress with a face for period pieces (``Ragtime,'' ``Once Upon a Time in America''). ``We were sitting and she turns to me and says, `Do people confuse you with me as much they confuse me with you?' I said `Yes!' She said, `At least you're talented.' And I said, `Yeah, at least you're talented. It's not like you're a bimbo.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: The ``Flower Painter'' Stigma
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Florence Harrison Nesbit has spent 60 years trying to shake the image of a ``lady flower painter.'' At 80, Nesbit still slips on a smock for ``painting binges'' at her studio in Seattle's Queen Anne neighborhood. She creates amid a stack of canvasses that includes watercolors of Whidbey Island and Walla Walla and scenes of her old sun porch in Berkeley, Calif. A shoebox of note cards keeps track of a lifetime of paintings. Some are sold. Some are displayed at Seattle's Bayview Manor where the artist lives. Many are forgotten. A Port Angeles gallery manager recently scouted Nesbit for a showing of her work. ``Are you just a flower painter?'' he asked skeptically. She bristled at the remark. ``It's a stigma you can't get rid of,'' Nesbit said. ``We want to paint just as badly as men do - most of us have had the same training as men had. But we have an awful time finding a place to show.'' Seattle gallery owners David Martin and Dominic Zambito want to change all that. This month, the Martin-Zambito Fine Art gallery on Capitol Hill is mounting an exhibition of paintings by Northwest women to commemorate the 60th anniversary of The Women Painters of Washington. The show will display works primarily from the 1930s, '40s and '50s by Nesbit and more than a dozen other members of the women's painting group. Only five of the artists featured are still alive. Relegated to family archives or sometimes destroyed altogether, art from this generation of Northwest women has not been easy to assemble, Martin said. He's rounded up works from families, friends and some of the painters themselves. A few paintings were picked up at New England auction houses. While critics continue to praise the vision of Northwestern painters Mark Tobey, Kenneth Callahan and Morris Graves, lesser known painters have been lost in history, Martin said. This show, he said, attempts to give Northwest women artists the recognition they deserve. ``It just seems unbalanced,'' Martin said. ``They are as talented as their male counterparts who showed in museums and gallery retrospectives. I want people to come and see their artwork because it's very good.'' The exhibition is a travelogue of Washington state countrysides and cityscapes. Paintings are priced from the high hundreds to $6,500. Dorothy Milne Rising offers 1940s scenes of the Puyallup Fair and Seattle's Pike Place Market. Rising, 95, currently lives in Mukilteo. Cle Elum's oldest homestead from the 1930s is portrayed by Olive Malestrom Carl. There are paintings of Mount Shuksan by Elizabeth Warhanik and Eastern Washington haystacks by Dorothy Dolph Jensen, two founders of The Women Painters of Washington. The exhibit also includes an 80-year-old photograph by Myra Wiggins, another co-founder. One of the ``photo secessionists,'' Wiggins participated in a landmark photography exhibition with Alfred Stieglitz in New York in 1910. A picture from that show will be on display at the Pike Street gallery. Perhaps the best known artist featured is Yvonne Twining Humber, 82, of Seattle. A painter for the Works Progress Administration (WPA) in Boston in the 1930s, Humber sells more art work in New England than the Pacific Northwest, Martin said. But the strength of her painting is apparent in an ethereal depiction of the ``Cascades at Night'' and her lively carnival scenes. Her work will be exhibited in a one-woman show this December at the Martin-Zambito gallery. ``The circus fascinated me,'' said Humber at her home in the city's Magnolia neighborhood. ``Old circuses would have a tent with elephants wandering around. It was the informality. There was loads of life.'' A Northwest resident since the 1940s, Humber said she has never been a flower painter. Job opportunities, not sexual politics, directed her vision, and she said her early experience with the WPA was influential. ``I paint buildings with better composition than I do fuzzy little trees,'' the artist explained. ``It was just circumstance that pushed me in that direction, but I loved it.'' Humber says she experienced no discrimination as a woman painter, but regrets her sex-segregated art training at the National Academy of Design in New York. Female-only classes, however, were better than no school at all. After a divorce in 1967, Nesbit applied to the fine arts program at her alma mater, the University of Washington. She hoped to earn a master's degree after completing one year of studies at Scripps College in California. But she was turned down by the program director, an old college classmate, who flatly told her that UW was not enrolling women painters. ``In those days before women's lib, we didn't think about it - we just took it,'' Nesbit recalled. ``I almost gave up painting and that was my life.'' Nesbit was an early success, placing first in watercolor in 1933 at the Seattle Art Museum's Northwest annual exhibition. In the decades that followed she won several painting awards and exhibited at a number of one-woman shows in California and Seattle's Frye Art Museum. Employed as a WPA painting teacher in the 1930s, Nesbit later got a job drawing fashion figures for newspaper advertisements. She co-founded the Northwest Watercolor Society in 1940. When she can, Nesbit still takes to the outdoors to paint live landscapes. But with age confining her more to the art studio, she has begun experimenting with new techniques such as tilt-top painting. Like other talented women artists of her generation, Nesbit followed her passion, but was rarely encouraged to take it seriously. After six decades of perfecting her art, she still stumbles in labeling herself a professional painter. ``My sister worked at Boeing for 27 years and that was considered successful. I was just a painter messing around,'' Nesbit said. ``Financially, I couldn't exist from what I make from my painting. Emotionally, I couldn't have lived without it.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: INXS Heads Back to Roots To Kick Off World Tour
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When members of the rock group INXS hit the road this month for a yearlong world tour, they wanted to kick it off where the band had its humble beginnings - the Australian pub. ``We're playing up in Queensland and places like that up in the north. Places that really don't get to see us that often, little towns you know,'' says Michael Hutchence, lead singer of the sextet. ``We could obviously do much bigger shows in Australia,'' says guitarist and keyboardist Andrew Farriss. ``But we feel it's a good way to start off the tour because it's grounding for us.'' The tour promoting their newly released ``X'' album will wind around the globe through Southeast Asia and Europe, reaching North America sometime in January. The first single from the album, ``Suicide Blond,'' is already scurrying up the charts. The song's title has spurred some confusion among listeners who wonder just what a suicide blond is. Hutchence explains that it's simply a term that was used in the 1940s for a shade of hair dye. ``It was hard times, everyone used to dye their hair with peroxide in the sink at home, so it was dyed by their own hands,'' Hutchence says. ``I thought that was an interesting case of semantics going on ... so I turned it into the song. It's actually much more positive than it sounds. It's not about suicide.'' ``X,'' with the bulk of the songs written by Hutchence and Farriss, is reminiscent of the rawness INXS has produced in previous albums - rhythmic rock mixed with a dab of funk. ``We're a hybrid, you know,'' Hutchence says proudly. And as the band's main songwriters, Hutchence, 30, and Farriss, 31, take their jobs seriously. ``You've got to move to music or music has to move you, or you shouldn't do it, in my opinion,'' says Farriss. ``You've got to be interested and want to move something around whether it's people's emotions, interest or loins or something of that nature.'' ``But we don't write something purely to dance to; there's a sense of rhythm, there's a sense of life,'' adds Hutchence. He warns that if you get too introverted in your approach to songwriting, you can ``get wigged out in sad, miserable tales.'' Rounding out INXS are Farriss' brothers, Jon and Tim, Kirk Pengilly and Garry Gary Beers. They began as a band out of Sydney called The Farriss Brothers in 1977, while most members were still in high school. They toured the Australian pub circuit, developing a huge following. The guys credit those pub days with giving them the power to negotiate contracts with record companies without compromising their own visions for the band. ``We were signed because we had created something already, we weren't made into anything and that's the way we've always run it,'' Hutchence says. ``No one has ever, ever run me and said to me or Andrew you better do this or do that. No one's ever told us to do anything.'' The band debuted in the United States in 1983 with the release of the single, ``The One Thing.'' But it was the 1985 multi-platinum album, ``Listen Like Thieves,'' that catapulted the group to widespread fame. The single from that album, ``What You Need,'' became the band's first Top 10 hit in the United States. Their next album, ``Kick,'' released in 1987, had the hits ``Need You Tonight,'' ``Devil Inside,'' ``New Sensation'' and ``Never Tear Us Apart.'' The band took a break after that album and follow-up tour. Some members spent the hiatus producing other acts and creating new bands. Hutchence, whose charismatic stage presence has been compared to the late Jim Morrison of ``The Doors,'' transformed his talents to the movie screen. He plays a small part in the yet-to-be released Roger Corman film, ``Frankenstein Unbound,'' starring John Hurt and Raul Julia. He also got raves for his first feature role in the 1986 Australian film ``Dogs in Space.'' ``I love films, I'm a real fan of films, I guess I aspire to that,'' says Hutchence, the only band member who makes his home outside of Australia. He resides in Hong Kong, where his British military father was stationed during part of his childhood. Hutchence also used the hiatus to put together ``Max Q,'' a group that garnered critical, but not popular, acclaim for its sole album. ``I thought it was going to be bigger than `Thriller,' it was going to be `Killer,' '' he jokes, referring to Michael Jackson's mega-hit album. The title of the latest album reflects the band's attitude toward simplicity. ``We didn't want something too wordy like `The Unbearable Lightness of Being,' '' says Farriss. ``We just wanted something simple. So it stands for whatever you want to make of it.'' The ``X'' could stand for the Roman numeral 10, signifying the 10th anniversary of the band's first album, ``INXS,'' or it could be a mocking jab at the music rating controversy, Hutchence suggests, although their own material does not push decency limits. The band members' belief in simplicity carries over to their attitude about live performances, which they say will be reflected in the tour. ``Our shows are more traditional,'' Hutchence says. ``We spend a lot of money on sound equipment and stage equipment. It'll look good, but really it's just a band playing and I think people appreciate that. ``We're not clowns. It's real.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: A Photographic Journey to Mississippi Delta's Juke Joints
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Though old ones close and new ones open, the juke joints of the Mississippi Delta persist, unique, individual, apparently oblivious of franchise America. These roadhouses - with such names as Magic City, Monkey's Place and the Out of Sight Club - appear all along the fertile basin of the river. The settings are rural, the clientele black. What they have in common are music, a jukebox usually, beer or harder stuff, and their regulars, the same faces this week as last. For most of America, these elemental pieces of the Delta puzzle are, if anything, ``another world ... in the midst of my own,'' as photographer Birney Imes says in a new book that collects his evocative pictures of the juke joints. Imes, a white Southerner whose work appears in the Museum of Modern Art, was referring generally to black culture, which he said he was ``only vaguely aware of'' before attending an integrated high school in the 1960s. ``When I began photographing six or seven years later,'' he adds, ``it was in part my wish and my need to overcome this ignorance that helped make my choice of subject an obvious one.'' Beginning by photographing people and scenes in rural Mississippi, he eventually came to see the juke joints as subjects. The result is ``Juke Joint'' (University Press of Mississippi, $39.95). The collection of 61 color photographs provides outsiders with a tantalizing look into these clubs, which beckon and forbid when one passes them on a country road. Their strings of year-round Christmas bulbs give off firefly light, their doors may open momentarily to release a yellow glow and a thudding, bluesy beat. It's the photos' ``capacity ... to be other than cultural snapshots'' that novelist Richard Ford appreciates. The Mississippian, author of ``The Sportswriter,'' analyzes the pictures' uncanny art in an introductory essay. Still, the peek in the jukes' door, the view of these private places that the pictures offer, is an undeniable part of the book's value. That's partly because in some cases the places depicted no longer exist. Beyond that, details in the corners of photographs help flesh out the lives of the mostly unseen juke joint patrons. Signs on the wall, often handwritten, reflect the local sense of humor or the approach here to problems seen everywhere. ``O Lord, Please help me keep my damn nose out of other people's business,'' says one sign, and next to it: ``No Dope. Please. Crack will kill you. Look at your buddy. He's dead, you no.'' In the homely decorations of many clubs that Imes portrays any reader quickly glimpses the notorious poverty of the region, as well as its legendary creativity. Some photos focus closely on brightly spraypainted interiors or homemade furniture. On a cracked wall of the Riverside Lounge in Shaw, Miss., somebody painted a large, floating bull in a style that strangely recalls the art of the cave paintings of France and Spain. ``What I see in Imes' photographs does not equal the human condition,'' Ford writes, ``only a human condition, a miniature advanced as art and meant to ease the adjustments between ourselves and the world by offering beauty, consolation, diversion, the satisfaction of direct address - all the usual enticements by which art dignifies and pleases us.'' It's risky to suggest where art originates, but part of what compells a reader to these pictures of places that are anything but glamorous comes from the light the photographer captures. In one photograph, a golden sunrise or sunset light bathes the torn tarpaper wall of the Pink Pony Cafe in Darling, Miss., and makes shadows, all in profile, of a line of people just outside the frame. The simultaneous presence and absence of people in many of the photos is another reflection of Imes' art. Some interior shots were exposed and printed so that furnishings, such as a pool table, appear in sharp focus while patrons, such as moving pool players, appear as blurs, almost as ghosts. No one is seen in a claustrophobic shot of a band's instruments, speakers, amplifiers and even drink glasses, but the reader almost hears the din of conversation between sets. Here and elsewhere in this collection ``the unknown,'' as Ford says, ``seems to have been put to use.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Christopher Sullivan is AP's Southern regional reporter, based in Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Nashville Sound: Matraca Berg a Feisty Newcomer
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Singer Matraca Berg is a feisty and defiant newcomer who slays the country music axiom ``stand by your man.'' In her well-crafted debut album, the 26-year-old firebrand ridicules her real-life ex-husband in ``The Things You Left Undone.'' In another autobiographical tune, ``Appalachian Rain,'' her real-life father, who helped conceive her without marrying her mother and then abandoned mother and child, is shot by her family. Berg says the song is true except for the shooting, which she describes as ``wishful thinking.'' The album is ``Lying to the Moon,'' a collection of rebellious country rockers and thoughtful ballads written by a woman, sung by a woman and definitely about women. So what does she put into her music? ``My heart and my soul,'' she said in an interview. ``That's exactly what I put into every song I write. And honesty.'' In the album, she repeatedly tells men ``goodbye,'' ``I don't love you'' and ``I can make it on my own.'' There's little acknowledgement of country queen Tammy Wynette's viewpoint in ``Stand by Your Man'' more than 20 years ago. The first single released from the album, ``Baby Walk On,'' is a rollicking tune asserting that a woman doesn't mind if her lover leaves the relationship. ``I Must Have Been Crazy'' is an up-tempo tune questioning why she loved someone. ``Lying to the Moon'' is a soft ballad about the pain from a misleading lover. It was written on the porch of a mountaintop cabin as she watched the moon rise and the mist form. Her songs are laden with romantic themes, drawn heavily from her personal life. ``I think we all go through trials and tribulations in love affairs,'' she said. ``I just happen to be writing about them. The songs are directed at a couple of guys in my life and not at men in general. ``I'm a reporter as a songwriter. I observe what other people go through and what I go through and I report it in the best way possible with the most empathy I can feel in the most undiluted fashion I can.'' Berg, whose first name is pronounced Muh-tray'-suh, has been writing hit songs since age 18 when she penned ``Faking Love,'' which was recorded by country singers T.G. Sheppard and Karen Brooks. She also wrote ``The Last One to Know,'' a No. 1 hit by country star Reba McEntire. She's been singing all along, with stops along the way with a Louisiana-based rock 'n' roll band and a spot in the movie ``Made in Heaven,'' in which she is discovered singing by actor Timothy Hutton. Berg, the daughter of the late Nashville recording session singer-songwriter Icee Berg, also sang with rock veteran Neil Young at the LiveAid concert in Philadelphia and other concerts. On ``Lying to the Moon,'' she enlisted and received the help of veteran singer Emmylou Harris, who provides backup vocals. ``She's pretty accessible, especially to young, new talent,'' Berg said. ``She contributed to making my year. She's a hero of mine so this was a high point in my career.'' Her mother, who died of cancer six years ago, never got to hear the folk-sounding song about her out-of-wedlock child and the fictional fate that befell the father. Berg said she'd be proud. ``I grew up realizing I was born an illegitimate child. My mother just never made a big deal about it. It's not such a no-no to me as maybe it would seem to other people,'' she said. ``My mother went through a lot of hard times back in the early '60s when this happened. I think it's a beautiful story worth writing about.'' She jests that ``The Things You Left Undone'' could be subtitled ``Ode to My Ex-Husband.'' He is a songwriter. The couple divorced last year after two years of marriage. ``It's a tongue-in-cheek kind of song. I dedicated it to him one night at a show. We are friends; we just couldn't live together. He owns his part of the bad deal and I own my part and we go on with it. He likes the song.'' Berg believes women are more enlightened than they were a generation ago and will welcome the viewpoint in her lyrics. ``Women are working now so their livelihood doesn't depend on this person that they are married to. So I think they tend to think more of themselves as a separate entity than they used to,'' she said. ``They are tougher in a lot of ways, so they stand up for themselves a lot more.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Oct. 19-21

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: ``Cats,'' Andrew Lloyd Webber's Tony award-winning musical, celebrated its eighth birthday on Sunday. Currently the fifth longest running show in Broadway history, ``Cats'' opened at the Winter Garden Theater on Oct. 7, 1982 and played its 3,340th performance Sunday. ``Cats'' opened originally in London's West End at the New London Theater on May 11, 1981, where it continues to play to capacity houses. In addition to the Broadway production at the Winter Garden Theater, and a national touring company, ``Cats'' has played or is currently playing in England, Japan, Germany, Hungary, Austria, Canada, Australia, Norway, Finland, the Netherlands, Sweden and France. ``Cats'' is the winner of seven 1983 Tony Awards, including Best Musical. ---= PHILADELPHIA (AP) - The Pennsylvania Ballet opens its 1990-91 Shubert Theater Season Oct. 24 with the popular fairy tale classic ``Coppelia.'' A family favorite, ``Coppelia'' is a charming love story set in a quaint Bavarian Village. It tells the tale of Toy Maker, Dr. Coppelius, who dabbles in wizardry and magic, bringing to life his many mechanical creations, including his precious doll, Coppelia. The Pennsylvania Ballet will present the full-length ballet Oct. 24-Nov. 4 at the Shubert Theater. This marks the first time since 1986 that the company has performed ``Coppelia.'' ---= WASHINGTON - Kevin Costner, co-producer, director and star of Orion Pictures' ``Dances With Wolves,'' will be honored by the Rosebud Sioux Tribal Nation in a ceremony known as the Hunka Ceremony at the film's world premiere. The ceremony will be conducted at a reception, as one of the highlights of a weekend of festivities surrounding the premiere of the film on Oct. 19. The premiere will benefit the Smithsonian Institution, which is dedicating the receipts from the evening to the building fund for the new Museum of the Native American, to open in 1998. ``Dance With Wolves'' is the story of a Civil War hero who becomes trapped between two worlds of a Sioux tribe and the white settlers. The movie opens in selected markets on Nov. 9.

America's unemployment rate worsened for the third straight month in September, the government said. The Labor Department reported Friday that the civilian jobless rate rose to 5.7 percent last month. Coupled with unemployment rises in July and August, marked the first time since the 1981-82 recession that the jobless rate has increased three months in a row, the government said. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Democratic leaders predicted that a new budget agreement easing Medicare cuts and tempering excise tax increases will be reached before the government shutdown takes full effect Tuesday. Democrats told their leaders Sunday to go ahead with a plan designed to let Democratic-controlled committees draft later the specifics for reaching $500 billion in deficit reduction over the next five years. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The failed federal budget accord slammed stock and bond prices but the markets recovered nearly all the lost ground, partly on President Bush's tough stance against Congress. In a lengthy night session, a rebellious House early Friday overwhelmingly defeated the $500-billion compromise package of tax increases and spending cuts sought by Bush and congressional leaders. Wall Street professionals had hoped for a budget accord to help reduce the amount of borrowing needed to pay the federal deficit and spur the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates. --- CHICAGO (AP) - The employee group trying to buy UAL Corp., the parent company of United Airlines, said that $2 billion in bank financing for its bid on Tuesday has fallen through. But the group will make a bid anyway, using a combination of cash and equity from other sources, Gerald Greenwald, chief executive officer of the United Employee Acquisition Corp. said Sunday He said substitute financing would come from company suppliers; sale-leaseback arrangements, in which the company sells equipment such as airplanes and leases them back; employee investments; and cash on hand. --- DEARBORN, Mich. (AP) - The United Auto Workers union and Ford Motor Co. reached a tentative national labor contract that closely follows a pattern agreement reached three weeks ago with General Motors Corp. Officials from the UAW and Ford said Sunday the tentative three-year agreement mirrored the contract reached Sept. 17 with GM and ratified a week ago by GM workers. But there were a few exceptions, including the maintenance of a two-week shutdown at Ford in July. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Charles Keating said he is innocent of a 42-count criminal indictment alleging fraud in junk bond sales through his failed Lincoln Savings & Loan. Keating and three co-defendants entered innocent pleas Friday to an array of charges accusing them of bilking investors in American Continental Corp. junk bonds sold through Lincoln branches. Keating, who has been unable to post $5 million bail, was then returned to jail. --- HARTFORD, Conn. (AP) - The Travelers Corp. said it is adding $650 million to its reserves to cover expected real estate losses, a move that will result in a third-quarter net loss of $500 million. The insurance company also said Friday it will reduce its quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share from 60 cents. The company said it was the first major addition to reserves since June 1988, when Travelers added $415 million to cover anticipated real estate losses. The latest increase boosts reserves to $1.15 billion at quarter's end. --- ST. LOUIS (AP) - Trans World Airlines Inc. sent layoff notices to 430 employees to cut its losses further in an industry hit hard by rising fuel prices and the slumping economy. A TWA spokesman said Frida that more layoffs, and possibly flight reductions, could come later. TWA, which has its hub in St. Louis, has about 33,000 employees worldwide. The spokesman said the layoffs were related to higher jet fuel prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. USAir Group Inc., Pan Am Corp. and Midway Airlines Inc. also have announced layoffs. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Federal Reserve policy-makers decided two weeks after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait to keep interest rates unchanged but to permit lower rates if economic conditions warranted, newly released records show. Short-term interest rates, which the Fed has used for two years in combatting inflation, did not change after the Aug. 21 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. They have remained at 8 percent since mid-summer. The Fed records were released Friday. --- LONDON (AP) - Dropping long-standing resistance, the government said it will link the pound to Europe's exchange rate mechanism, a move expected to help Britain's fight against inflation. The move Friday symbolized British willingness to participate in European integration, but Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher stressed her continued opposition to creating a single European bank and a single currency. ---

Stock prices fell Friday, but the market managed to minimize the damage from an early sell-off that followed the rejection of a government budget plan. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 6.19 to 2,510.64, reducing its gain for the week to 58.16 points. The dollar rose against most major currencies. Gold gained modestly. Bonds were little changed. Pork belly futures prices aimed for near-record prices; livestock futures and soybeans were mixed; wheat gained and corn was lower; and energy futures rose.

DOC.HEAD: Official Call on Recession Could Come Before Year's End
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs reprt.
DOC.TEXT: Geoffrey Moore is a referee who's not looking forward to his next call. He could blow the whistle on the longest economic expansion in U.S. peacetime history. Moore and six colleagues affiliated with the National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, Mass., will decide - perhaps before year's end - on whether the latest recession has begun. Many private economists believe a downturn is imminent - if it is not already here. And Moore said he expects his committee to decide before December whether the next downturn is under way. The current growth cycle, which would be eight years old in November, already has broken the previous peacetime record of 58 months, from March 1975 to January 1980. The all-time record of 106 months of economic growth ran from February 1961 to December 1969, a time period that included the Vietnam War. The last recession lasted from July 1981 to November 1982, according to Moore and his colleagues on the bureau's Business Cycle Dating Committee. The next would be the eighth that Moore has been involved in defining. ``I don't look forward to recessions,'' he says. ``I just try to identify them after they've started.'' The bureau, a private research organization of several hundred academic economists scattered around the world, has become recognized as the arbiter of business cycles. Founded in 1920, it is funded by corporate contributions and government and foundation grants. Its tables showing the extent of business growth and contraction since 1854 have been published regularly in Commerce Department publications beginning in 1961. ``That's what has made it `official,' more than anything else, that a government agency would use its data,'' Moore said in a recent interview. He retired from the bureau staff in 1979 after 40 years to become director of the Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University - a position he still holds at age 76. However, he still is affiliated with NBER. ``Their calls are widely accepted,'' said Adren Cooper, a Commerce Department spokesman. ``Since the NBER has been doing that ... there's been no controversy that I know of.'' The government itself does not announce the beginning and end of business cycles out of fear that it would be accused of making politically manipulated decisions. The NBER definition of a recession is more complicated than the often-used formula of two consecutive quarterly declines in the gross national product - the broadest measure of the nation's economic activity. That was coined by Arthur Okun, chairman of President Lyndon Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers. The NBER's broader definition is ``a recurring period of decline in total output, income, employment and trade, usually lasting from six months to a year and marked by widespread contractions in many sectors of the economy,'' bureau spokeswoman Donna Zeritz said. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan also uses a more complex definition of a recession. A recession is ``a cumulative process of deterioration in which events feed on each other,'' causing a major economic decline, he told Congress last month. ``A process in which the economy is deteriorating in a cumulative, interactive manner ... is a true recession.'' Although Greenspan and the Bush administration contend the economy is not now in a downturn, many private economists disagree, saying the economy began contracting during the current quarter. Others say a recession is likely before year's end. Moore describes the criteria for measuring a recession as ``the 3-D words: duration, depth and defusion.'' As for duration, the longest recession lasted 65 months, from October 1873 to March 1879. The shortest lasted six months, from January to July 1980. The Great Depression went on for 43 months, starting in August 1929 and ending in March 1933. In addition to duration, Moore said, ``we look at measures of aggregate economic activity such as non-farm employment, industrial production, real GNP, real income and real sales. ``We get a variety of measures of that sort and see whether the decline that's begun is comparable with the magnitude of previous cycles,'' he explained. Defusion, Moore said, means the decline is experienced widely and not contained in just one or two industries such as housing and automobiles. Joining Moore in deciding the peaks and troughs of business cycles are Martin Feldstein of Harvard University, the NBER president who became economic adviser to President Reagan as the nation was emerging from the last recession; Robert Hall, the committee chairman from Stanford University; William Branson of Princeton University; Benjamin Friedman of Harvard; Victor Zarnowitz of the University of Chicago Business School; and Robert Gordon of Northwestern University. The bureau also is credited with developing the Commerce Department's Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six months to nine months in advance.

The bureau includes the end of a recession and the beginning of a growth cycle in the same month: May 1937-June 1938, 13 months. February 1945-October 1945, 8 months. November 1948-October 1949, 11 months. July 1953-May 1954, 10 months. August 1957-April 1958, 8 months. April 1960-February 1961, 10 months. December 1969-November 1970, 11 months. DOC.HEAD: Saturn Heading into the Thick of the Market
Graphic
With BC-Saturn-Competition-Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. this week introduces its new Saturn line into a market some say is already crowded with cars in the $10,000-price range. No less than seven other manufacturers offering more than three dozen kinds of cars, including some of the best-selling vehicles in the United States, already are in the same ballpark as Saturn. ``Where does it fit in?'' said Herb Adcox, owner of Herb Adcox Chevrolet-Geo in Chattanooga, Tenn. ``There is no shelf space.'' Officials of Saturn Corp., a GM subsidiary established to help show the distinction of its cars from GM's others, said they're planning to get 80 percent of the corporation's projected annual sales of 250,000 cars from would-be import buyers. Auto analysts said the goals, especially the 80-percent import conquest rate, will be difficult to attain as foreign automakers, especially Japanese, grab larger shares of the shrinking U.S. auto market. At the end of September, Japanese automakers held about 28 percent of the U.S. car market. Based on price and other statistics, the four Saturn models will be competing against three models each of the Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance, six of the Ford Tempo, six of the Honda Civic, three of the Mazda Protege, seven of the Nissan Sentra and five of the Toyota Corolla. That's in addition to two models of the Chevrolet Cavalier and four of the Geo Prizm, both sold by Adcox and thousands of other GM dealers. The Cavalier was the third best-selling car in the 1990 model year and Civic was at No. 10. ``We've got dozens (of models) in that same (Saturn) price bracket,'' Adcox said. ``I don't know how in the world you are going to market a $10,000 to $12,000 car.'' Saturn's four models carry base prices between $7,995 and $11,775, without taxes, destination charges, options or other costs. Other cars in that price segment offer incentives, but Saturn isn't, for now at least. ``It's pretty clear that by starting out at $8,000 base, they fully intend to sell this vehicle without an incentive,'' said auto analyst Joseph Phillippi of Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York City. ``The last thing you want to do is taint the vehicle or its reputation by having to slap an incentive on the vehicle in weeks or months or a very short period after its introduction,'' he said. Selling a car without an incentive in the United States these days is a tough chore. In some cases, selling a car with an incentive is tough, too. For example, sales of the Chevrolet Cavalier through the first nine months totaled 222,980 cars, down 3.3 percent from last year. GM's latest incentive on the car is a $900 cash rebate. In addition to cash, some of Saturn's main competitors are giving away air conditioning and automatic transmissions. While Cavalier sales slipped, January-September sales for the Honda Civic, which carries no incentives, were up 11 percent, compared with last year, to 198,284 cars. Basically, Saturn officials are banking that their dealers' showrooms will be flooded with people who have bought import cars in the past, but feel guilty about shunning American manufacturers. Saturn wants to build a reputation quickly that its cars are more like imports than other GM models. Saturn's first round of advertising contains no references to it being a part of GM and the company is requiring that Saturn dealers erect separate dealerships for Saturn sales and service operations. It's the first time in 58 years that GM, the world's largest automaker, has created a new division. There are more than two dozen companies selling hundreds of kinds of cars in the United States - ranging from Yugos to Rolls Royces - all scrapping for parts of a shrinking market. Last week, foreign and domestic automakers reported car and truck sales that resulted in the worst model year in the industry since 1983. ``The real question for GM is what does this vehicle do to other GM products,'' Phillippi said. ``They've got to get a significant number of sales - three-fourths - from non-GM family brands.''

DOC.HEAD: Saturn and Its Competitors
With PM-Saturn-Competition
DOC.TEXT: Following are specifications for the new line of Saturn cars and its main competitors. The price range shows the low and high for base models, excluding destination charges, taxes, dealer preparation, options and so on.
