DOC.HEAD: Joint Soviet-Western Periodicals Carving Their Niche
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Shortly after the U.S.-Soviet business weekly Commersant hit the newsstands in January, government ministers started calling editorial offices to find out how to muzzle its sharp commentaries. ``When they found out we were independent, they kind of lost their bearings and gave up,'' said Vladimir Yakovlev, Commersant editor-in-chief. Commersant and two other new Soviet periodicals owe their independence in part to the policy of glasnost, or openness, and in part to their backing from investors in the United States and other Western countries. Unlike most Soviet publications, they are not affiliated with the Communist Party or government and are not subject to the same hierarchical pressures that Soviet bureaucrats are accustomed to applying. Commersant, backed by the U.S. investment company Refco, is the type of Soviet business that a visiting delegation from the New York Stock Exchange will be scrutinizing during a three-day meeting in Moscow this week. The tabloid provides a weekly barometer of the ups and downs of foreign enterprises' performances in the Soviet Union and critical features on Soviet economics. Although paper shortages have forced the government newspaper Izvestia to miss editions twice, Commersant has a supply contract with a private company, guaranteeing a steady flow of newsprint. Its Russian circulation is 350,000 and its English distribution is 30,000, Yakovlev said. Commersan recently went on sale in the United States. According to officials of the State Committee for the Press, joint ventures have filed 23 applications to start publications. Sixty applications have been filed by private individuals and 20 by political parties and public organizations, the officials said. Two glossy magazines - Moscow and Business in the U.S.S.R. - are building their circulations, and several pilot publications have appeared. Izvestia and Hearst Publications published a pilot issue of a new English-Russian newspaper on July 4 and hope to be issuing a regular edition next year. The weekly magazine Business Week brought out a dual language edition last summer and also hopes to publish regularly. Special one-time editions of Western magazines, including Ladies Home Journal and Paris Match, also have appeared in Soviet shops. Other joint venture magazines include New Farmer, an offshoot of the U.S.-based Rodale Press that could distribute in the Soviet Union next year to give Soviet farmers American agricultural know-how, and Russian Business Review, a quarterly to be published in 1991 by a Swiss-Soviet joint venture. Business in the U.S.S.R. is aimed at the emerging class of Soviet business leaders, said editor Vadim Biryukov. ``We want to hit the right guy, the economist, the factory director, the banker, the small businessman - anybody who deals with the economy,'' he said. Until recently, the term ``businessman'' was disparaging, Biryukov said. ``We are trying to change that. We clearly see all our readers, we talk to them, try to give them the courage to become businessmen, to be proud to be a businessman.'' In a step designed to open the door for joint-venture publishing, the Supreme Soviet parliament adopted a press law Aug. 1. Under the law, a new pubication can start after an application is filed and a regestration fee of 2,000 ($3,200) is paid in hard currency. That could pose a problem for Biryukov, who founded the magazine earlier and may end up paying twice. ``We registered before the law was adopted, now we have to register again,'' he complained. ``We haven't had time to earn that kind of money.'' Business in the U.S.S.R. published its sixth issue in October. With a circulation of 100,000 editions in Russian and 50,000 in English, the magazine relies heavily on advertising for hard currency revenues. Moscow magazine is patterned after the trendy, glossy publications that thrive in big American cities. ``We are styled a little after city magazines, like New York,'' said editor Derk Sauer, a Dutchman. But ``we are not a copy of New York. They are a lifestyle magazine, and there's not a lot of lifestyle here in Moscow,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pound's Link Could Spur European Monetary Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Britain's long-delayed entry into Europe's exchange rate mechanism could spur the European Community's move toward economic and monetary union, but for Margaret Thatcher the immediate motives are closer to home, analysts say. Linking the pound to other European currencies should stabilize the pound's exchange rate, help fight inflation and bring down interest rates, which could improve the prime minister's chances of winning a fourth consecutive term. But the price of joining the so-called ERM could be a further crimp on an already slowing economy and a rise in unemployment. The government announced Friday it would link the pound to the mechanism on Monday. The government also said Britain's 15 percent interest rates would come down a full percentage point the same day. Under the mechanism, Britain's currency will be allowed to fluctuate no more than 6 percent from an agreed-upon exchange rate. Putting a floor under the pound gives Mrs. Thatcher room to cut high interest rates - unpopular with both homeowners and businesses - before she must call an election by mid-1992. ``It was becoming urgent for the government to get interest rates down if they were going to stop the next election being lost on the recession issue,'' Robin Aspinall, analyst at the London investment firm Hoare Govett Ltd. Britain already is in a mild recession, the business community and opposition Labor Party say. No, it isn't, the government argues. Mrs. Thatcher likes a strong pound because it adds up to tighter monetary policy. It fights inflation by forcing companies to keep export prices competitive by keeping wages and other costs down. But as a strong pound forces export prices higher, it becomes harder for British companies to compete overseas. Corporate profits can fall and jobs can be lost. ``Yes, ERM would impose a small discipline for bringing inflation down, but it does so at the expense of growth,'' said Avinash Persaud, a monetary economist at the London investment firm UBS Phillips and Drew. Britain becomes the tenth of the 12 European Community currencies to enter the exchange rate mechanism. Currencies of Britain and Spain are allowed to flucutate 6 percent from the agreed rate and the others are allowed to swing 2.25 percent in either direction. Still outside the mechanism are the Portuguese escudo and Greek drachma. Central banks of ERM member countries are required to buy or sell currencies to keep the exchange rate within the prescribed band. The ERM is intended to provide stable exchange rates that make business planning easier and reduce disruptions to economic strategies of the EC and its member states. After years of pressure from ERM advocates, Mrs. Thatcher in June 1989 promised to join once British inflation fell closer into line with the EC average of 5.5 percent, and once capital flowed freely in Europe. Britain has decided to join even though inflation stands at 10.6 percent because the rate is headed downward, Mrs. Thatcher said Friday. She has kept interest rates at 15 percent for a year to fight inflation by slowing consumer demand. ``The fact that our policies are working and are seen to be working have made both these decisions possible,'' she said. Entering the mechanism would ``underpin our anti-inflationary stance,'' she said. Britain said the pound would enter the ERM at a rate of 2.95 German marks. By entering, Britain fulfilled its commitment to the first part of a three-stage plan for the economic and monetary union of the EC nations. But while spurring monetary union, the move also strengthened Mrs. Thatcher's hand in fighting the next two stages - a single currency and central banking system. ``It will make the path . . . easier,'' said Geoffrey Dicks, who teaches at the London Business Schol. ``But it also will give the U.K. a stronger base from which to launch its serious criticisms.'' Instead of a single currency, Britain has proposed turning the European Currency Unit into a 13th, common European currency to be used alongside the existing 12 EC currencies.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Britain-Pound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Here, in question-and-answer form, is an explanation of Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism, or ERM. What is the ERM? It is a feature of the European Monetary System that limits the fluctuations of European Community currencies. Why was it set up? It was set up in March 1979 to prevent disruptive exchange rate swings. The fixed exchange rates which had supported European economies since World War II had broken down and the floating rates were creating havoc for the 12-nation Community. Who belongs to the ERM? With newly joining Britain, 10 EC countries. Still to join are Portugal and Greece. How does the ERM work? The ERM limits how much the currencies can move up or down against one another. Most of the members observe a margin of 2.25 percent above or below agreed rates. But Britain and Spain use a 6 percent band, which gives their governments more breathing space. How do countries keep their currencies within those bands? Central banks intervene, buying or selling currencies or changing their interest rates. Does it always work? No. Sometimes inflation or other economic conditions threaten to push a currency beyond its band. When that happens, the members realign the system by mutual agreement, changing the basic rates of one or more currencies to relieve the pressure. There have been 14 rate or band realignments since 1979. The last was on Jan. 8, when Italy switched from the 6-percent to the 2.25 percent band. Does the ERM affect European exchange rates against the dollar? It has no direct bearing on these currencies' values against non-EC currencies.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Reaches Tentative Pact With Ford; Prepares for Chrysler Negotiations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DT1
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union and Ford Motor Co. have tentatively agreed on a national labor contract nearly identical to one reached with General Motors Corp. last month. The three-year agreement reached with Ford on Sunday - like the one reached with GM - includes a 3 percent pay raise in the first year, lump-sum payments of 3 percent of wages in the second and third years, an income guarantee for laid-off workers and no change in health-care benefits. If the pact wins final approval, the union will turn its attention to the last of the Big Three domestic automakers, Chrysler Corp., said UAW President Owen Bieber. He added that he isn't worried about comments Chrysler officials made after the GM contract was negotiated that they would have trouble affording the same deal. The No. 3 U.S. automaker's third-quarter losses promise to wipe out the $251 million it earned in the first two quarters of this year. ``I don't get all shook up with them telling me how bad they are,'' Bieber said Sunday. He added that the pace of talks between the UAW and Chrysler would pick up soon, but said he wasn't sure when he would go to Chrysler's headquarters in Highland Park. ``We're going to go to Chrysler as soon as we get the work done here,'' he said. UAW's 135-member Ford bargaining council meets in Dearborn on Tuesday for briefings on the Ford pact by Bieber and UAW Vice President Ernie Lofton, who heads the union's Ford Department. The group of presidents and heads of bargaining committees from the UAW's 44 locals at 79 Ford locations nationwide must approve the contract before it is sent to the approximately 100,000 members for a ratification vote. Lofton said he wants to have the ratification process finished by Oct. 21. The agreement with GM was ratified by the company's workers in an 80 percent to 20 percent vote announced a week ago. Among the provisions of the contracts the UAW negotiated with GM and Ford are: -A 3 percent increase in base wages in the first year and lump-sum payments of 3 percent of wages in the second and third years with no changes in the cost-of-living protections for wages. -A commitment by the companies to fully pay employees laid off for more than 36 weeks during the next three years because of sales slumps. GM said it would spend up to $4 billion and Bieber estimated that the Ford commitment would be about $1.5 billion. -Two lump-sum payments to retirees totaling $1,260. -A new schedule of penalties for scheduling excessive overtime ranging up to $5 an hour. The previous maximum was $1.25 an hour. -No change in health-care provisions. The overtime penalty appeared to be the most worrisome to Ford as talks accelerated last week. Ford makes more liberal use of overtime than GM or Chrysler. But the overtime penalty doesn't appear to be a problem in the near future because car and truck sales are down and economic recovery doesn't appear to be close at hand, said Ford Chairman Harold Poling.

DOC.HEAD: Motorists Paying 6 Cents Per Gallon More at the Pump
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Persistent uncertainty about possible war in the Persian Gulf and fear of crude oil shortages sent retail gas prices upward an average 6 cents per gallon over the past two weeks, an industry analyst says. Since the Iraqi invasion of oil-rich Kuwait in early August, the average price of gasoline nationwide has jumped 26{ cents a gallon at the pump. Since the crisis began, an international embargo has blocked all Iraqi oil exports. The sale of Kuwaiti oil also was banned to prevent Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein from making money on appropriated crude oil reserves. Increases in oil market prices were passed on to consumers quickly. ``The cause, of course, is the continued pass-through of higher crude oil prices, which is driven by fears of shortages due to confrontation in the Middle East,'' analyst Trilby Lundberg said Sunday in a telephone interview. The latest biweekly Lundberg Survey of 13,500 gasoline stations nationwide showed the overall price of gas for all grades, including taxes, was 144.20 cents per gallon. The survey was taken Friday. The average price was 5.84 cents higher than the average derived from a Sept. 21 Lundberg sampling, she said. The Lundberg Survey's overall average price on July 20 - the latest pre-invasion sample - was nearly $1.18 a gallon. ``The price increases have really put on speed,'' said Lundberg, adding that she was unable to predict whether prices would continue their upward spiral. ``It's entirely dependent on what the crude oil market does,'' Lundberg said. ``It's insecurity, but not a world shortage. The sensitivity of the market is tremendous.'' The survey taken Friday showed the average price of regular leaded gasoline, including taxes, at self-serve pumps was 130.59 cents per gallon. At full service stations, regular leaded averaged 152.21 cents. Self-serve unleaded was 133.56 cents per gallon, and full-service unleaded was 155.11. Premium unleaded was 149.95 cents per gallon at self-serve and 168.79 at full service. Lundberg notes self-service customers represent more than 80 percent of gasoline sales. ``The full service prices really represent a specialty service that not too many use,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Stocks Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar plummeted to a 1{-year low against the Japanese yen in heavy trading today because of rising pessimism over the U.S. economy, traders said. Stock prices soared. The U.S. currency dropped 3.67 yen from Friday's close, ending the day at 130.05 yen. It was the dollar's lowest closing level since March 15, 1989, when it ended at 129.88 yen. The dollar also fell against European currencies. Toshiaki Kakimoto, a senior analyst with Sumitomo Bank, said investors unloaded the dollar because of a belief the U.S. Federal Reserve will lower interest rates following Friday's release of worsening U.S. labor statistics. He said the failure to reach a deficit-reduction accord also added to pessimism. ``These factors made investors think that U.S. economic fundamentals are not likely to improve,'' Kakimoto said. A narrowing interest rate gap between the two countries also made the dollar less attractive, analysts said. Compared to Friday's 7.94 percent Federal Funds rate, Japan's counterpart call rate was only slightly lower at 7.65 percent today. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average rose 802.35 points, or 3.51 percent, ending the day at 23,630.00 in moderate trading. The closely watched index rose 549.46 points on Friday. Volume on the market's first section was estimated at 400 million shares, compared with Friday's 450 million. Stock prices soared as investors, encouraged by the stronger yen and rising bond prices, went bargain hunting. Traders said index-linked buying also helped to send stock prices higher. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese bonds closed higher at 83.54, up from Friday's 82.90. Their yield ended at 8.020 percent, down from Friday's 8.170 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Financing Falls Through on UAL Bid
DOC.TEXT: The employee group trying to buy UAL Corp., the parent of United Airlines, says it has failed for the second time in two months to get bank financing, but it plans a bid Tuesday using money from other sources. One analyst gave the endeavor little chance of success and said the waning value of the group's offer is beginning to resemble ``a K mart blue-light special.'' Gerald Greenwald, chief executive officer of the United Employee Acquisition Corp., announced Sunday that the $2 billion in bank financing his group had hoped to assemble had disintegrated. He blamed tight credit and economic uncertainties following the Persian Gulf crisis. The group instead will use a combination of cash and equity from other sources to meet a Tuesday deadline to offer a bid, he said. Greenwald declined comment on how much the bid would total. A statement from his group said only that it would be substantially higher than the current price of UAL stock, which closed at $102.75 a share Friday on the New York Stock Exchange. Substitute financing is to come from company suppliers; sale-leaseback arrangements in which the company sells equipment such as airplanes and leases them back; employee investments and cash on hand, Greenwald said. ``We're trying to come to the board with - in total - an equally attractive package,'' he said in a telephone interview from New York. ``We are trying to make up the shortfall in cash with some other features.'' But analyst Stephen Dexter of Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago said he believes it will be very difficult to persuade suppliers to finance the deal and also to sell the board on an inevitably lower buyout offer than the $165 to $175 per share the group was believed to have been readying. ``It's starting to look like a K mart blue-light special,'' he said. ``You're marking down the price and marking down the price until finally you get financing.'' Two months ago, when the board granted the employee group an extension to arrange financial backing, the employees were working on a $201-a-share offer. That was far less than the $300-a-share bid that pilots and management were trying to put together a year ago when financing collapsed. Whatever the bid, the price should be higher than the value of rival American Airlines - about $3.8 billion, Dexter said, particularly since taking a company private should add a premium to the price. If the United employees offered $165 to $175 a share, the total would amount to $3.6 billion to $3.8 billion. ``The two (United and American) are very similar in size, very similar in domestic networks. But United has the real jewel of the airlines industry - the Pacific division,'' Dexter said. ``It's much more profitable than the domestic or Atlantic division. You should be paying more for that, not less. If board members take out their pocket calculators, they're going to find it just doesn't compute.'' Dexter said if the board rejects the bid on Tuesday, he believes the employee-buyout effort is ``a dead deal.'' Greenwald said the banks were attracted by the deal but concerned about economic uncertainties. ``Some of the banks who declined to participate said, `Yours is the best proposal and most tempting one we've seen all year, but we're just very worried about the economy,' '' Greenwald said.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Production at Pre-Crisis Quota Levels
DOC.TEXT: Extra production by OPEC members in September made up for 3 million of the 4 million barrel-a-day loss caused by the Iraq-Kuwait crisis, the Middle East Economic Survey reported Monday. But the respected newsletter said the world still faces a shortfall in the fourth quarter of this year. Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries produced an average 22.49 million barrels a day in September, the Nicosia-based oil newsletter said. In July the cartel was producing 23.5 million barrels a day. Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and the world embargo on exports from those two major producers, cut 4 million barrels a day from OPEC quota exports. The Middle East Economic Survey said in September the increased production came from Saudi Arabia with an extra 2.1 million barrels a day, Venezuela 305,000, Nigeria 260,000, Iran 250,000 and Libya 100,000. ``It should not be forgotten that the world production system is operating at a very full stretch,'' the newsletter said. It said OPEC crude production of 22.5 million barrels a day compared with projected demand by the International Energy Agency of 23.9 million barrels a day in the fourth quarter. This would leave a need for consumers to draw down existing reserve stocks of 1.4 million barrels a day in the quarter. Saudi Arabia's oil minister Hisham Nazer has estimated world reserve stocks at 700 million barrels. The Middle East Economic survey said, however, that Saudi Arabia plans to increase its production another 300,000 barrels a day to 7.8 million barrels a day in October ``with possible further increments to be forthcoming in future months.'' The newsletter said total OPEC production might be increased by 500,000 barrels a day to 23 million by the end of the year, mainly from Saudi Arabia.

The stock market chalked up a broad gain today amid revived hopes for action to narrow the federal budget deficit. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 31.44 points to 2,542.08 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 803 up, 237 down and 342 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 16.57 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The House passed a new budget plan overnight, raising an alternative to the proposal that was rejected in Congress last week. Analysts said investors were hopeful that an agreement would be reached soon on a budget aimed at narrowing the gap between the government's revenues and spending. Brokers also said traders' spirits got a lift from gains in several foreign stock markets, from Tokyo to London. Activity was muted, however, by the absence of many market participants who were taking a Columbus Day holiday. Among actively traded blue chips, Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing rose \ to 78|; International Business Machines 1[ to 109]; Philip Morris { to 48\, and General Electric | to 54~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.68 to 172.38. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .68 at 307.16. On Friday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 6.19 to 2,510.64, reducing its gain for the week to 58.16 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 3 to 2 on the NYSE, with 588 up, 903 down and 460 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 153.38 million shares, against 145.41 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Sugar Prices Leveling Off
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead in 2nd item to DELETE word `animals' because 1,000 refers to herds, sted individual animals; also on general news wires. ^By DON KENDALL
DOC.TEXT: Consumer sugar prices are starting to level off, and Agriculture Department analysts say domestic and global supplies are large enough to help dampen them for a while. ``On the world level, it looks like prices should stay about where they're at,'' says Peter Buzzanell of the department's Economic Research Service. ``The reason is that we see more of a balance in world supply and demand.'' Buzzanell said in a telephone interview that ``growth in consumption out paced production (and) led to an upturn in prices'' in the last several years. However, he said, the price of raw sugar delivered to Caribbean ports lately has been just a little more than 10 cents per pound, compared to the 13 or 14 cents a few months ago. In the United States, Buzzanell said, the 1990 sugar cane crop was hit by poor weather, but the sugar beet harvest is expected to be improved from last year. Sugar consumption by Americans is still growing, but ``not at a sharp rate,'' he said. ``So, with our new (import) quota, we're anticipating that we'll have a balanced situation - and prices about where they are or, hopefully, softening a little bit.'' Buzzanell was asked to comment on a new sugar outlook report issued last week by the USDA agency. In it, analysts noted that retail prices of refined sugar in the United States averaged 41.8 cents per pound in the first nine months of the 1990 fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, up 2.7 cents from the same period in 1989. The July average was 42.7 cents per pound, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and it edged up to 43.3 cents in August. The September prices have not yet been announced. Total domestic sugar production in the crop year that began Sept. 1 is estimated currently at 6.47 million short tons of 2,000 pounds each, raw value, down 113,000 tons from 1989-90 production. Beet sugar output was estimated at 3.77 million tons, up 11 percent from the drought and freeze-damage crop of 1989-90. But cane sugar production is expected to be only 2.7 million tons, down 15 percent because severe freeze damage and drought in Louisiana. A new ``tariff-rate quota'' was announced on Sept. 14 by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. Under it, the United States will import slightly more than 1.9 million tons of raw sugar during the year that began Oct. 1. Under the new system, a two-tiered quota level is used, allowing a fixed amount of sugar into the United States at a relatively low duty rate of 0.625 cents per pound, and additional imports at a much higher duty, an additional 16 cents per pound. The so-called TRQ system replaces an absolute quota which had regulated U.S. sugar imports since 1982, the report said. Australia had complained about the earlier method of quotas, and the United States was found to be in violation of rules under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The TRQ method puts the United States in compliance under GATT, the report said. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The number of cattle herds under quarantine for brucellosis has edged below 1,000 for the first time since the eradication program began nearly 60 years ago. According to Agriculture Department officials, at the beginning of September there were 959 cattle herds quarantined for the disease, down from 1,005 herds a month earlier. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, reducing the quarantine herds to below 1,000 ``marks a significant point'' in the history of the cooperative state-federal program against brucellosis. ``In the early 1930s, when eradication efforts first started, 5 percent of the nation's cattle herds were estimated to be infected with brucellosis, a disease that causes abortions and lowers milk production,'' he said. ``By the late 1950s, there were nearly 124,000 herds under quarantine. By 1980, this had been cut to 7,074; by 1985 to 4,533.'' Currently, 29 states and the U.S. Virgin Islands have been declared free of brucellosis. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Rising milk production has boosted the output of butter and other dairy products, according to a monthly report by the Agriculture Department. In August, butter production was estimated at 83.8 million pounds, up 4 percent from August 1989, the report said. Total cheese production was reported at 488 million pounds, up 7 percent from a year earlier, and non-fat dry milk for human food was estimated at 62.9 million pounds, a 20 percent increase. Milk production in 1990 is forecast at a record 147.7 billion pounds, compared with 144.3 billion last year and the previous high of 145.2 billion pounds in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Jumps By 17, Back With Seasonal Routine
DOC.TEXT: Texas and Oklahoma led an increase in the number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States, which rose 17 this week to 1,064, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. The Houston-based toolmaker reported Monday the count was up from last week's 1,047, and was above the number for the same week a year ago when 960 rigs were working across the country. The rise for the week was led primarily by Oklahoma, which reported a gain of six rigs for the week, and Texas, which reported a gain of four. ``Seasonally, this is the time when the rig count rises,'' said I.C. Kerridge, a Baker Hughes vice president and keeper of the count. Kerridge said the rig count dropped the last two weeks and ``this may be getting back on the seasonal track.'' Baker-Hughes has kept track of the rig count - the widely watched index of drilling activity - since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Kerridge said higher oil prices have not yet affected the rig count but said a 9 percent jump in workover rigs - used for routine maintenance on producing rigs - was attributable to the higher prices. ``We're looking for a strong fourth quarter,'' Kerridge said. ``People would like to see some stability and oil prices staying at a reasonably high level. If that continues, will see increases in the rig count.'' Besides Oklahoma and Texas, other major oil producing states that reported gains for the week included Colorado, up two; Louisiana, up four; New Mexico, up three; and Pennsylvania, up one. Among states reporting a loss in drilling activity for the week were California, down two; Kansas, down one; Ohio, down one; and Wyoming, down five. North Dakota's rig count was unchanged.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 348.12 up .76 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: DETROIT: he says.
DOC.TEXT: Before the referendum passed, comedian Jay Leno, on national television, poked fun at the system's $1 million how-to-be-more-frugal study. Until 1988, school board members were driven to meetings by chauffeurs. It isn't just money. An April attendance report showed that only 21 schools had 90 percent to 94 percent attendance each day. A dress code took effect this fall, a measure to curb violence such as the shooting of an Osborn High School student over his $135 jacket, and the slaying of a Kettering High School student who was stripped of his coat and $70 sneakers. Mayoral spokesman Bob Berg says racism is part of the city's trouble. ``The city's about 70 percent black; the suburbs are white,'' he says. ``There are people who brag about not coming downtown in years. They say it's not racial. But it is.'' Detroit's black population soared from 28.9 percent to 63.1 percent between 1960 and 1980, census data shows. Detroit's 1980 black population was the largest among the nation's 10 major cities. The racial divide between Detroit and its suburbs is deepening, as it is in Chicago, Baltimore and Gary, Ind., according to the University of Michigan's 38th Detroit Area Study, its most recent. ``The social segregation is astonishing,'' says Steven Rosenstone of the Ann Arbor school's Center for Political Studies. Macomb, Oakland and Wayne counties are 92.2 percent white, compared with 75.1 percent black in Detroit. Detroit's 20.6 percent unemployment includes people who have given up looking for jobs. A third of Detroiters surveyed lacked access to a car in good condition, meaning ``blacks cannot get out to the better-paying jobs.'' ``I think things are going to get worse before it gets better,'' Rosenstone says. What Detroit needs is jobs, says Berg, explaining Mayor Young's sometimes controversial strategies - knocking down a neighborhood for a Chrysler Corp. plant, plans to demolish another neighborhood to expand the airport and to exploit the free trade pact, encouraging more riverfront development such as the downtown Renaissance Center complex. Detroit is lifting itself from the doldrums of population decay, auto industry slumps and a bad image, say Hubbard and Berg. During last October's Devil's Night, about 30,000 residents from an array of community groups patrolled the streets to dampen the annual arson spree. The Detroit Civic Center hosted 14 percent more business in 1989 over 1988, an increase to 8.4 million visitors. A survey of 24 major metropolitan areas by national accounting firm Grant Thornton found Detroit's economy advanced in the 1989 fourth quarter to its highest in five years. The racial controversy over a white woman heading the council of a mostly black city ended with Maryann Mahaffey's election last fall to council president. The Detroit Pistons, who play their home games 30 miles north of downtown, won their second straight NBA champsionship. Ten years from now, Detroit ``will be more of an information and service industry for manufacturing. We'll be more of a convention industry,'' Hubbard says, stressing the need to shift from the cyclical auto industry that has dominated and determined much of Detroit's past. And the city might just make it over the 1-million mark in the census count, Neithercut says. Berg says there are easily 30,000 Detroiters missed by the count. `II think all this is going to turn around. I think the movement to the suburbs will collapse. You can't have a rotten core in the doughnut,'' Rich says. ``The same economic forces working on the city will work on them. ``People in the suburbs will realize they don't want those overpriced homes and they'll reclaim the city,'' Rich says, pointing to the so-called ``gentrification'' of Washington, D.C. ``Detroit is not going to be the Bangladesh of the Midwest.''

DOC.HEAD: Hungary: IBM's Window on the East
With BC-Computers-Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: IBM Hungary is the giant computer company's window on the East. The subsidiary was one of the few Western companies to weather more than four decades of communism in Hungary. Now it is serving as IBM's model for expansion in the rest of Eastern Europe. Perhaps the reason communist authorities allowed a little bit of capitalism to survive all those years is that it filled a vital need: It serviced IBM machines that were used to perform the census and other record-keeping, said Eugen K. Hahn, managing director of Eastern European operations for International Business Machines Corp. ``We took care of the equipment, so we protected the investment the government made,'' he said in an interview at IBM's modernistic headquarters building in a residential neighborhood. IBM Hungary employs nearly 100 people, all Hungarians, to sell and service the company's products. Zsuzsa Branyik, who resigned as general manager of IBM Hungary in April after about 20 years, recalled how the subsidiary managed to survive during the communist years even though it was limited largely to servicing equipment, not selling new machines. At one point in the 1960s, even the service operation was shut down and the engineers transferred to the state. But in the early 1970s, the company was given back its employees and began to flourish. ``It would be wonderful for me to work today - so many things are much, much easier,'' said Mrs. Branyik, the only female head of a country organization IBM has ever had. IBM has sales and service representatives throughout the former East bloc, but it wants to establish a greater presence in these nations along the lines of IBM Hungry, Hahn said. To increase its presence, IBM has donated computers to universities in several Eastern European nations as part of what it calls its academic initiative. In exchange, the universities are expected to develop software and ties to local industry. IBM also plans to tie these universities together in a computer network, and then link that network to the West - one of the first such computer connections in the former East bloc, Hahn said.

DOC.HEAD: Dream Launch for Publisher Who Broke Away
DOC.TEXT: Christopher Sinclair-Stevenson, a courteous Old Etonian in the tough world of British publishing, broke away to set up on his own after 28 years with one company and struck gold with his first book. Sinclair-Stevenson Ltd. sold 60,000 copies of a life of ever-popular Charles Dickens in less than two weeks at 19.95 pounds ($37.70) each. The sales sent ``Dickens'' to second place on The Sunday Times best-seller list, behind a book on cricket. But what shook the book trade was the large sum of 650,000 pounds (nearly $1.3 million) offered by the fledgling independent publisher to Peter Ackroyd, an admired writer who tackled Dickens after doing other literary lives, some in novel form. ``It was an unusually large amount of money, but Ackroyd has a good reputation and track record and the offer also covers a book he is writing about William Blake,'' the publisher said. Sinclair-Stevenson, 51, talked in the office he set up with a staff of 10 in a charming Kensington mews. He launched his company and the Dickens book Sept. 3, just over a year after leaving the respected hardback publishing house of Hamish Hamilton, his only employer since he left Cambridge University with a modern languages degree. His last 15 years with the firm were spent as managing director. He didn't like the changed atmosphere when the firm, which had earlier been sold to the Canada-based Thomson group, was sold again to Penguin, the giant paperback publisher. From friends and contacts he raised 2.4 million pounds ($4.5 million) to start his own company. When authors whose books he edited found he was leaving they went with him, including Ackroyd. Sinclair-Stevenson is steering clear of paperback publishing, and a large slice of Ackroyd's advance came from selling the paperback rights in Dickens to other companies. Sales of the hardback should comfortably make up the balance, he said. The new publisher's first catalog is half fiction and the rest mostly travel, memoirs and contemporary history. Well-known writers such as Paul Theroux, A.N. Wilson and J.K. Galbraith are on the list, and of the 27 books, 20 are by authors from his old employers. He handled most of the Hamish Hamilton authors who were finalists over the years for the Booker Prize, the literary event of the year in Britain. ``Most people thought William Boyd, who was a finalist in 1982 with `An Ice-Cream War,' should have been nominated again this year for `Brazzaville Beach,' which we submitted. We will be in some difficulty next year deciding which three of our novelists to put in,'' the publisher said. Publishing is big business. Total book sales in Britain were worth 2.2 billion pounds ($4.1 billion) last year. Book exports amounted to a further 655 million pounds ($1.2 billion). The industry is dominated by about a dozen companies, among them, Macmillan, the Oxford and Cambridge university presses and HarperCollins and News International, which belong to media magnate Rupert Murdoch. Publishing has changed vastly from the days when it was considered a leisurely occupation for gentlemen. Revered imprints have disappeared while others cling to their identities in the embrace of multinationals and conglomerates. ``I think publishers take over other publishers to stop other publishers taking them over. When they become big they want to be strongly based everywhere,'' Sinclair-Stevenson said. ``A big organization has clout in the marketplace. It can afford expensive authors, has more power in dealing with bookshops and a bigger presence in the publishing world,'' he said. ``Corporate life is very different to that of an independent publisher. I began to feel the imperatives in the Penguin group were systems rather than books. ``Editors are concerned with publishing and selling but conglomerates keep looking at their internal affairs. They work to dotted lines, call meetings and tell people what to do. Their authors get missed out,'' he said. ``When I left in July 1989, a lot of the authors I was handling were my personal friends and I suppose they thought I was a good publisher and would do their future books well. I think they felt that once I'd gone, their connection with Hamish Hamilton ceased: They wouldn't know anyone there.'' Writers are important, Sinclair-Stevenson said. ``They lead rather lonely lives. They are not going to an office every day and they need encouraging to write and to live as well. I like to publish authors I know and like. I find it difficult to publish authors I don't like.'' He thinks the spate of mergers isn't good for publishing. ``It concentrates too much power in too few hands, narrows the choice for the author and reduces the contact between the author, his agent and the publishers,'' he said. ``I think we did `Dickens' as well as any conglomerate and possibly better, because it's our lifeblood. ``We are hungrier,'' he said. ``We have no fat to live off.''

DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones Profit Down
DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Co., publisher of The Wall Street Journal, on Monday said net income declined during the third quarter and the year's first nine months as the acquisition of Telerate Inc. weighed on profits. Net income for the quarter ended Sept. 30 totaled $23.76 million, or 24 cents a share, down 17.5 percent from $28.81 million, or 29 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Revenue for the quarter totaled $408.54 million, up 1.1 percent from $404.08 million a year ago. The company said net income for the quarter was reduced 11 cents - and 34 cents for the year to date - due to higher expenses related to the acquisition of Telerate, which was completed in January. Dow Jones also said operating results were distorted by development costs for Telerate's electronic foreign exchange trading system. This year Dow Jones bore 100 percent of the costs; last year the company shared the cost with a 50 percent partner. Revenue rose 5.6 percent to $185.11 million within the company's information services unit, which includes Telerate, but operating income within the segment was down 36.1 percent at $35.01 million in part because of retrenchment within the financial services industry. On the publishing front, Dow Jones said operating income from its business publications, including the Journal, Barron's magazine and others, fell 79.6 percent to $2.72 million on a 3.6 percent decline in revenue, which totaled $165.84 million. Advertising lineage at the Journal declined 16 percent during the period. Ottaway Newspapers Inc., the community newspaper subsidiary, saw a 7.4 decline in operating income, which totaled $2.72 million, on $59.59 million in revenue, which represented a 1.5 percent gain from the third quarter of 1989. For the first nine months, Dow Jones said net income totaled $83.51 million, or 83 cents a share, down 69.9 percent from $277.17 million, or $2.75 a share in the year-ago period. Excluding a one-time gain in 1989, net income for the first nine months declined 26.1 percent. Revenue for the first nine months totaled $1.28 billion, up 2.3 percent from $1.25 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Higher

DOC.TEXT: Share prices in London closed moderately higher Monday on record turnover, as market confidence was bolstered by Britain's decision to join the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed up 57.7 points, or 2.6 percent, at 2,201.6. A high of 2,283.7 was recorded at the opening of trading. The Financial Times 30-share index closed up 50.1 points at 1,705.7, compared to 1,655.6 Friday. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 32.13 points to close at 1,165.09. Volume was a record 1.085 billion shares traded, compared to 447.8 million shares traded Friday. The day's turnover broke the previous single-session record of 997.3 million shares on July 9, 1987. The government announced Friday its decision to join the exchange rate mechanism and to lower interest rates by a full percentage point to 14 percent. The moves touched off heavy buying in Britain's financial markets.

DOC.SECOND: Execs Named At Time, Sports Illustrated
DOC.TEXT: Sports Illustrated Publisher Donald J. Barr on Monday was named an executive vice president of Time Inc. Magazine Co., and the company promoted two veteran editors of the sports weekly. Barr, 55, joined Time in 1957 and had served as publisher of Sports Illustrated for the past five years. A graduate of the University of Notre Dame, he will join the company's corporate policy committee and report directly to Time Chairman and President Reginald K. Brack Jr. Mark R. Mulvoy steps up as publisher of Sports Illustrated from his post as managing editor. Mulvoy, 49, began his career as a reporter for the magazine in 1965. Succeeding him as the magazine's sixth managing editor is John L. Papanek, most recently managing editor of Sports Illustrated for Kids. Separately, Richard W. Angle Jr. was named a senior vice president of Time Warner Publishing, which includes Time's magazine and book companies. He previously served as senior vice president of operations and chief administrative officer at Time Inc. Magazine Co.

DOC.HEAD: Candice Bergen to be US Sprint Spokeswoman
DOC.TEXT: Emmy-award winning actress Candice Bergen, star of the popular ``Murphy Brown'' television series, will serve as corporate spokeswoman for US Sprint, the company said Monday. Sprint, the nation's third-largest long distance company, said it was using Ms. Bergen to project a ``sincere, yet light-hearted manner'' and high professional standards in its fierce ad competition with AT&T. She will appear in a series of ads targeting residential and small-business customers, an area where Sprint is trying to gain market share. The first commercials featuring Ms. Bergen were scheduled to appear Monday.

DOC.HEAD: EC Farm Ministers Struggle Over Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: A new European proposal to slash government farm subsidies to break a deadlock with the United States in world trade talks would sacrifice farmers, an organization of European farm groups said Monday. European agriculture ministers considered the plan Monday for the first time since it was unveiled last week by the European Commission - the executive body of the 12-nation European Community. The ministers planned to discuss the proposal next Monday after getting more details on how the plan would affect farmers. COPA, an umbrella organization for farm groups, announced its opposition to the plan immediately. COPA President Joseph Yverneau said the proposals ``are unacceptable and we totally reject them.'' ``They are totally sacrificing the agriculture sector,'' he told a news conference. ``We should not be put on our knees.'' Yverneau, a French farmer, estimated that at least half the farmers in Europe would be affected adversely by the farm plan. The community's new proposal calls for a 30 percent reduction in farm subsidies for such major products as cereals, rice, sugar and livestock over the period 1986 to 1996. A 10 percent cut is offered in fruits, vegetables and tobacco. No specific trims are suggested in the community's costly export subsidy program. But the proposal signals a willingness to negotiate reductions with other nations. Germany's agriculture minister, Ignaz Kiechle, said the proposal didn't gain much initial support from the European farm officals. He said 10 of the 12 farm chiefs were ``critical to very critical'' of the proposal. British Agriculture Secretary John Gummer, who supports subsidy trims, challenged the United States to meet the trading bloc's proposal. ``I would very much like to see the Americans match it,'' he said The dispute over farm payments has stalled the Uruguay Round of international trade talks, which are designed to overhaul the world trading system. The four-year negotiations, which end in December, are aimed at reducing barriers to trade in 15 areas, including agriculture, textiles and other manufactured goods and services, such as banking and investment. The American push to get the community to do more to cut its farm payments has angered its trading partner. Gummer said the export subsidies are ``part and parcel'' of the community's farm program. ``Just because the United States doesn't like the system we use doesn't mean for some reason or other we shouldn't have a measurement which is fair to everybody,'' he said. He also told reporters the U.S. government ``is a very major subsidizer of its farmers.'' The Bush administration is expected to unveil a new bargaining position on farm payments before a deadline next Monday at the trade talks. The U.S. position is expected to include a 10-year plan for reductions of up to 70 percent in domestic supports and import duties and more than that in export subsidies. The U.S. has backed off a previous demand for elimination of export subsidies. The American plan also would force the community to widen its markets to foreign farm goods and slash farm payments that encourage overproduction. The trade ministers gather later this week to discuss the proposal before it is formally put on the table at the trade talks. The Uruguay Round is being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum and agreement for removing trade barriers.

DOC.HEAD: Germany Media Giant Invests in Former East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Bertelsmann AG, the German media giant, has acquired the top book publisher in former East Germany, the company said Monday. Bertelsmann bought Graphischer Grossbetriev Poessneck GmbH (GGP), which employs about 1,000 people in making 50 million books a year. Bertelsmann said the takeover would open the door to the East European publishing market because of GGP's excellent connections. The financial terms of the purchase was not disclosed. GGP, founded in 1891, is located in the town of Poessneck, not far from the border with Czechoslovakia. Its main business has been related to textbooks published for the Soviet Union, Bertelsmann said. However, a large portion of GGP's traditional contracts are not expected to be taken over, the media giant said. Bertelsmann said its own European publishing houses, located in Germany, Austria, Spain, Italy and Portugal, currently are working at capacity, making about 200 million books a year. Bertelsmann has actively pursued an expansion program in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Limited Soviet Stock Exchange Possible Next Year, Wall Street Says
DOC.TEXT: Trading on a Soviet stock exchange could start next year, but foreigners probably will remain on the sidelines until the ruble is convertible, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange said Monday. ``It's not going to look like some kind of enormous exchange ... but it could begin in a modest way,'' chairman John Phelan Jr. said in an interview at Moscow's international trade center. ``I think it's a real possibility.'' Phelan and a delegation of 20 prominent Wall Street businessmen were invited to Moscow to give a three-day seminar on the nuts and bolts of running a stock market. Dealings in stocks and bonds has been illegal in the Soviet Union since the 1917 revolution. The Kremlin, with the enthusiastic backing of budding Soviet speculators and entrepreneurs, is preparing to allow the return of financial markets as part of the transition to a free market economy. The most radical economic blueprints under consideration call for the establishment of a stock exchange within 100 days. Phelan predicted that whatever economic plan is finally adopted, within the next 18 months the government will have reorganized financial structures, permitted the development of private companies and lifted legal restrictions on private transactions between individuals. ``That would be the logical time for the stock exchange to form,'' he said, adding it could begin as soon as late 1991. More than 400 Soviet bankers, economists, academics and government officials attended the crash course on securities, American style, seeking explanations for several concepts foreign to communist ideology and to their command economy. How does a company get listed on the NYSE, one asked? How do you prevent the government from meddling in market prices? Do American stock exchanges compete with one another? How are dividends paid? Joseph Grano, president for retail sales and marketing of PaineWebber Inc., said it was critical that private ownership develop at the same time as a stock exchange ``for this dream to come to fruition.'' He recommended the privatization of large state enterprises, particularly in the oil industry, before allowing more private ownership of smaller, riskier businesses. ``They need some success stories and if they can show a high concentration of workers, a high concentration of investors, how it works and how successful it can be, then I believe you've started changes in the mindset,'' Grano said in an interview. Since June, the government has permitted the creation of joint-stock companies, although it usually retains a majority of shares. Finance Minister Valentin Pavlov told the seminar more than 400 such companies have been set up. ``The genie's out of the bottle. Nothing can get it back in again,'' said William Schreyer, chairman and chief executive officer of Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc. during a break in the seminar. Phelan later told a news conference that long-term foreign investment in a Soviet stock market probably would require a fully convertible ruble, the right to export profits and the right to receive dividends in a stable currency. The state now controls the price of the ruble against world currencies. The Soviet public will need to overcome its lingering sentiment that profits are wrong and based on exploitation, and its fear of taking financial risks, several Wall Street participants said. ``You have to learn to fall before you can walk,'' said lawyer Joseph Flon. ``There will be ups and there will be downs. The market reflects changes in society, changes in the world.'' Schreyer said public education is still needed, but added, ``I just got the sense that maybe profit wasn't quite as dirty a word as it was.'' The Soviet government has licensed one brokerage house, although it hasn't started work yet. A committee of business people said it hopes to register the first stock exchange in Moscow next month, regardless of whether the government has passed the necessary laws. ``We don't have anything, we don't have space, we don't have the specialists,'' said banker Yuri Chetverikov. ``We have only ideas, and people are very eager to structure this kind of business.''

DOC.HEAD: Benetton, Soviets to Launch Joint Venture In Armenia
DOC.TEXT: Casual wear manufacturer Benetton Group SpA said Monday it has entered a joint venture to produce clothes in Armenia for sale in the Soviet Union. Under the agreement, Milan-based Benetton and the Armenian Ministry of Light Industry each will invest $4 million to set up production of cotton Benetton products at an Armenian factory. The goods will be sold in an unspecified number of stores Benetton will open in the republic and in other Soviet cities, according to a company statement. Benetton projected profits of $11 million - to be received in Russian rubles - after the first three years of operation. Revenues are expected to equal $81 million after three years, based on annual production of 3 million items. Benetton's investment in the Armenian venture is the latest in a series of steps toward tapping Eastern Europe's emerging consumer market. Benetton already has a store in Moscow, nine stores in Hungary, five in Czechoslovakia and two in Poland.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Shutting 2 Ohio Plants Next Week; Shortage of Dealer Orders Blamed
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. will close two plants in northern Ohio next week because of a shortage of dealer orders, United Auto Workers and company officials said Monday. Ford spokesman Joel Pitcoff said the Lorain assembly plant, which makes Mercury Cougar and Ford Thunderbird cars, would be closed for a week beginning Monday. The shutdown affects more than 4,800 workers. He said the shutdown was caused by a lack of dealer orders. The factory was closed for three weeks in January, a week in February, two weeks in April, two weeks in August and one week in September. Pitcoff said the August closing was caused by a shortage of trim materials, but the other shutdowns were the result of sagging dealer orders. Don Schnur, president of UAW Local 2000, said there also will be a weeklong shutdown at the company's Avon Lake Econoline van plant, affecting about 1,400 employees. The crisis in the Persian Gulf is partly to blame for that shutdown, Schnur said. Pitcoff said van conversion operations have cancelled some orders since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Again On War Fears
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices moved up almost $1 per barrel on the futures market Monday as traders decided a lack of news from the Middle East made war seem more likely than peace. Light sweet crude traded as high as $39.40 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange before settling at $38.95, up 96 cents from Friday, on contracts for November delivery. Later contract months were all up by anywhere from 63 cents to 90 cents a barrel. Volume was fairly light because of the Columbus Day holiday. Rising crude prices helped lift heating oil and gasoline futures. Home heating oil rose .26 cent to $1.0296 a gallon for November contracts, with all other delivery months also moving up. Unleaded gasoline went up 1.11 cents to 93.75 cents for November delivery, with other months also trading higher. Natural gas was off .5 cent to $1.93 per 1,000 cubic feet for November contracts. Other delivery months were trading higher, with December at $2.55, January at $2.81 and February at $2.60. Although there was no news dominating the markets, broker Brian Tagler at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. said the items watched by traders were construed as bullish. They included statements from Iraq that attempted to link the Kuwait crisis with Israeli territorial disputes and news that two U.S. pilots were killed in a jet crash while the military looked foing 95 on option - to add to its fleet of 338 aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Mixed in Light Holiday Trading
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices were mixed Monday in light holiday dealings. U.S. Treasuries changed hands only overseas, as domestic government bond markets were closed for the Columbus Day holiday. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell 9-32 point, or $2.81 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when the price falls, increased to 881 percent from 8.78 percent late Friday. Short-term government issues rose while intermediate-term and long-term bonds fell. Credit-market analysts said that reflected nervousness about investing in longer-term bonds until the federal budget impasse was resolved. ``In times of uncertainty, there's a propensity to stay short in terms of investment,'' said John V. Sebastian, executive vice president with Clayton Brown & Associates in Chicago. Congress met Monday despite the holiday as lawmakers sought a budget agreement that would avoid a government shutdown on Tuesday. Early Monday, a divided House passed a new budget plan and sent it to the Senate. In order to achieve a $500 billion cut in the deficit, the plan could lead to tax increases even higher than the $134 billion that originally had been proposed. Yields on three-month Treasury bills were unchanged at 7.24 percent as the discount held at 7.03 percent. Yields on six-month bills were unchanged at 7.42 percent as the discount stayed at 7.07 percent. Yields on one-year bills remained at 7.49 percent as the discount was unchanged at 7.01 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investent in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. Prices of short-term governments rose 1-32 point to 1-16 point, intermediate maturities fell 3-32 point to 7-32 point and long-term issues lost about \ point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. Federal funds quotes weren't available Monday because the Federal Reserve was closed for the holiday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 88 23-32, unchanged from late Friday. The average yield to maturity was 7.77 percent, also unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Traders Cheer Pound Move and Interest Rate Cut
DOC.TEXT: Stock market and foreign exchange traders responded enthusiastically Monday to Britain's sudden entry of the pound into the mechanism that regulates most European currency exchange rates. British homeowners were optimistic that Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major's simultaneous announcement Friday of a 1 percent drop in interest rates could signal a turnaround from two years of economic gloom. The exchange rate mechanism (ERM) of the European Monetary System links European currencies to avert huge swings in exchange rates. With British membership, 10 of the currencies of the 12-nation European community are linked in the system. Portugal and Greece still have not added their currencies. Bank of Portugal Governor Jose Tavares Moreira said Monday that Portugal would not be rushed into the system despite Britain's entry. There had been speculation in the market Friday that the escudo could follow the pound. Under the rules of EMS membership, the British government must halt any rise in the pound outside its upper band of 3.13 German marks to the pound. Sterling is allowed to range within 6 percent of its central rate of 2.96, so its lowest exchange rate is 2.77 marks. If the currency goes too high, Britain must lower its exchange rate either by selling sterling or reducing interest rates. Britain's entry to the EMS boosted the pound to 3.03 marks on Monday from 2.99 at Friday's close on the foreign exchange markets. The dollar-pound exchange rate is not directly affected by Britain's entry into the system, but the pound soared against the dollar Monday on concerns about the U.S. economy and the lack of a plan for budget deficit cuts in the United States, currency dealers said. The pound rose in London to $1.9745 from $1.9455 late Friday and in New York, to $1.9760 from $1.9525. Economists said entry into the system won't be a panacea, but said it was long overdue. ``We've joined a club we should have been in for quite some time,'' said Trevor Cass, foreign exchange manager at Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ``Over the last five years we have seen the European economies benefiting from ERM. The U.K. wants a slice of that.'' Traders on the London Stock Exchange were equally enthusiastic. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up nearly 140 points at Monday's opening before slipping back to close up 57.7 points, at 2,201.6. A record 1.085 billion shares traded hands. ``This is the first fresh buying we have seen in ages,'' one trader said. ``The initial euphoria has faded and in the cold light of day there are other things to look at besides ERM,'' another trader said. Those other things included the continuing Persian Gulf crisis. Ian Amstad, senior economist at Chase Investment Bank, said the market's ``initial knee-jerk reaction to entry has passed. People are now going away to think about what it all means.'' The producer price input figure, released Monday, showed the sharpest monthly jump in 14 years, a 2.2 percent increase from August to September. The more trustworthy inflation indicator, the consumer price index, is due out Friday. Inflation was running at 10.6 percent in August - an 8{-year high. September's figure is expected to be higher because of oil price increases. But British homeowners and mortgage brokers were optimistic that interest rates fell to 14 percent. In Luxembourg, Major shrugged off criticism that the drop was made for political reasons. Recent polls have shown the Labor Party with a 12 percent to 14.5 percent lead over the governing Conservative Party, which was to begin its annual political conference Tuesday. He said he reduced rates because ``U.K. domestic monetary and real circumstances, in my judgment, merited it.'' Britain's slumping building societies, the equivalent of U.S. savings and loans, moved quickly to lower mortgage rates after Major announced the 14 percent rate. Sharon Chilcott, spokeswoman for Bristol and West Building Society, said the mortgage market had been slow for about two years. ``It will take some time for it to pick up,'' she said. ``It may take another fall in interest rates to really get it going again.''
