DOC.TEXT: The stock market settled for a moderate advance in a quiet session Monday amid revived hopes for action to narrow the federal budget deficit. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 13.12 to 2,523.76. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 822 up, 627 down and 490 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 99.47 million shares, down from 153.38 million Friday and the lightest total since a 92.94 million-share day on Sept. 4. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 123.96 million shares. The House passed a new budget plan overnight, raising an alternative to the proposal that was rejected in Congress last week. Analysts said investors were hopeful that an agreement would be reached soon on a budget aimed at narrowing the gap between the government's revenues and spending. Brokers also said traders' spirits got a lift from gains in several foreign stock markets, from Tokyo to London. The Dow Jones industrials jumped about 30 points at the opening, but then began gradually settling back. Activity was muted by the absence of many market participants who were taking a Columbus Day holiday. UAL tumbled 11{ to 91\ on word that a union group seeking to buy the company couldn't get bank financing for a bid in the range of $165 a share to $170 a share. Travelers Corp. fell 2 to 14] on top of a 4]-point drop Friday, when the company estimated a $500 million third-quarter loss and cut its dividend by one-third. British stocks were strong for the second straight session, benefiting from Britain's plan to join in the European Monetary System's exchange-rate mechanism. British Telecom rose 1| to 56}; Barclays 1{ to 30\; British Gas 1 to 56}, and National Westminster 2] to 34[. Gainers among the blue-chip industrials included International Business Machines, up 1\ at 109{; General Electric, up \ at 54{; Procter & Gamble, up ~ at 80; General Motors, up | at 37{, and DuPont, up { at 34]. Abbott Laboratories climbed 1 to 41]. The company reported third-quarter profits of 51 cents a share, up from 44 cents in the like period last year. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $13.57 billion, or 0.46 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .95 to 171.65. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 2.16 to 369.08, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.98 at 313.48. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added .78 to 348.14. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 306.51, up .03.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Declines, Gold Ends Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT change to 0.3 cent
DOC.TEXT: The mighty British pound took center stage again in foreign exchange Monday, while the dollar weakened against all major currencies amid continued economic jitters. Gold prices rose after declining overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $394.90 a troy ounce, up $1.30 from late Friday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $395 an ounce, up $1. Trading was described as thin, with many U.S. banks closed or with abbreviated trading schedules in observance of Columbus Day. ``It was just a lackluster market,'' said Timothy Barton, an assistant vice president and trader at Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago. Barton said technical factors, along with concerns about the weakness in the U.S. economy, helped depress the dollar. Most traders here and abroad also were awaiting a new deficit-reduction package. The House passed a new budget plan overnight Sunday, raising an alternative to a proposal that was rejected in Congress last week. Efforts to narrow the gap between the government's revenues and spending will likely result in a drop in interest rates, and that is expected to further depress the dollar. Market activity continued to focus on the British pound's entry into the Exchange Rate Mechanism of the European Monetary System. The mechanism links European currencies to one another to avoid large swings in exchange rates. The move is expected to help Britain fight inflation and improve that country's economic prospects. The pound jumped to $1.9745 from $1.9455 late Friday in London, and to $1.9760 from $1.9525 in New York. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell to a 1{-year low against the Japanese yen, closing at 130.05 Japanese yen, down from 133.72 yen Friday. It traded at 130.70 yen in London, and 130.475 in New York, down from 132.20. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.53225 German marks, down from 1.5475; 1.2800 Swiss francs, down from 1.2940; 5.1300 French francs, down from 5.1850; 1,151.50 Italian lire, down from 1,160.25; and 1.15135 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1524. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday: 1.5355 German marks, down from 1.5372; 1.2840 Swiss francs, down from 1.2847; 5.1400 French francs, down from 5.1473; 1.7315 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7340; 1,150.75 Italian lire, down from 1,160.50; and 1.1515 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1538. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $392.45 an ounce from $394.35 late Friday. In Zurich, gold closed at $391.80 an ounce, down from $394.40. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.26 to close at a bid $388.69 an ounce. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.670 a troy ounce, up 0.3 cent from late Friday. Silver fell in London to $4.67 an ounce from $4.69.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Soar on Harvest Delays
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices soared as much as 17 cents a bushel Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid heavy speculative buying spurred by harvest delays in the soggy Midwest. Grain futures also advanced. On other commodity markets, energy futures rose; precious metals were mixed; pork futures fell sharply; and cattle were mixed. Soybeans settled 5\ cents to 17 cents higher with the contract for delivery in November up 17 cents at $6.34 a bushel; October soybean meal surged $8.40 to $191.80 a ton. Wheat futures settled 2{ cents to 5{ cents higher with December at $2.79\ a bushel; corn was 2\ cents to 5\ cents higher with December at $2.34 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2 cents higher with December at $1.23{ a bushel. Soybean futures opened modestly higher and climbed gradually until about an hour before the close, when sudden strength in the soymeal market sparked rounds of buying by chart-based speculators, analysts said. ``It was Katie-bar-the-door and we had a strong run to the close,'' said David Armstrong, soybean analyst with AgriVisor Services Inc. in Bloomington, Ill. Cold, rainy weather kept farmers from their fields across a broad band of the Midwestern soybean country Sunday and Monday. Farmers in some areas may have to wait two or three days for fields to dry out, said Gerald Zusel, manager of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s grain-trading operations in Chicago. In addition to delaying the soybean harvest, which is less than half complete, rain can cause yield losses. ``Every time you wet a mature soybean pod and it dries out again, it cracks open a little more and the beans can fall out, so more of them end up on the ground and fewer of them end up in the machine,'' Armstrong said. The rally followed a USDA report late Friday that U.S. exporters had sold 205,000 metric tons of U.S. soybean meal to the Soviet Union in addition to the 150,000 metric tons reported earlier. But Zusel said the market already had discounted the meal sales, which were the subject of rumors early last week. Crude oil and gasoline futures rose sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting continued bullishness amid a lack of conciliatory gestures by Iraq in the Persian Gulf standoff. ``The markets have a natural tendency to stick with a trend until its reversed,'' said Peter Beutel, energy analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group, a commodities research firm in Hoboken, N.J. Light sweet crude oil settled 5 cents to 96 cents higher with November at $38.95 a barrel; heating oil was .26 cent to 1.2 cents higher with November at $1.0296 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .65 cent to 1.11 cents higher with November at 93.75 cents a gallon. Gold futures rose moderately on New York's Commodity Exchange, following crude oil, but silver futures finished narrowly mixed. Gold settled $1.20 to $1.30 higher with October at $394.90 a troy ounce; silver was 0.7 cent lower to 0.3 cent higher with December at $4.728 a troy ounce. Pork futures tumbled on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after posting sharp gains last week. Cattle futures were mixed. All pork belly contracts fell the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound amid profit taking. Hog futures also dropped sharply, pressured by spillover selling from the belly pit and by lower cash hog prices. Live cattle settled .25 cent lower to .05 cent higher with October at 79.25 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .37 cent lower to .33 cent higher with October at 88.15 cents a pound; hogs were .10 cent to 1.25 cents lower with October at 55.92 cents a pound; pork bellies were 2 cents lower across the board with February at 64.45 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Conrail Squeezing Canadian Pacific Over Buffalo-Niagara Falls Link
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede and INSERTS 6th graf: ``Cox said,'' to note unresolvable different reports of length of disputed track; Also on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: A plan to create a new rail link between key East Coast ports and the Canadian interior may fall apart because of a short stretch of tracks between Buffalo and Niagara Falls, N.Y. The tracks - known as the Buffalo-Niagara Gateway - belong to the Consolidated Rail Corp., which has gone to a special court over the dispute with Canadian Pacific Ltd. ``I wouldn't want to be in the position of saying what's motivating Conrail in all of this but certainly a major competitor in their back yard has got to be of concern to them,'' Canadian Pacific spokesman John Cox said last week. ``There are two issues embedded in one - whether the trackage rights are available to us and, second, what the cost will be. Right now we're blocked on both fronts,'' he said. Canadian Pacific has offered to buy the financially ailing Delaware & Hudson Railway and link it at Niagara Falls to CP Rail tracks into southern Ontario. If it can't get the trackage rights, CP may withdraw its $25 million offer, Cox said. Cox said the stretch of track was about 15 miles long. On Monday, Conrail said it was 30 miles. Cox could not be reached to resolve the discrepancy because of the Canadian holiday of Thanksgiving on Monday. The spokesman for D&H was not in his office Monday. The link is vital to Canadian Pacific's plan to use the D&H system to connect the ports of Philadelphia and New York with the Canadian interior. If CP can put all the pieces together, it will be competing directly with Conrail for freight in the Northeast. The D&H, the nation's oldest continually operated railroad, filed in July 1988 for protection from its creditors under U.S. bankruptcy laws. The railroad, which runs from Montreal to Washington and between Albany and Buffalo, owes about $100 million. CP took over operation of the D&H in August and agreed to absorb any further financial losses, which had been running at about $200,000 a month. On Oct. 1, Conrail took the track dispute to a special three-judge court, which was created in the 1970s to oversee the railroad bankruptcy proceedings that created Conrail. Court spokesman Richard Eriksen said the panel would hear the case in Washington sometime between Oct. 10 and the end of the month. ``Conrail filed its motion with the special court because that court has indicated in the past that Conrail should bring cases Conrail believes are under the court's jurisdiction to the special court,'' Conrail spokesman David Neurohr said last week. On Monday, Neurohr said Conrail believes CP should pay its fair share to maintain the Buffalo-Niagara tracks, although he declined to give dollar amounts. ``Under Conrail's proposal, CP and Conrail would both contribute capital funds proportionate to each railroad's use of the tracks,'' Neurohr said, reading from a statement. ``Although the tracks are now in satisfactory condition, the dramatic increase in tonnage proposed by CP is likely to impose an expensive maintenance and repair burden on Conrail that would not otherwise be incurred.'' Conrail negotiated trackage rights with D&H in 1976 but those rights were never exercised, Cox said. Conrail is arguing that those rights would not extend to CP as the new D&H owner. In addition, Cox said, Conrail is seeking to raise the per-car cost for running trains over its tracks. ``Standard agreements between railways these days for operating trains over another railway's line - it's a mileage rate per car - can be anything between about 21 or 22 cents per car-mile to 50 to 55 cents per car-mile,'' he said. That would translate to $6 to $10 per car, he said. ``But what they're looking for is $145 in each direction, so that's a bit of difference,'' he said. This is the second time that Conrail has thrown up a roadblock in CP's effort to buy the D&H. Earlier this year, Conrail refused to negotiate the rights to its tracks between Hagerstown, Md., and Harrisburg, Pa. This led CP to withdraw its initial $35 million bid for the D&H. CP later offered $25 million for the D&H, a bid that was accepted in May by the bankruptcy trustee overseeing the railroad's reorganization. Last week, the Interstate Commerce Commission added its unanimous vote of approval to the deal, and the matter appeared to be headed to U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., for the finishing touches. But that hearing has been postponed from Oct. 10 to Nov. 2 because of the special court case. CP owns about 14,000 miles of tracks in Canada and about 5,000 in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Say Literacy Problems Will Plague Employers in '90s
DOC.TEXT: Work force illiteracy is likely to be a rising problem during the 1990s, but few corporations are preparing for an influx of workers who lack necessary reading skills, a prominent research group said Monday. ``Illiteracy has been a softly ticking time bomb across corporate America,'' said Leonard Lund, education specialist of The Conference Board. ``While precise data are not available, the evidence strongly suggests that the work force skills of many youngsters are declining at a time when new jobs are becoming increasingly sophisticated.'' The study focused on 163 large corporations and found that nearly 20 percent reported problems finding people who can read well enough for entry-level jobs. Almost half the companies said between 15 percent and 35 percent of their workers cannot handle more complex tasks. The Conference Board said 10 percent of the companies surveyed have found up to half of their workers do not have the necessary skills to be promoted. Most of the companies contribute money to programs aimed at fighting illiteracy, but few have their own programs, the researchers said. The Conference Board found that more than 70 percent of the surveyed companies have no formal procedures for testing entry-level job candidates for reading and writing skills. Based in New York, the Conference Board is a business-financed research organization that conducts wide-ranging studies into economic trends.

DOC.HEAD: Interco Reports Second-Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Interco Inc., a footwear and furniture maker struggling to bounce back from huge debt, reported a loss of $35.3 million, or $1.53 a share, in the second quarter. The loss was the result of flat sales in the company's four core businesses, along with more than $64 million in interest expenses paid by the St. Louis-based company. Chairman Richard Loynd said the poor performance was in line with what the company expected because of the soft state of the nation's economy. In last year's second quarter, Interco reported a profit of $118.6 million, or $2.43 per share, but that included the sale of several companies, including Ethan Allen Furniture and Senack Shoes, which brought the company $210 million. Sales from continuing operations in the quarter ended Aug. 31 were $369 million, down 14 percent from $430 million in the same period a year ago. Sales from the company's core businesses in last year's third quarter were $371.3 million. In July, Interco reached an agreement with its numerous creditors on a complicated deal to restructure more than $1.6 billion in debt that the company took on in 1988 to fend off a hostile takeover attempt. The deal between Interco and its banks, medium-term noteholders and subordinated debenture holders helped the company avert bankruptcy. Since 1988, Interco has been selling off subsidiaries in an attempt to repay its debts. It has retained four companies: Converse Inc., Florsheim shoes, Lane Co. and Broyhill Furniture Industries. The plan to sell off assets to pay off the debt faltered, however, when Interco subsidiaries brought far less than the company had anticipated. For the first six months, Interco reported a loss of $76.5 million, or $3.21 per share, compared with a profit of $87 million or $1.14 a share for the same period last year. Sales for the first half were $727 million, down from $899 million for last year's first six months.

DOC.HEAD: RJ Reynolds Buys German Cigarette Brand
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) - R.J. Reynolds Tobacco International Inc. said Monday it has purchased the third largest cigarette brand in former East Germany. The company signed an agreement with the former East German State Trust, Treuhandanstalt, to acquire Club. It currently holds a 15 percent share of the local brand segment in the former East German market. Club has been sold and marketed by RJR Tobacco International's German subsidiary, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco GmbH, under a contractual agreement since March 1990. RJR began selling its Camel, Winston and Reyno brands in East Germany earlier this year. Company officials said the purchase of Club would give RJR an additional foothold in the eastern German market. Production of the brand will be moved next year from eastern Berlin to an RJR facility in Germany. R.J. Reynolds Tobacco is a subsidiary of RJR Nabisco Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Orders New Jets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to CORRECT value of deal; PICK UP 3rd graf pvs, The 757 . . .
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines has ordered 25 new Boeing 757 jets - with an option for 25 more - in a deal potentially worth more than $2.4 billion, airline officials said Monday. ``We're looking at the long-term needs of the airline,'' Continental spokesman David Messing said. ``We know we have higher fuel prices, and some expect a recession, but we want to add capacity for when the economy returns to strength.'' The order for the first 25 jets is valued at $1.2 billion, Messing said. The option on the second package of jets sets about the same price, but will adjusted for inflation, he said. The 757, a twin-engine aircraft that seats up to 190 passengers, will replace older aircraft when delivery begins in May 1993. The planes would help the airline save money if fuel prices remain high because they're more fuel-efficient than other models, Messing said. ``This order is a significant component of a well-reasoned fleet plan we have developed for the '90s and beyond,'' said Continental Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Hollis L. Harris. The order will be largely financed by the Boeing Co. and the engine manufacturer, Continental said in a prepared statement. Continental said it had not yet chosen between Rolls-Royce or Pratt & Whitney to make the engines. In Seattle, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group spokesman Craig Martin declined to discuss Boeing's financial arrangement with Continental. ``We never comment on such arrangements with our customers,'' Martin said. Continental also has an order with Seattle-based Boeing for 100 737s, some of those on option, and with the French firm Airbus Industrie for 40 long-range A330s, some of those also on option. With the order announced Monday, Continental has a total of 190 aircraft on order - including 95 on option - to add to its fleet of 338 aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Philips Working On Digital Tape Machine That Also Plays Regular Cassettes
DOC.TEXT: Dutch electronics giant Philips Consumer Electronics confirmed Monday it was developing a new digital cassette machine that would also play regular analog tapes. The company said the system, when used with digital tapes, would provide the same sound quality as compact discs. Tandy Corp. said Monday it was working with Philips on the technology. Tandy said the system's introduction would depend on action from the U.S. Congress on copyright legislation. Record companies have been fearful that digital audio tapes' ability to make near-perfect copies would encourage record piracy. To help mollify the record companies, DAT was introduced in the United States this summer using a technical standard that prohibits the machines from being used to make second-generation recordings from CDs. Although DAT recorders were first introduced in Japan three years ago, sales have been slow because of their high cost, the lack of prerecorded tapes and opposition from record companies. Unlike conventional digital audio tape machines, the new machine would offer consumers the ability to continue playing their old tapes. Sony Corp. last month introduced a new line of DAT machines including a car player and a Walkman-sized version. DAT, like CDs, use use computer-like digital signals to reproduce sound. However, DAT machines also allow consumers to make recordings that can rival studio equipment in sound quality.
